PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia:

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that: The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, e.g. petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Warships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled and to the Australian Government:
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
foreign warships visiting Australian ports give acceptability to the increasing militarization of the Indian and Pacific Oceans;
W.A. endures a visit of a foreign warship on average every 1.5 weeks;
a situation of de facto ``home-porting'' facilities exists in W.A.;
there is increasing citizen concern that nuclear armed/nuclear powered warships put Australian ports and people at risk in many ways.
Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Australian Government refuse entry to Australian ports to all foreign warships.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate on Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 80 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth.
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth.
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 14 citizens) and Messner (from 152 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Armagh Gaol: Northern Ireland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the practice of strip searching women prisoners in Armagh Gaol, Northern Ireland.
We are appalled that the prison authorities have demanded:-
Women prisoners in Armagh gaol to be strip searched up to 32 times more frequently, on average, than women prisoners in Britain.
Individual women prisoners in Armagh to be strip searched up to 28 times in one month.
The occasional participation of male prison officers in forcing women to undergo strip searches.
The insistence that menstruating women remove their sanitary towels and tampons, in order to facilitate strip searches.

The strip searches currently being practised are violent, degrading and humiliating. They are a blatant violation of human rights, clearly contravening Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. Your petitioners gravely feel that the employment of strip searching in the North of Ireland, by the British Government is designed not for security purposes but to dehumanise and violate the basic dignity of these women prisoners. Your petitioners view the British Governments strip search policy in Ireland as an extension of Britains war effort presently being conducted to prevent Ireland becoming an Independent 32 County Irish Sovereign State.

Your petitioners humbly call upon the Australian Government to lodge a protest with the British Government, calling upon the British government and the Northern Ireland Office to discontinue the practice of strip searching women prisoners in Armagh Gaol in Northern Ireland immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, left Australia on 3 May to travel overseas. He is visiting the United States and Europe. In his absence, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, will be Acting Minister for Defence.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Does the Government agree that the dignity and standards of the High Court of Australia would best be served if Mr Justice Murphy were to resign? Does the Government agree that in all of the circumstances it is inappropriate for Mr Justice Murphy to resume sitting on the High Court Bench tomorrow pending further investigation of outstanding matters, some of which have arisen since his acquittal? I further ask the Leader Government in the Senate: If Mr Justice Murphy does remain on the Bench, will the Government establish by special Act of Parliament a judicial inquiry comprising eminent Australian judges to inquire into and report upon all matters, including those in volume 2 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions, which might bear on Mr Justice Murphy's eligibility to continue on the High Court Bench in terms of section 72 of the Constitution?

—The matters which form the general ambience-I am sorry; the general environment for Liberal senators, of Senator Chaney's question have been considered at some stages by the Government today and will be further considered by the Government today. I wish to make no comment about any matters pending that consideration and certainly I do not wish to make any comment which would, in any way, endorse the comments implicit in Senator Chaney's question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it true that the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, said when addressing the National Congress of the Vietnam Veterans' Association last Saturday that he was not the shadow Minister at the time the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam-the Agent Orange royal commission-reported? Did he distance himself from the position that the Opposition adopted at the time of wholeheartedly endorsing the Royal Commission's report? Does this mean that every time a change takes place in the composition of the shadow ministry we can expect an about-face by the Opposition?

—The Senate will recall that when I presented the report of the Royal Commission to the Senate last year a number of criticisms were made about the Government's holding of a royal commission in respect of the use of chemical agents and the effect on those who served in Vietnam. In fact, Opposition spokesman criticised the Royal Commission as a waste of public money. Of course, that was not the view of the Government, which sought to establish a commission to inquire into all the aspects of the matter, and a very careful statement was put down by the Government in respect of that Royal Commission. I was therefore very surprised to find at the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia's conference on the weekend Mr Fischer, the current shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, taking an entirely different position from that taken by the Opposition last year. He obviously distanced himself from the statements made by his Party at that time. One can only come to the conclusion that, as the Opposition changes its shadow Ministers, it changes its attitudes and policies. It is a bit like saying that it changes its position as often as it changes its socks or stockings. One found a complete inconsistency between the views taken by the Opposition on that occasion and the clearly opportunist approach taken by Mr Fischer at the Vietnam Veterans Association conference on Saturday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Minister note two significant reports today, one from the Business Council of Australia and the other from National Australia Bank Ltd, calling on the Government to place greater emphasis on fiscal policy to restrain inflation through a reduced Budget deficit and a more flexible and balanced approach to wage fixing? Did the Minister also note that an index prepared by the Westpac Banking Corporation and the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research showed that economic activity in Australia fell by 2.3 points in February-the biggest monthly drop for three years? In the light of these reports, Australia's debt burden, its poor export performance and the lack of investment by business, will the Government recognise the growing concern about the economic indicators by taking the necessary decisions to establish a Budget framework which will restrain inflation and encourage business confidence? I further ask: Will the Government make a major economic statement prior to the end of this parliamentary session?

—I have not had an opportunity to see in the Press today reference to the Business Council and National Australia Bank comments to which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle refers. Let me say, however, that those calls are not entirely surprising to the Government. The calls for greater emphasis on fiscal policy are, if I might say so, even in an ordinary year quite seasonal. They come about two to three months before the Budget and they come every year, as do the autumn leaves.
—Which are late, like the Government's action.

—I do not want to lapse into the sort of philosophical mode of a Chauncey Gardener, but let me say that there is no doubt that these calls are cyclical and come to be expected at this time. It also does not surprise me that Westpac's survey of economic activity shows a significant fall in the month of February. The Government expected that; indeed, the Government has said that it was necessary and desirable that the rate of growth in the Australian economy be slowed, and it has taken quite deliberate measures to see that that happens. I was then asked whether, in the light of poor export performance, trade figures and investment, the Government will make a general economic statement. That is not a matter about which I can make any promise or prediction today. Of course, the Government is concerned about the trade figures; we have had discussions about that in this chamber at Question Time and during debates on various matters of public importance and so on. The Government does not hide from its concern about the trade figures, but we do say that those trade figures are a result of the delusions of governments over many years, and indeed of the Australian community, and are to be anticipated. I make the same comment about poor export performance. On the question of investment in manufacturing, the Government is not totally discouraged by the investment figures, particularly in manufacturing industries. They could be better, but they could be much worse. I do not know whether that helps the honourable senator, but that is my answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has there in recent times been any, and if so what, movement in the farming community away from traditional areas of farming into new ones? If the answer is in the affirmative, can the success of that movement be assessed at this time and, again if the answer is in the affirmative, what success has occurred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney mentioned this to me a while ago. I thought he was referring to geographic movement, that is, extension principally of arable farming into marginal rainfall country. There has been some of that in recent years, of course, as there has been at other periods of Australian history. Now, as in previous periods, there has also been a recognition that it has gone too far in some areas into country that is sub-marginal. However, I understand that Senator Cooney is really talking about different products-the same land and the same farmers but changing into different products. To some extent this has happened and for some individual farmers there has been considerable success. I will see whether the Minister for Primary Industry has any comprehensive statistics quantifying movement into new agricultural products, but it is beyond doubt that a number of individual farmers have quite successfully done that. It is probable that there is scope for more of that to be done.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I think such potential that exists should be assessed with some care. For example, in the past various proposals have been put up as a panacea for the ills of farming. One of the most spectacular I can remember in recent times, for example, was the proposal that there should be established a large scale power alcohol industry, using either grain or sugar cane as raw material. Indeed, I remember that the editor of the National Farmer asserted a couple of years ago that the only thing that stood in the way of development of a major rural industry which would employ 250,000 people was government intransigence-that is, government intransigence in the form of refusal to pay a hidden subsidy of 50c a litre on the production of power alcohol. That, of course, was never a viable proposition. It was quite irresponsibly promoted by a number of people, particularly by the editor of the National Farmer. So although there is some scope for this conclusion, the potential, both in economic terms and quantitatively-that is, the number of new producers who could move in successfully to a new type of agricultural product-should be carefully assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Gareth Evans representing his own Department, the Department of Trade, the Department of Foreign Affairs or whoever, but generally the Government. Can he guarantee that the tails-U238-of Australian uranium enriched in the Soviet Union do not finish up in the production of plutonium for nuclear weapons in the French Super Phenix fast breeder reactor? If he can give such an assurance, on what basis can he give it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, the question presupposes that Australian uranium enriched in the Soviet Union on an all-in all-out basis, as I have described it in answer to previous questions, has been sent on by either Finland or Sweden, which I am advised are the only two countries to have used Soviet enrichment facilities for Australian uranium, to other users. I have no information immediately to hand as to whether that has been so. However, as Australian origin nuclear material of this kind is thoroughly kept tagged, it ought to be possible to find that out. But I do not make the assumption that any such material has been sent on from Finland or Sweden to France or, for that matter, anywhere else.
—Don't you know?

—Senator Chipp gave me some indication of this question about an hour ago. I have sought information, but it has not been possible to get it in the time available. I have just indicated to the honourable senator that Australian origin nuclear material is tracked, including the product of enrichment processes. I am able to find out the information, but I just was not able to do so in the time I have had available.

ANSWER.PARA: The second assumption lying behind Senator Chipp's question is that the Super Phenix reactor in France, in Senator Chipp's words, is going to be used for the purpose of producing plutonium for nuclear weapons. I simply make the point that at least the claim has been made by the French that the reactor is designed to be utilised solely for energy production purposes and that plutonium there produced will not be used for nuclear weapons. As I understand it, that is the claim that has been made.

But let me go on from there to say that there is, of course, an embargo on the supply of Australian origin nuclear material for end use in France while that country continues to test nuclear weapons in the South Pacific. The French authorities indicated to us, when this matter arose in another context some little time ago, that France would not act contrary to this ban. Therefore, having regard also to the very substantial quantities of depleted uranium which now exist in France, irrespective of their availability from some Australian source, there is no reason to believe that France would seek to use Australian uranium in the Super Phenix.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you trust the French Government?

—We can operate in this respect only on the basis of assurances we have received. Certainly we have no knowledge of any Australian origin nuclear material being used or being earmarked for use for this purpose in the Super Phenix breeder reactor. We have no knowledge of either of those things to date.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point I make is that regardless of where Australian uranium is enriched, whether it is in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France or anywhere else, from a safeguards point of view, that is to say, ensuring that such material is only ever used for peaceful, non-military purposes, there would be no difficulty in depleted uranium derived from Australian uranium being used in that kind of a reactor in France. I am not saying that it has been or that we want Australian material to be used for any end use in France under our existing policy; but, from a safeguards point of view, there would be no particular difficulty in practice or in principle because the use of such material would be subject to the terms of both the Australia-Euratom and the Australia-France nuclear safeguards agreements. Accordingly, derived plutonium would be available only for peaceful use and would be safeguarded by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TALENTED SECONDARY SCHOOL STUDENTS: UNIVERSITY ENTRANCE ASSISTANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to a report of plans being made by the University of Western Australia to facilitate university entrance for talented secondary school students whose circumstances might otherwise preclude them from tertiary education? Can the Minister comment on the effectiveness of such measures and indicate what Government encouragement can be given to initiatives of this sort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the intention of the University of Western Australia to take special steps to encourage students from disadvantaged backgrounds to enter the university and complete their courses successfully. I believe that the University of Western Australia ought to be congratulated for implementing the Government's policy on increased access by disadvantaged students. It is a fact that, despite the broadening of the social mix of the university population in recent years, it is still the case that students from lower socio-economic groups are still under-represented, particularly in the older established universities such as the University of Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of programs of this nature currently receive funds from the equity provisions of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's program. For example, at both the University of Melbourne and the University of Sydney programs of a similar kind are funded where students from disadvantaged backgrounds are identified, counselled and assisted so that they can enter and study successfully at these universities.

In Western Australia, the Western Australian College of Advanced Education has received $16,000 for a pre-tertiary studies course for Aborigines. The Western Australian Institute of Technology has received a grant of $12,500 for women in business and administration.

These are two examples of the kinds of projects that are currently being funded in Western Australia to broaden the socio-economic composition of the student body. It may well be that the University of Western Australia will receive similar funding should it apply under the equity provisions. In any event it is very encouraging to see universities acting in a socially responsible way and taking special steps to ensure that the benefits available to students are more broadly available than they have been in the past.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a pamphlet published by the Australian Sports Aid Foundation which is headed `Australia Bound for Edinburgh '86'. Inside the flyleaf it has a message from Mr Hawke imploring us all to support financially the Australian Commonwealth Games team which goes to Edinburgh this year in July. The pamphlet includes the statement:

QUESTION.PARA: The Australian Government has incorporated the Australian Sports Aid Foundation with the intention of making your donation to the team tax deductible.

Does this definitely mean that the money paid to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation is tax deductible? Secondly, is any other money paid to support the Australian Edinburgh team also tax deductible?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I recall it-I will have this checked with the Treasurer-donations to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation are tax deductible. I am not aware of whether other deductions to support the team are tax deductible.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does that not mean that the Government is allowing people, through one of its own corporations, to make something tax deductible that would not otherwise be tax deductible?

—As I recall it, donations to the Sports Aid Foundation, irrespective of whether the funds are ultimately destined for that particular purpose or some other purpose, are all tax deductible. But I will have that checked with the Treasurer.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Queensland Young Nationals decided yesterday that the Federal Government should establish an `operation bludger' campaign to stamp out alleged social security fraud? Does the Government support a proposal such as this which would cause distress to many social security recipients? Is it fair to compare the Young Nationals' proposal with the recent Operation Noah drug campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice in the paper this morning that the Young Nationals in Queensland had urged that we have an `operation bludger' campaign to get at what they describe as unemployment beneficiaries who are ripping off the system.
—Other bludgers they don't mind.

—As Senator Walsh has said, the Young Nationals are very selective in the people they pick out. Each year they come up with a proposal of this type. I point out that last year the amount of social security overpayments was estimated to be about $20m. The amount of money which is ripped off the system through tax avoidance and tax evasion is generally estimated to be some hundreds of millions of dollars-in fact it is estimated by the Australian Taxpayers Association to be over $2,000m-but we never have the Young Nationals in Queensland concerned about this sort of rip-off. They are quite selective in what they do. What they want is for people to dob each other in, particularly those on unemployment benefit, in order to cut down the benefits.
—Hear, hear!

—I expect Senator Townley to agree with that thoroughly. But Senator Townley would never agree to people dobbing in people who were indulging in tax evasion or tax avoidance, because he thinks that is fair game and fair play.
—I didn't say that.
—Of course he did. He says it all the time. He is up to his ears in it and always has been.
—Up to his hair line.

—That is unkind, Senator Withers. Also, the Young Nationals in Queensland never complain about the use of public money when it is put to providing a dam on the farm of one of the Premier's children. This is perfectly acceptable, but the Young Nationals come out and want people to dob each other in. They say that they want to do this because Operation Noah was successful. Operation Noah was about a very much more serious problem; a problem that goes right throughout the community. Operation Noah was not the type whereby people were being asked to dob in people who were getting small social security benefits and to create an atmosphere, particularly among people in poorer suburbs, in which people would be encouraged under those circumstances to dob each other in for all sorts of reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I point out that each year people report others for what they think are social security frauds. That has gone on for many years and the figures each year are quite consistent. About a quarter of these reports result in people having their social security benefits reduced. In about 70 per cent of the cases no action should be taken because the reports are not founded. In another 5 or 6 per cent of cases people end up getting more than they got before. That sort of approach by the Young Nationals will only lead to a society whereby people are walking around with great suspicion of their neighbours. I suggest that the Young Nationals would be better off looking at the real wasted money in this community and the real ripping off of revenue which occurs in tax evasion and tax avoidance and in some of the expenditures of the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the decision of the United Kingdom Government to restrict defence intelligence information to New Zealand, as reported in the Australian today. How does this decision affect Australia's practice of passing on United Kingdom defence intelligence to New Zealand? Does the fact that now both the United States of America and the United Kingdom find New Zealand's defence policy such that it is considered unwise to pass on sensitive intelligence affect the Australian Government's attitude to passing on intelligence gathered from Australian sources? How will these developments affect intended changes to the Government's foreign affairs and defence policy to build a new defence relationship with New Zealand outside of the ANZUS Treaty?
—That question is more appropriately addressed to the Minister for Defence. I do not have a brief from him on it, but I will seek one and give Senator Hill a reply as soon as I can.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation state whether airline security has been reviewed in the light of recent developments in the Middle East, in particular the threats of world-wide retaliation against the United States of America?

—The Government deplores all acts of terrorism, particularly those that take place from time to time on aircraft or at airports. Consequently, having regard to events over the past few years in respect of the airline industry, the Government is consistently reviewing the security procedures with a view to learning from overseas experience and protecting the passengers, the aircraft and citizens generally who frequent our airports. The Government is constantly in contact with overseas specialists who are taking extraordinary precautions to prevent terrorism as it affects aircraft and passengers generally. Consequently, those matters are on the agenda of the Department of Aviation almost daily. That has taken place particularly since the recent difficulties that have occurred in various parts of the world. We have responsibility for Qantas Airways Ltd and British Airways, which have been subjected to certain difficulties. We have taken additional steps to protect all of the security procedures in the hope that we will avoid any of the disasters as far as Australian aircraft or aircraft using Australian airports are concerned.

—I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the Prime Minister's admission yesterday on Channel 9's Sunday program that the Government is making slow progress in agreeing on measures for the forthcoming Budget that will allow its trilogy commitment to be met in 1986-87? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will, in fact, honour its trilogy commitment in the 1986 Budget? If not, what parts of the trilogy will be broken?

—I did not hear what the Prime Minister said on Channel 9's Sunday program yesterday and I do not know whether the Prime Minister said anything about the trilogy commitment at all. It is not suggested in the question that he did. I believe that that commitment can be honoured.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to recent comments by Opposition Leader Howard and Deputy Opposition Leader Brown in which they have emphasised the Opposition's commitment to a deregulated system of wage fixation. Is the Minister aware of an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 April 1986 which outlined the findings of a report prepared by the senior economist at Sydney University, Dr Flora Gill? The report claims that a deregulated wage fixing system does not necessarily ensure that wages would be determined by a company's capacity to pay and cautions against uncritical acceptance of collective bargaining as a panacea for problems associated with wage fixation. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the accuracy of the claims made in the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald of a couple of weeks ago, I think it was. In general I think anybody whose judgments are determined by evidence and experience rather than ideological prejudice would have to agree with the conclusions which Dr Gill put forward. We have had in Australia in the past and have in other countries at present an empirical testing of the wage outcomes under collective bargaining and under centralised wage fixing. We had the dreadful experience in Australia after the last Government had its first flirtation with collective bargaining, commencing in May 1981. We had a wages explosion of 14 per cent in 1981 and 13 per cent in 1982. One would have thought that a chimpanzee would have learnt from that experience that experiments at times of reasonably high economic growth with free wage bargaining are likely to produce a wages explosion. Moreover, and perhaps more importantly, this is occurring at a time of continuing recession. In the United Kingdom the Thatcher Government's experiment with a deregulated labour market has produced substantial increases in real wages for the employed, even though the economy is in deep recession, has an unemployment rate of around 13 per cent and still going up. Even under those circumstances those who are employed have achieved substantial increases in real wages. Contrast that with the situation in Australia, where after three years of historically high economic growth, real wages have in fact fallen-or they are about to fall with the next national wage case-and real unit labour costs have been reduced to the lowest point since the late 1960s.

ANSWER.PARA: The fundamental error made by these ideological bigots, who assert that lower wage outcomes would result from a deregulated labour market is that they ignore the existence of unions. If there were no organisation on the labour side of the market-place their theories might well be soundly based; particularly in periods of economic slump wages might fall quite considerably. But the fact is that unions do exist; they cover by far the greater part of the work force in Australia, as they do in the UK. Given that reality, from all the empirical evidence that is available, it is inescapable that a deregulated labour market would produce higher wage outcomes than have prevailed in Australia over the last three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Following the disclosure that seven transport unions in Victoria are giving themselves, their spouses, dependants and retired members free travel on all public transport any- where in Victoria, at a cost of $2m over the last eight weeks, and enforcing their illegal agreement by coercion and by reporting to their union anyone who refuses to comply, I ask: As the Federal Government intends to tax fringe benefits received by employees, does it intend to tax the Victorian Government on the fringe benefits received by employees, does it intend to tax the Victorian Government on the fringe benefits these unionists are receiving at taxpayers' expense?
—I think the short answer to that question is no.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, the Opposition has a very consistent record of swallowing the claims of industry propagandists and then regurgitating them in the Senate. It has done this about almost every component of the tax package. Senator Maguire referred in particular to the fringe benefits tax on entertainment or, as it is more commonly known, the ending of the free lunch, and the ridiculous claims that were made by assorted members of the Opposition-I will specify some of them in a moment-about the alleged employment effects of that taxation change.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for employment in restaurants, hotels and personal services show that in August 1985, which was the last full month prior to the disallowance of those deductions for entertainment expenses, employment in the industry was 284,000, in round figures. In December 1985, which is the latest figure available, that had increased to 303,000. In other words, there was an increase in industry employment in that very short period in excess of 19,000 people, or 6.9 per cent, at the same time that total industry employment increased by 2.3 per cent. In that short period 2.3 per cent is a very rapid increase in total industry employment, but it is absolutely dwarfed by the massive 6.9 per cent increase in employment in that particular industry. It shows to have been quite ludicrous the assorted claims made by industry propagandists and tax bludgers, which were swallowed and mindlessly regurgitated in the Senate by members of the Opposition.

I will give a few examples. According to Senator Messner, 18,500 jobs would be lost. According to American Express International Inc., 40,000 jobs would be lost. According to the national Restaurant and Catering Association, 10,500 jobs would be lost. According to Senator Knowles, quoting the President of the Restaurant and Caterers Association of Western Australia, there had been a drop in business of between 25 and 40 per cent. Perhaps there was in the particular restaurant that Mr Traill operated, perhaps because it was a pretty sleazy second-rate restaurant, but in the industry as a whole the fact is that employment has increased in the four-month period by a massive 6.9 per cent. The prize for the most outrageous, the most irresponsible, the most inaccurate claim of all goes to the mouth from the south, Mr Hodgman, who asserted that there would be 80,000 jobs lost in the industry. What, in fact, happened in the first four months was that employment increased by almost 20,000 or almost 7 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General whether, in view of the answer given earlier in Question Time today by Senator Button on behalf of the Government concerning the Government's consideration of the position of Mr Justice Murphy, he maintains the view that he put to the Senate on 29 April 1980, namely:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have seen the reports to which Senator Coates referred. That promise is one of many irresponsible expenditure and taxation promises which the Opposition Leader has delivered as he has travelled around the countryside. —The Commonwealth has quite satisfactory controls over expenditure by higher education institutes of funds that they receive from us. Funds are made available to higher education institutions via the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. For the most part, those funds appear in legislation or in schedules attached to legislation. So Senator Sheil, like any other honourable senator, has the opportunity to scrutinise the funding decisions made by the Commonwealth on the advice CTEC. —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, relates to Australian exports. Would the Minister agree that for some time our wine sales to Japan have been dropping considerably and that this could be due to the fact that the Japanese consumer is confused with the similarity of the names Australia and Austria? Would it be sensible for our export products to be labelled in such a way that they could be easily recognised-for example, by depicting a red kangaroo, a koala or something similar which is truly Australian-and for only goods of a high standard to be allowed to use that emblem?

—I am always amenable to suggestions as long as somebody does not take up the thought that we should brand some of our wines Emu brand, which I recall drinking in London some 15 years ago with totally disastrous effects. I think we should be very careful. I think that I have had a question on this topic before from honourable senators. I am not sure whether Australian wine exports to Japan have been falling in any significant way. I am certainly aware of some confusion with Austrian products generally on the world market, particularly in Japan in relation to wine. That is because neither Australia or Austria is very well known in other parts of the world. I will take up with the Minister for Trade Senator Elstob's suggestions as to the identification of Australian wines. Australian trade commissioners in Japan have been very quick to try to distinguish Australian wines from other wines sold there, including Austrian wines. Nonetheless, the suggestion is worth pursuing and I will put it to the Minister for Trade.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry able to confirm or reject recent reports that the United States is likely to sell 60,000 tonnes of rice to Papua New Guinea at, I understand, a price which will be 50 per cent lower than the Australian export price? I ask that question in light of the fact that Papua New Guinea is Australia's largest recipient of rice. It receives 52.4 per cent of our total exports and 60,000 tonnes would represent something like 53 per cent of that amount. On the prices anticipated this year for the export of Australian rice that would be a loss to Australia of something like $19m. If there is confirmation of that sale, has the Government been able to communicate with the United States Government and what action is it likely, or able, to take?

—I have not seen the reports that have been referred to but I do have a note from the Minister for Primary Industry which confirms that there have been Press reports along the lines indicated and that the rice growers co-operative has expressed strong concern about this matter in a letter to the Prime Minister. I am advised that the Australian Embassy in Washington has been assured by United States officials that no direct export subsidies for rice sales to Papua New Guinea have been requested under the export enhancement program or other United States Government guaranteed credit programs. I am also advised that United States rice prices have declined significantly in recent weeks as a result of other provisions of the United States farm legislation. As that advice is almost a week old-there may be something to add-I will see whether Mr Kerin has anything to add to it.

—My question is to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to the guidelines for the importation and manufacture in Australia of contraceptive devices and to the manufacture and marketing within Australia of intra-uterine devices. Given the current concerns and proceedings relating to the Dalkon shield IUD, can the Minister say what is the outcome of investigations on the future importation of IUDs? As the provision of safe and effective contraception is a vital issue for women's health, what steps does or will the Government take to ensure the continuing manufacture and/or importation of safe and reliable products, and does the Government have any proposals or mechanisms, firstly, to monitor the use of contraceptive products; secondly, to recall defective or dangerous products; and thirdly, to address the rights to and mechanisms for achieving compensation for personal injuries arising out of the use of such products?

—For some years IUDs have been subject to approval by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. My colleague the Minister for Health has advised that a sub-committee of the Therapeutic Goods Standards Committee was established in 1985 to develop guidelines to ensure the quality, safety and efficacy of IUDs, both medicated and non-medicated. Under present legislation the Commonwealth has power to apply the guidelines only to imported IUDs. The Minister now intends that the guidelines be applied equally, by co-operation between the Department of Health and State and Territory health authorities, to IUDs manufactured in Australia. The issue of national legislation controlling therapeutic goods, including contraceptive devices, is under review. I am concerned that the current litigation against the manufacturer of the Dalkon shield and its attendant publicity may deprive women of a method of contraception which, with the exception of the Dalkon shield, has had acceptable safety. The threat of litigation has led to manufacturers of IUDs withdrawing their products from the market in the United States of America. This withdrawal may lead to an unwillingness on the part of manufacturers to continue research aimed at improving the safety and efficacy of IUDs. That result would not be in the best interests of women. The matter is being pursued by my other ministerial colleagues concerned with it, and I will keep honourable senators informed of developments.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. In answer to Senator Chipp's question the Minister said in relation to the all-in, all-out basis for uranium enrichment in the Soviet Union that he does not know where the tails-uranium 238-end up. Is the Minister then, ignorant of the fact that they do end up in France? If he is ignorant of the situation, why is he ignorant? Secondly, how does the use of this material in France affect our `non-sale' of uranium to France? Thirdly, is he aware of a great deal of evidence to support the fact that Australian U238 is used in the Super Phoenix?

—I could ask a question in return of Senator Sanders. If he did not listen to the answer I gave earlier today, is he deaf or simply stupid? The reality of the matter is that I said our system of nuclear accounting is such that we can take account of all the material that comes out of the Soviet enrichment process which has emanated from one of the customers to which we sell this material. That is what the all-in, all-out system is about. We do have the capacity to track that material. I simply said that since I had advance notice of this question only at around one o'clock it was not possible in the time available to check with the Australian Safeguards Office as to what the particular answer was so far as any material that had in the past been supplied from Finland or Sweden to the Soviet Union for enrichment purposes was concerned. I said it was my advice that we are perfectly capable of tracking that. That is exactly what I said to Senator Chipp, and the honourable senator should not ask such a fatuous question in the future if he does not want to make a total fool of himself.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The Minister has been approached recently by Samson Films of Sydney for permission to use in the script of a television mini-series for children the word `Anzac'. The series is based on an award winning children's book by Nadia Wheatley. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the issues involved in making such a decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may not be aware that the word `Anzac' has been protected since 1920 following the enactment of the War Precautions Act Repeal Act of that period. The use of the word `Anzac' is vested in the Government through the Minister of the day, the purpose being to prevent its commercialisation. For example, one would not want to read about Anzac beer or Anzac milk or Anzac steel. A regulation has been established which gives the Minister of the day the opportunity to decide on the use of the word `Anzac', which members will recall came about as a result of the involvement of Australians and New Zealanders in World War I.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been many approvals under the regulation over the years. Most Returned Services League branch headquarters have the title Anzac House, which has been approved at various times by the Government or by the Minister of the day. In respect of the television mini-series ANZACS no prior permission was sought but it was given subsequently. I am not necessarily critical of that fact because I think that probably it would not be known generally to the media or to the public at large that the word `Anzac' is a protected word. I hope that as a result of the question put by Senator Devlin some publicity will be given to the matter so that those who may believe that they are able to use the word will know that they need to seek the approval of the current Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In the Cabinet's review last week of the fringe benefits tax and its serious detrimental effect on the car industry, did the Cabinet give specific consideration to the impact of that measure in South Australia? Has this assessment of the car industry in South Australia been given to or acknowledged by the Premier of South Australia? Will the Minister now outline to the Senate his assessment of the impact of the tax on the car industry in South Australia-specifically his expectations concerning the extent of the decline in production and the extent of retrenchments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question put to me by Senator Teague is whether specific consideration was given to the situation of South Australia. I do not quite know what is meant by that. Of course the situation of South Australia was taken into account, just as the situation of Victoria was taken into account and, to a lesser extent perhaps, the situation of other States because there is not such a concentration of motor vehicle production in other States. I was then asked whether the problem has been adverted to in discussions with the Premier of South Australia. I have had a number of discussions with the Premier of South Australia about this matter. I do not think I should or could disclose all the details of those discussions, but of course the Premier has made his views clear in public statements about the effects of the proposed fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked about employment. I have said all along that a whole range of issues relating to the fringe benefits tax are speculative because a number of matters will bear on the registration of motor vehicles this year and, of course, on the production of vehicles by the local industry. If I may go through them again, they include the current level of interest rates, the fact that 1985 was a record year, the fact that because of the introduction of unleaded petrol there was a pull-forward into 1985 of orders which might normally have occurred in 1986, and a number of matters of that kind. Senator Teague specifically adverted to the question of employment. I say again that there has been a lot of speculation about the effects on employment, some of which is wild speculation in my view. The senator may have noticed a report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 2 May which purports to be a survey of the employment effects on the downturn in the car industry generally. I quote from that report:

The Australian car manufacturing industry overall is recruiting and not sacking workers despite a downturn in sales and worries over the looming car tax. Mitsubishi has taken on 400 workers this year.
Mitsubishi is a principal manufacturer in South Australia and the reference is to this calendar year. The article continues:

Nissan is employing 300 extra; Toyota is advertising jobs to overcome a `shortage'; Ford says it has not had to shed any staff and GMH says the 500 employees it has lost over the past six months are the result of a wind-down of the Woodville plant announced three years ago.
In addition, major Adelaide automotive component supplier W.H. Wylie and Co. is advertising for process workers to cover normal attrition and keep up its workforce numbers . . .

In SA, Mitsubishi's workforce has increased from about 4,000 at the start of the year to 4,400, while production is running at full capacity of about 300 vehicles a day, despite the general market slump.

There are more figures in that article. Senator Teague might like to refer to them for his own enlightenment and, perhaps, check them out if he wants to. I have every reason to believe that they are correct. Within those figures are some companies who say that they are putting more people on and others who say that they are not. There is a certain element of market success in all of that. Mitsubishi has been very successful in the market in the last year and seems to be continuing to be successful. Other manufacturers are less successful. The Government cannot pay the highest regard to those matters in the context of a fringe benefits tax of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of great regret to us that the Soviet Embassy officials refused even to accept the petition of the parliamentarians of the Australian Parliament. The explanation given to us was that they disputed the contents of the petition which I have just read. Whilst that might seem to us to be somewhat offensive, obviously the allegations that are the basis of that petition are a matter of much greater importance. These include the allegation that some 400,000 Jews in the Soviet Union are seeking to emigrate from the country unsuccessfully. They have been sent the notarised invitations from relatives in Israel which are a prerequisite to emigration; but, notwithstanding their having met those formal requirements, they still have not been given permission to leave the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: There are allegations that there are no Jewish schools or Jewish organisations in the Soviet Union, and that no books in the Hebrew language and virtually no books in any language on Jewish history and culture are published in that country. There is also the allegation that the Soviet internal passport, or identity card, has a special column for nationality. A Jew is recognised as such and must declare his nationality as Jewish. But that fact then restricts him throughout his childhood when applying to be admitted to university and when applying as an adult for employment posts.

These most disturbing allegations have, of course, received extensive corroboration over a long period and cause Australian parliamentarians grave concern. Therefore, I use this forum to put on the public record the petition of Australian parliamentarians in calling upon the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to permit members of the Jewish community within that country the freedom to practise their religion free of persecution and discrimination and the freedom to be reunited with their families and people in Israel. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for a more flexible system of wage fixing and a more co-operative approach to work practices.

I bring that subject forward as a matter of urgency because it is a matter which goes to the standard of living of every Australian. I bring it forward now because there are some heartening signs that the view which has been expressed for some years on this matter by the Opposition is becoming a view with much wider support. I certainly understand from my discussions last week with Senator Siddons that the broad concept of a more flexible work force is supported by the Australian Democrats. It was encouraging to hear the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, last week say something similar. The need for a more flexible work force relates to our need to make changes in Australia that will help us to become a modern competitive economy. If we do not become a modern competitive economy, the difficulties that we are suffering at the moment will become worse and we will see the gradual decline of Australian living standards.

I really want to bring forward this debate not to emphasise points of division but rather to emphasise points of common ground which exist in this area. I do that because I believe that if we are to change attitudes-many Government members have been prepared to say that what we need in Australia if we are to get over our economic problems is attitudinal change-as far as possible we have to say things in common so that the community will understand that this is not a matter of politics but a matter of survival. The simple fact is that we need to be more productive if we are to reduce unemployment and to be better off in Australia. One of the common views of most Australian people is that that this country ought to be able to offer us all the opportunities to have increasing standards of living. The simple fact is that we will not get those increased standards of living unless we have a more productive economy.

I will touch later in my speech on the very useful and high profile example we were given last year in the Mudginberri dispute, which revolved around the resistance to the employer and employees at that abattoir agreeing to approach their work on a basis which would increase both productivity for the employer and income for the employees. Mudginberri stands as a very important example because it indicates that there are both institutional interests and attitudinal interests which really go against economic efficiency. Why was it that an employer and a group of employees who simply wanted to be more efficient, to increase their incomes and to become more productive had to go through the travail they went through at Mudginberri of pickets, applications to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, applications to the courts and very protracted and expensive legal proceedings?

The sad fact is that a great deal of the debate on this issue is obscured by political point-scoring. It is the view of the Opposition that, if we could move away from that and move to a point where we can start to address the real needs of the community and examine what needs to be done in work places around Australia, we would have some chance of meeting the challenges we have at present and getting over the difficulties we have with our balance of payments and in many other areas. It is important that we get public recognition and acceptance of the need for change. We need public recognition of the fact that many of our problems are attitudinal and we need a common effort to change attitudes.

I do not intend in this debate to address the question of straight-out industrial disputes. I think most Australians would accept that the sort of strike action we have seen recently, which has held back some $150m worth of exports of coal at a time when we have a balance of payments crisis, is absolutely absurd and against the national interest. I do not want to tackle that issue in any detail, although I must acknowledge it as a very substantial problem. I suppose that anybody who has travelled by air in Australia in the last week-most honourable senators would be in that category-would agree that the inefficiencies and additional costs incurred by industrial action in the airline industry over that period are scarcely what we need if we are to have a more competitive economy. We will not solve our problems if we maintain many of the attitudes of the past.

The encouraging thing is that around Australia, from a whole series of different sources, we see the beginnings of an acknowledgement of the need for change. We see the beginnings of a new public awareness of the problem. I think that is easily understood because of the publicity which has been given to the external deficit, which is a serious difficulty for Australia, and the publicity which has been given to the value of our dollar since the Government, in action supported by us, floated it. The Government predicted a current account deficit of around $10.8 billion. That is a very high figure, but the worrying feature of the external deficit is that we had reached the figure of $10.4 billion by March. In other words, with three-quarters of the year passed, we had already almost got to the point of the external deficit which was predicted for the whole year in the Budget only last August.

Quite clearly there is a broad public understanding that something is wrong. Most of the people of Australia realise that we are buying from the world much more than we sell to the world. Most people have the sense to realise that we cannot keep that up without running into difficulty. We certainly cannot keep that up without substantially increasing our external debt and putting our country substantially at risk in the future. The floating of the dollar has again been a very high profile element of the Government's economic management. I think most Australians are aware that there has been a very substantial drop in our dollar, and they understand that that is something which will reduce our standard of living because the very many goods we import are going to be much more expensive for us, and the goods we sell are, of course, not appreciating in any real value. So there is a loss to Australian consumers. I put the view on behalf of the Opposition that understanding that there are problems is the first step in finding solutions.

The symptoms of our uncompetitiveness are many. I have already mentioned the balance of payments and the fact that month by month we find that again we have sold very much less than we have had to buy. Figures of around, or in excess of $1 billion a month have become part of our monthly reading. I suppose the most sobering set of figures is that of our performance as an exporting country. In 1953 this country with a small population was the eighth largest exporting country in the world. In 1983 we had slipped to twenty-third. In absolute terms, in 1953 we produced 2.6 per cent of the world's exports; by 1983 we produced only 1.2 per cent of the world's exports-the largest fall experienced in any so-called modern economy. The ratio of exports to our general gross domestic product has declined from 20 per cent in 1953 to less than 13 per cent in 1983-84. So as a trading nation our position has very substantially diminished.

The most serious aspect of that problem is that our export of manufactures has diminished. We have had a particularly poor performance in that area, whereas on any comparative basis-in primary industry and in mining-we have done reasonably well. We have a slipping share of trade in those areas which involve the use of a large amount of labour and high value-added costs. Our exports of manufactured goods constitute only about 18 per cent of our total exports; that is a slipping figure. Only a couple of years ago it was 22 per cent of our total exports. the figure is going steadily downwards. Yet in the industrialised countries with which we normally compare ourselves we find that 75 per cent of their exports are in manufactured goods. World wide export trade is 60 per cent manufactured goods. We think of ourselves as a sophisticated country, yet in Brazil the figure is 39 per cent and in Argentina, 24 per cent. Australia is only 18 per cent. In other words, a tiny part of our exports are in manufactured goods. If we compare ourselves with a European country such as Spain, which is not seen as one of the mighty industrialised countries of Europe, we find that it is producing 71 per cent of exports in the manufactured goods field.

The importance to us, and the reason why I have lingered on those figures a little, is that world trade is going up and up in manufactured goods; it is not going up and up in the exports we predominantly have. That is a very dangerous situation in the long term for Australia and it points to the fact that we must do something about our manufacturing industry. It points up the common view of both the Government and the Opposition, and I am sure the Australian Democrats, that we must have manufacturing industries which are growing, which are outward looking, and which are internationally competitive.

To complete the symptoms of our malaise, we have interest rates which are currently the highest real interest rates in the industrialised world; we have consumer price rises which are several times higher than those of our competitors; and our inflation rate is now at about 9.2 per cent on an annual basis compared with 3.2 per cent for the United States, 2.4 per cent for Japan, 0.9 per cent for Switzerland, 0.1 per cent for Germany, and 5.1 per cent for the United Kingdom. Our comparative position is slipping. Our inflation rate is far higher than that of our trading competitors. Whilst our dollar has recovered slightly against the American dollar, if we look at the whole basket of currencies against which we trade we find that our dollar is worth about 10 per cent less than the value forecast in the Budget only last August.

All of that is central to the concerns that we are expressing about the lack of flexibility in our labour market. I mention Mudginberri as an example of an attempt by an employer and employees to achieve higher productivity and hence to do something towards solving that problem. We need to get that sort of attempt at every work place in Australia, but instead of that what we have is a system which is quite inflexible with respect to wage fixing and which also tends to be quite inflexible with respect to non-wage benefits and to be very inflexible with respect to the way people work within a work place. It tends to lead to demarcation disputes instead of the sort of co-operative common approach to the job which is required if we are to improve our situation.

Within the present system there is little or no incentive for a co-operative approach between employers and employees and, in fact, the present system lends itself to destroying that sense of common purpose. There is no doubt that that problem is contributed to by the trade union movement. It is often also contributed to by management, which fails to encourage the positive attitudes on the part of the work force and to work with its work force in a way that will encourage the development of common attitudes.

We see a need for change. We see it at the institutional level as well as at the attitudinal level. The inflexibility we have in our labour market is, in fact, the major impediment to the international competitiveness of our economy. Labour costs are the major cost item and there is a direct impediment to the growth of our economy. We are seeking more flexibility in the interests of developing less of the `them and us' attitude and more of the common purpose. In that sense, the Opposition welcomes the sort of comment that was made by Senator Button last week both in the Senate and in the media. I quote what he said on the Schildberger radio program on Wednesday, 30 April:

Whether it's at that end of the scale in respect of small businesses, or whether it is in respect of the accord generally, I think anybody who thinks about it recognises that gradually we have to free up some of the provisions of the accord. I see that as a necessary development into the future, and I think a lot of other Ministers do too, and I think the ACTU would.

That is not a matter on which the Opposition seeks to score a point. That is simply a matter on which we say it is fundamentally important that it should not be just the Opposition which is putting out this message; it is important that the Government is also prepared to acknowledge that aspect of the changes that are needed in Australia, as indeed changes in so many other areas are needed. We think it is important that it should also be acknowledged by trade unionists, and I will come back to that in a moment.

This debate takes place in the context of a week in which we expect that the industrial relations policy of the Opposition will become public. Within the next week or so that document will be released. That document will need to be looked at in the context of this need for fundamental change. It represents our contribution to thinking at this time to the institutional changes that can be made to produce more positive attitudes amongst both employers and employees and which will raise the productivity of this country. What is released in that document later this week will be the continuance of a debate which the Opposition has promoted over a very long period and which in particular has been promoted by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. John Howard has long held the view that tackling this area and getting greater flexibility into the system is a very important aspect of getting a better deal for Australia. I do not wish in this debate-indeed I do not have time in this debate-to quote at great length what he has had to say, but let me quote a couple of comments he made the Monday before last at the annual dinner of the Australian Finance Conference here in Canberra. I take just a couple of paragraphs from that speech. He said:

This inflexible, centralised Accord approach ignores the fact that national wealth and national productivity is the sum total of the wealth generated by, and the productivity of, individual enterprises and that unless the right climate for wealth generation and productivity improvement is produced at an individual business or enterprise level, then the cake will not get larger.
A little later he said:

The system also robs too many entrepreneurs and their employees of the capacity to make sensible workplace decisions about how their businesses should be run, how their workers should be remunerated and how their productivity can be lifted.

The great risk, of course, is that this debate is diverted off into a sterile argument about some detail of policy instead of concentrating on the basic need that this country has for a more flexible and more productive economic system.

In the time that remains to me I would like to make some reference to what I think is a quite notable contribution to this debate by Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon in a paper which was delivered in February 1986 but which has seen the light of day only more recently. I commend that paper for a detailed reading by people who are concerned about the economic future of this country, not because I agree with every word that Mr Fitzgibbon has had to say but because I think he has made a very important contribution to thinking and he has indicated that important elements of even the trade union movement are prepared to face these changes. I quote from paragraph 34 of that speech, where he referred to the problems of Australian manufacturing industry and, having put aside the idea of simply controlling imports to solve our problems, he said:

If you attempt to control the imports you may do so by protective means and that protective means can fuel the whole cycle of inefficient industry in competition with outside industry unless there is some new thinking in respect of the mode that we adopt to ensure efficient relationship, one part of the economy to the other.
A little later, he said:

To anybody who wants to think in general about the situation, the developments automatically answer the question as to whether or not industrial relations can stand aloof from all the other forces shaping economics. They cannot stand aloof and there must be an understanding that as a society we are not any longer in competition with like societies.
Mr Fitzgibbon there acknowledged the fact that we are now competing on a thoroughly different basis and, therefore, we have to change our thinking. He said specifically in paragraph 50:

. . . what is required is to change the thinking of people by exposing more and more groups to the advantages inherent in a change of thinking. In other words, it is necessary to keep educating portions of the community to an understanding of the advantages of the material gains inherent in a more co-operative productive society.

Mr Fitzgibbon certainly addressed himself in those rather general terms to the problem, but he went on to deal with some of the more detailed points which tend to give rise to what I would describe as a divisive and unthinking debate rather than an attempt to come to grips with the problem. He referred, for example, in paragraph 76 to the harm that can be done in certain areas by a rigid concept of comparative wage justice. Of course, in fairness to him, he defended the application of that principle in many circumstances but he pointed out there are circumstances where it can be destructive to apply it. I think that is a very important point. He pointed out that that is something that needs consideration and he talked about the fact that, if one has a system which is so rigid as to prevent a reward for special endeavour, that will inevitably mean that there is no special endeavour.

To sum up what I see those comments meaning, what Mr Fitzgibbon said is that if we want this economy to be more productive certainly we must make sure that there are genuine incentives for people to try harder and to be more productive. Since my time has expired, I must close this speech and simply say to the Senate that I hope there will be a positive and constructive attitude to achieving change in this vital area for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a 20-minute speech by Senator Chaney on an urgency motion by the Liberal Party of Australia calling for greater flexibility and co-operation in the work place. The first half of the speech concentrated on taking us through a tour of the trade statistics, a tour I have no difference with in terms of the statistics elicited and the facts brought out. In fact, many of the things in the first half of his speech were truisms and I am pleased to see that they are recognised. The issue is not about what is the state of the economy and what the problems of the economy are; the issue is how one solves those problems. The Liberal Party has chosen soon to showcase its industrial relations policy. This debate today can be fairly said to be the first shot in the program of showcasing that policy.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of his remarks Senator Chaney lamented in passing two disputes that were current within recent weeks in Australia. I want to caution very strongly about that use of statistics because it ignores the fact that industrial dispute levels in this country are at levels known to us only two or so decades ago. There will always be a dispute of one type or another. To select those disputes to try to pretend that the picture is serious is a misrepresentation of the statistics.

One is concerned about export industries. Senator Chaney mentioned coal. Against the unfortunate example of coal I put the very fortunate example of the iron ore industry, which is critical to our export income, an industry which has been working under the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Labor Party accord on a consultative council basis to try to identify and reconcile problems in that industry before they become disputatious. The record of that industry was notorious under the Liberal Government. The industry was more disputatious than almost any other. It was well and truly above the general level of industrial dispute statistics. It is now well and truly below that level. That is a living example of how a Labor government, working through the prices and incomes accord, can bring greater flexibility to the work place and achieve greater harmony and thus greater productivity. Senator Chaney dwelt on the fact that productivity breeds living standards. We have never denied that. We are pursuing it under our policies.

As I said, this matter of urgency attempts to showcase the central plank of what we will soon see to be the Liberal Party's industrial relations policy. Under the Howard leadership of the Liberal Party, we have waited 10 months to receive it. Mr Howard hung his hat on the policy as being his critical area for change. It comes out at a time when Mr Howard's leadership is very much on the line, when he is approaching single digit popularity in the polls. No doubt the Liberal Party is concerned to market the policy very strongly. Unfortunately, Mr Howard is being quoted as saying that some of the aspects of his policy will bring five years of industrial chaos. Also unfortunately, he has been quoted as calling for a thousand Mudginberris-a disputatious and dislocative dispute in the Northern Territory. If they be the costs of that policy, the Australian community has the record of this Government to stand against that chaos and disputation, a record of harmony and achievement. Without striking another blow in this debate, the case is ended.

We have been waiting patiently for the last three years and two months, since we took the treasury bench, for the Liberal Party to produce an industrial relations policy. We have been through the period in which, under the Opposition's Peacock administration, the Macphee-led wets or pragmatists fought the Howard dries. We are now in the dry or arid phase under Howard. It has taken about 10 months for the jewel in Liberal Party economic policy, its industrial relations policy, to be given birth. It has been a difficult birth, too, because on 18 February Mr David Trebeck of the Liberal Party issued a confidential memo to Mr N. A. Brown and Mr Howard, calling for a way for the policy to be marketed. While this document is the property of the House of Representatives, I will go to some aspects of it. It set out a script as to how the policy should be sown in advance with a number of key people and it set out, in a crass and arrogant way, how some people needed to be neutralised and how Brian Noakes, the leader of the Confederation of Australian Industry, should be bypassed and undermined.

As this policy's marketing continues, we will see how well the script and the cast as selected by Mr Trebeck perform according to their assigned roles; whether businessmen who are potential supporters come out in the way they are scripted by Mr Trebeck and whether Mr Trebeck succeeds in his initiative to neutralise Bill Dix, Sir Peter Abeles, Brian Loton, Chuck Chapman, John Utz and Brian Kelman.
