We note in the script for selling this policy that eight journalists are indicated to be supporters and 17 need to be neutralised or are opposers. Perhaps the Liberal Party has launched this matter of urgency on the basis that the Press is already against it according to the Party's internal documentation.

Let us turn to the principle of flexibility that is under debate. One ought to commence a discussion on flexibility in the wage area by going to the position that exists, so that we do not debate an illusion. All too often in industrial relations-an area in which the Liberal Party regards itself as being at war with the unions-terms are misused as if this were a real war. Terms are given which do not describe what happens. Flexibility in the wage area applies now. If the Liberal Party strategists in preparing their policy cared to consult industrial law and lore, they would know that the overwhelming number of awards in Australia are minimum rate awards-there are very few paid rate awards-which constrain employers to pay a minimum amount and no less. Employers are not constrained not to pay more if they choose.

Under the accord, unions have given a voluntary commitment before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission not to make extra claims. No claims are being made in the work place beyond wage indexation, but employers have given no such commitment. Employers have infinite upward flexibility on wages. Concerning flexibility, what applies in law and the real situation before the Arbitration Commission is that flexibility which rests with the employers. If it is to be argued that there should be downward flexibility, somebody should produce an argument why an independent arbitrator, with distinguished service in industrial relations, hearing a case from employers and unions and interested third parties who have been granted leave to appear, and making a decision based on justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case presented, should have that decision departed from simply because it might suit Liberal Party demonology. That case has never been put, but it is what really happens now. Until that case is rebutted it cannot be strongly argued with any rationality that a case has been put that is convincing.

There is a tendency to mutilate some of the languages in industrial relations. We have heard, not on this occasion-I respect Senator Chaney for this-but on past occasions, and doubtless we will hear in the future, about unjustified or large wage claims. In this whole debate about industrial relations, the things focused on are the unjustified claims that are alleged by the Opposition. Of course, the Opposition knows that under the mechanistic procedures of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, unions file ambit claims which, by their very nature, are not the claims which the unions are seeking to have met. This shallow and misrepresenting focus on ambit claims being regarded as if they were genuine claims is the sort of lexicon of the labour debate on which the Opposition focuses. I trust that in this new-found search for a more deliberate and intelligent dialogue, those phrases will no longer apply.

The assumption underlying all that Senator Chaney said in his speech was that there would be downward flexibility. I counsel him that were his ideas picked up the result that he seeks to achieve may not be achieved. Senator Chaney seems to think that it would be unlikely for there to be any upward flexibility if negotiations were left to small units in the work place. I can think of a number of small or medium businesses in which, if the no claims commitment were removed from unions, there would be an immediate rash of wage claims. The lid would be off the accord and there would be immediate upward flexibility. In those types of enterprises, the shortage of skilled labour is crippling. They would simply bid up the price of that skilled labour as a market rate rather than as an award rate to try to attract more skilled labour. Upward flexibility would dominate. A wages pattern would be set up which would create a reverse form of flow-on.

Unlike in the last year of the Liberal Government, we still have strong and vibrant economic growth. The economy has performed year after year with 5 per cent economic growth. We are performing at that level now. Because of the massive increase in jobs available to the community, in some key areas, shortages of labour occur. If, at this stage of our economic growth phase, the lid was taken off extra claims and flexibility was given, it is very possible that we would have a wages explosion reminiscent of the Fraser years as the relativities were dragged out backwards through those areas where flexibility was conceded. I put it to members of the Liberal Party of Australia that, if they are serious about looking for a general level of costs in industry that can be contained in wages, their own theory may well skewer them on the pinnacle of experience. It may just be that it will turn out to be totally counterproductive.

It is important to state that the accord has removed from industry the element of indecision and uncertainty. In industrial relations the greatest cause of disputes and disharmony is people not being able to predict whether their income levels will remain stable in real terms, fall, or do something else. The accord has assured all Australians in the work force-all those 6.5 million people who earn their living by working in this country-that the real purchasing power of their wages will remain stable, will increase over time, and that the social wage, in the form of Medicare as we gave it last year and in the form of other services and goods provided by government, will also increase so that their living standards, and not just their wages, will rise. It is our conviction that people are concerned about living standards, not a paper chase after money wages, which is illusory. The accord delivers the real value of living standards and not the illusion of paper wages.

Coming back to the debate on flexibility it ought to be conceded, if this debate is to have any credibility, that there is considerable flexibility in the wage fixing structure now. Without the flexibility that I refer to it would not have been possible for the cost of Medicare to be discounted from the consumer price index. Without the flexibility that I refer to it would not have been possible to negotiate accord mark 2 to make possible a 2 per cent cut in the consumer price index for the devaluation effect. Had we freed up the labour market we would have to negotiate each claim case by case. In some cases we might succeed, in many we might lose, and we would not get the flexibility which provides a major instrument for government negotiation and an ability to adjust the general level of wages according to all other movements related to the social wage or the wider economy.

It ought to be recognised in this debate too that there is flexibility before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in negotiating or arguing for anomalies and inequities where, under the work value principles, the nature of work changes. There is flexibility in those circumstances to appear before the Commission and make a case as to what is new and what is in need of flexibility.

Senator Chaney resorted to the ploy of quotations in order to bolster his case. Let me follow his example. I think the main flaw in his argument is that he tended to overstate individual flexibility, when there is a basic recognition of general flexibility through the areas that I have referred to. I mention again Medicare, the 2 per cent discount for devaluation, and the ability to argue anomalies and inequities cases. On the subject of flexibility, let me go to the historic report of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems which was commissioned under this Government. This Committee, for the first time since Federation, carefully and calmly went through all the submissions from the industrial relations environment, economists and other commentators, and drew forth a report which picks up, I think, the essential character of change for Australian industrial relations. The Hancock Committee stated in its report that it did not believe that relativities were a sensitive signalling device. It said that this was because wage relativities do not respond readily to changes in the underlying conditions of demand and supply and that the allocation of labour is insensitive to change in relativities between the wage levels of major categories of labour. Honourable senators will agree that that is a fairly emphatic statement by the Hancock Committee after its detailed investigation. The assumption that Senator Chaney has made is that wages respond in the manner the Hancock findings say they do not. Not only the Hancock Committee holds that view. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has reached a similar conclusion. In its `Employment Outlook' for September 1985 the OECD said:

While one would expect a flexible wage structure to aid labour market adjustment it is not clear how important this is in practice. Even in a situation of a relatively inflexible industrial wage structure labour mobility may occur smoothly on the basis of expected life-time earnings and availability of job opportunities.
Talking about Australia, the OECD said:

In countries pursuing consensus policies to achieve aggregate wage moderation care is also needed to ensure that attempts to substantially increase relative wage flexibility do not comprise this goal.
That is not the full extent of my quotations. The Business Council of Australia, an employer body, in a letter to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, said:

Where shortages have emerged, wage flexibility and remuneration differentials are not a major contributing factor. Accordingly, there is little justification for `freeing-up' the system solely on the grounds of trying to alleviate shortages of labour in a relatively narrow range of specific occupations in particular areas.
I cite, therefore, the Hancock Committee, the OECD and the Business Council of Australia as major authorities going against the thrust of what Senator Chaney has said.

Senator Chaney also drew some comfort from Charlie Fitzgibbon's recent speech which has been sent to the Economic Planning Advisory Council and on which EPAC is currently working. I think it should be said, so that the record is balanced and so that there is no offence to my old mate and militant firebrand, Charlie Fitzgibbon, that when he was asked about Liberal Party claims concerning his speech he said, and I quote from the Age of Thursday, 27 March:
It is absolute nonsense to say that . . . I have nothing but contempt for the Opposition's policy because it is designed to produce conflict in this country, which we need like a hole in the head.

So said Charles Fitzgibbon, the central plank upon which Senator Chaney has based a lot of his argument. As I have a minute left, I should defend Senator Button because he was also quoted for comfort by Senator Chaney. In the Schildberger interview quoted by Senator Chaney-this was not quoted-Senator Button, in talking about wage flexibility, said:
But let me say that possibility in my view has to be borne in mind and has to be thought about. It is being thought about.

This Government has a flexible view about the future. It is not cast in granite with rigid policy objectives; the Government has a flexible view about how to achieve those objectives. Sure, we will look at flexibility but certainly in the circumstances of Australia today we will look at it in terms of ensuring that the economic growth we have been able to generate, the wages approach that we have been able successfully to implement, the low level of industrial dispute that has occurred under our leadership, the growth in the economy that has occurred under our leadership, the increase in productivity that has occurred under our leadership and the greater harmony in the workplace that has occurred under our leadership are continued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the need for more flexibility in wage fixing in Australia. On this point, the Australian Democrats agree with the Liberal Opposition. I suspect, however, that that is probably the only point on which we can agree. I listened to Senator Chaney's speech with a great deal of interest. Essentially, it was a plea to find common ground in the area of industrial relations as to how we may free up our wage fixing policies in this country. As far as the Democrats are concerned, that plea will not go unheeded. We agree absolutely that, unless we find common ground and a way to have a more flexible wage fixing policy in this country, industry will never become efficient. It certainly will never become export orientated. It was a pity that Senator Chaney, in the course of his remarks, did not give us some details to get our teeth into. How do the Liberals propose to have a more flexible wage fixing policy? I realise that Senator Chaney is under some constraint because his Party's detailed policy has not yet been released. In that respect it is perhaps a pity that we are not debating this subject after the release rather than before.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only surmise that two aspects of the Liberal Party's flexible wage approach will be of grave concern to the Democrats. In looking for flexibility we can do one of two things: We can hit the unions over the head-we can wish that they were not there-or we can try to get a flexible wage policy which does not embrace the trade union movement. If that is the Liberal approach it is doomed to failure. Whether we like it or not unions are a necessary part of the Australian system of conciliation and arbitration. It is written into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. We cannot fix wages without the involvement of the unions in our system of conciliation and arbitration. So to that degree unionism is a part of the Australian way of life.

The Democrats' approach is this: Let us accept the fact that unionism is a part of our way of life. Let us attempt to get a new attitude by the unions; let us attempt to get co-operation rather than confrontation. Do not let us try to have collective agreements that seek to exclude the fact that the unions are around because if we do we will inevitably hit a brick wall, we will precipitate confrontation, and we cannot possibly hope to get co-operation. I hope that the Liberals' ideas of flexibility do not mean flexibility downwards as far as wages are concerned. Again I believe that that is an unrealistic approach. We cannot negotiate wages downwards while at the same time we have a centralised wage fixing system through the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which sets minimum wages and conditions. On that basis the two approaches are absolutely contradictory. I ask: Firstly, does the Liberal Party hope to exclude unions, and secondly, does the Liberal Party mean, when it talks about flexibility and presumably collective agreements, that it is hoping by that mechanism to push down wages? If it does, its policy is doomed to failure, in the Democrats' opinion. However, we believe that there is a place for collective agreements to be negotiated in this country within a legal framework that is binding on both parties, and, furthermore, we believe that this can be done in the context of the accord.

Some months ago I introduced the Employee Participation Bill 1985 in the Senate. It is still awaiting debate. So far the Liberals have shown little interest in employees participation, judging from their reaction to the Bill that is before the Senate. Unless we attempt to get co-operation with unions and with the work force generally we will never get industry efficient and we will never get a better and more flexible approach to wage fixing.

When I was first a senator from 1980 to 1983 I was a member of the now famous Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation under the chairmanship of Senator Harradine, whose opinions on industrial relations I almost entirely agree with. His chairmanship of that Committee was very efficient and very businesslike. We received submissions from most of the important unions in this country, from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and from the majority of employer organisations. Two matters became abundantly clear to me as the evidence from all the representatives of industrial relations in this country poured in. I believe that they were also apparent to other members of the Select Committee. Firstly, the 300-odd unions around the country value and respect their independence. In my view, there is no way we will ever get any meaningful amalgamation of the greater number of unions in this country. Certainly we will never get down to the German model, which has 16 or 17 trade unions. Union amalgamation as a fundamental reform in industrial relations in Australia is out. We have to accept as a fact of life that there are a lot of unions.

The second matter that became abundantly clear to me during the Senate Industrial Relations Committee's work was that our system of conciliation and arbitration is so entrenched that it could not be disbanded without a revolution. We have to accept that we have conciliation and arbitration in this country, and it is so widespread and is woven so extensively through the fabric of our whole society that we have to accept it. The accord accepts the facts of life and to date it has been successful. What the Democrats would like to see is a Bill introduced into this Parliament which would allow direct bargaining and collective agreements to be voluntarily negotiated between unions and management-both parties wanting to negotiate-in selected areas. There are industries in which the two parties should get together to negotiate collective agreements on a broad range of issues, not just on wages and conditions. The mining industry would be a case in point, as well as industries that have large export contracts. Some small businesses could best negotiate agreements relating to their particular area of activity.

Having said that, I do not want to give the impression that we could have widespread collective agreements that would generally replace our centralised wage fixing system and the accord. I believe that in specialised cases we could gradually introduce collective agreements into Australia and then let that process gather strength and be gradually phased in. However, those collective agreements will not be successful until we recognise two fundamental things: They have to be negotiated with the unions and they have to be negotiated on a broad range of issues. Certainly no attempt should be made to negotiate wages and conditions downwards because that would be in absolute contradiction of the accord and of our minimum wage setting practices. We could negotiate a period of three years peace in a specific industry; we could negotiate that wages should escalate in line with the consumer price index or some other index specifically for that industry and for the length of the contract. It is fundamental that the starting point for any negotiation has to be on above award conditions, not below them.

Collective agreements that allow us to negotiate on a whole range of issues, including employee participation, offer a way to streamline Australia's industries through giving incentive to workers and management to restructure in terms favourable to both parties. By making over-award payments legally binding, collective agreements would avoid the instability and industrial unrest associated with over-award payments at the present time. On this basis there would be no reaction against collective agreements, as there has been in the past. The real advantage is that they allow negotiations on an extremely wide range of issues-not just industrial issues but all kinds of issues relating to the industry, for example, new equipment which could modernise the industry, security of employment, and all the other things involved in modernising and revitalising Australian industry.

Industry has been hamstrung by inefficient work practices and by not keeping abreast of technological change. Flexibility is vital, but not just in the wages area. I am saying: Get the unions involved in updating work practices; get them involved in making industry more productive; get them involved in making the work place safer. They are the ones operating the equipment, the ones doing the work. Give them a say in how this new equipment should be installed and how it should work. If we can get this spirit of co-operation, Australian industry does have a hope of becoming efficient. I mentioned earlier that we have a great variety of unions in Australia. That is a fundamental fact of life. What are we going to do about it? In the collective agreements approach that we envisage we would embrace the concept of a chief negotiating union. We would suggest that the unions within a company should get together and form a panel to negotiate on an agreement. By that process alone we immediately would cut across demarcation disputes and the differing interests of particular unions in a particular company.

We have also looked deeply into the legality surrounding collective agreements in Australia. I hope that the Liberal Party of Australia has looked at the legalities of what it proposes. There is little doubt in our minds that under the industrial power of the Constitution we could not find a safe base to establish a law for collective agreements. We believe that in the corporations power of the Constitution there is a safe base, and any new legislation to make agreements legally binding should be based on the corporations power. We have to start from the point that any agreement between unions, employees and management is not legally binding in this country at present; it cannot be made legally binding without a new legislative framework. So such negotiated agreements at present are not worth the paper they are written on. There is a great gap in Australia's industrial law. We say there should be a legal framework that would make such agreements legally binding, which could be enforceable in our civil courts and could be encouraged in certain industries right now with the idea of at least giving us a safety net in the event that the accord breaks down for any reason, as it will, on historical evidence, sooner or later. We should have legislation that allows us to get involved in more flexible direct negotiation in the work place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This urgency debate on the need for a more flexible wage fixing policy and a more co-operative approach to work practices is basically about responsibility, rationale and reason. For too long Australia, because it has been living beyond its means, has been bolting down a path towards economic ruin. The Opposition does not have to tell Australians that; they can see it for themselves. We have an Australian dollar that is buying less and less on various world markets. We have an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent while Japan has a rate of 1.8 per cent, the United States of America 3.2 per cent and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries an average rate of 3.8 per cent. Australians can see that every month our balance of payments situation is deteriorating, that interest rates have jumped to unaffordable levels, and that, while lots of money and time is spent on Priority One campaigns and other public relations stunts, our unemployment level for youth is at an eight-month high of nearly 22 per cent-and we are told to expect a slow-down in employment growth this year. No wonder all Australians are worried.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's answer to this has been to claim the accord is leading and will lead this country out of its economic problems. We are constantly told that we have on the Government benches the best economic managers this country has seen in 50 years. Why, then, are we in such a mess? Why do we have businesses, large and small, closing every day, retrenching staff, and massive unemployment in small towns? Why do we have a rural sector that last year and this has taken to the streets to protest? Why is it, if we have the accord and the so-called best economic managers this country has known, that we are in such a mess? I get very worried about the economic abilities of this Government when I read comments such as that made recently by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), when he talked about the demonstrable success of the Government's wages policy. How can he make those claims in light of such disputes as that at Mudginberri and when almost weekly we have coal, wheat or live sheep held up at the wharves because of union demands?

Australia's wage fixing policies are simply a reflection of how far the unions are able to push their demands, and the accord has solved nothing. Charles Copeman, Chief Executive of Peko-Wallsend Ltd, said recently that Australia's wage fixing system was at the heart of Australia's malaise, and he claims that unions are not playing their part, either. He says that the worst answers he has had to the question of how to meet rising wage costs when the price of the commodity is falling has come from union bosses, who he claims say they would rather have a mine shut down than have the employer hold the line on wage demands. Look at what is happening out at Broken Hill at the moment. We read about it in the paper this morning. The company that owns the mine says that it will lose $40m this year and it is asking for new work practices to save the mine and save the jobs of some 1,500 employees. Surely there should be a more co-operative approach to the work practices adhered to by the unions to save their jobs and those of their fellow men.

Spalvins, from the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd, has called the accord `the iron hand of union power which can be exercised with virtual impunity whenever unions choose to do so'. Union power, or the irresponsible use of it, has led to situations such as that on the Port Adelaide waterfront, where the cost of cleaning four holds of a ship leaving Adelaide to load sugar in Fiji was $8,100, for 80 minutes work. The union claimed that 24 painters and dockers were needed, at a rate of $4.20 per minute per man, to do the work. The situation is apparently no better at Fremantle, where the 32 workers are paid $11 an hour when they are working, which is about half the time. The Fremantle Port Authority last year collected $324,000 from ships using the port to pay the workers for when they were not working. Divided among the 32 workers, that works out at about $10.13 an hour. So we have an absurd situation, with people being paid $11 an hour when they are working and almost as much when they are not working. Is it any wonder that our produce is too expensive for the world market?

The waterfront is by no means the only industry where absurd wage structures and demands apply. In the restaurant and tourist industries we have penalty rates which do not lead to more employment and more prosperous business. It has led to less staff providing a poorer service, and therefore harder working conditions. The same situation occurs in the rural sector in a great variety of jobs. We have long gone beyond considering the question of the ability of an industry to pay. If ever the more militant unions took that into consideration, it is very evident they no longer do so. It would seem the time is overdue for common sense to prevail in the argument about wages in this country. Two quotes are of relevance here. The first is a probably predictable response from a man who has been more on the employer than employee side of business. He says:
What we all need to realise is that increased wages can only be paid when the total size of the economic cake is increased.

Increased output and improved productivity, based on the capacity of individual business and industries to pay, are the only real bases on which wage increases can be granted without creating increased inflation and increased unemployment.
That statement is from John Leard. The second quote is as follows:
The need for change to the industrial relations norms of earlier periods has been recognised by some in important positions of influence.

That understanding has been followed by a recognition that a grab by trade unions now for a bigger slice of the economic cake could destroy opportunities for growth because this would result in self defeating inflation and lost competitiveness . . . it is accepted by realists that unless movements in labour costs are in line with economic capacity and growth in productivity the result will be to the detriment of organised labour and Australians generally . . .

Australia could still be in a favourable position if it could be a secure supplier. Unfortunately it has not been able to develop this reputation because of the operation of a conflict society. The problem for Australia is not that there is some conflict . . . it is that there is too much . . .
That statement was made by Charlie Fitzgibbon, of whom Mr Kelty said:

He's not theoretical . . . a very practical person, but he is always thinking about the future, never the past. He is truly a man of vision. He is singularly the most impressive union official I have ever dealt with.
The Confederation of Australian Industry has made the following comment:
It is a sad indictment on the position in industrial relations where the trade union movement presents the industrial tribunal with only two choices-acquiescence or economic chaos.

It has claimed that the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions use the accord as a loaded gun put straight to the head of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Confederation warns that if the 3 per cent productivity rise is paid, we will be heading clearly down a path of recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doom and gloom again. You have said the same thing many times.

—Senator McKiernan causes enough problems out in the community. He should not come in here and cause more problems. So today influential businessmen are saying that we cannot afford to keep the wages structure that we have, the largest association of businesses is saying that we cannot afford the wages structure we have, and now we have a trade union leader saying we cannot afford that wage structure. Even the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is now suggesting some flexibility in the wage structure. So when will the Government start to listen to the rest of Australia and realise what apparently almost everyone else in the community realised long ago? The present inflexible, rigidly controlled system of wage determination is inappropriate, inadequate and totally detrimental to a future healthy economy.

SPEECH.PARA: A relaxation of the wages structure would have a far-reaching benefit for a number of industries. The small business and farm sectors would then be given an opportunity to be removed from the strictures of centralised regulations and to permit enterprise-based employment contracts to emerge. This would provide greater employment opportunities for young people; it would allow small businesses and farmers to employ and train more people. Would it not be better to have young people on voluntary contracts in the work force than on the unemployed scrapheap? This would be an important step along the road to developing what is called the share economy. This is productivity-enhancing because the employee shares in the purpose of the business and hence also in its rewards.

At present there appears to be no understanding of business by the trade unions. How absurd it is to have in the metals industry, for example, an increase in the award last April of 2.6 per cent, 3.8 per cent in October, 2.3 per cent now, and a 3 per cent productivity claim. These increases naturally flow on and affect primary industry, for example, which cannot afford them at this stage. In recent months primary industry has had to suffer falling prices for its commodities as well as rising costs for machinery and hired labour, not to mention interest rates, fertiliser costs and so on. So the cost of machinery goes up, and the ability of the purchaser to pay goes down. That results in reductions in machinery sales staff, and ultimately a drop in the number of machines produced and the number of people producing them-the people Labor senators say they are protecting.

Voluntary wage agreements can work if they are allowed to. In the much-quoted Mudginberri dispute there was agreement between the employer and the employees involved to work for a price and a contract that suited them both. It was the union that objected-and why? The contract-the arrangement-was worked out to the satisfaction of both parties, neither side felt it was disadvantaged, and the arrangement was effected within an existing award. It would seem that the time is overdue in this country for common sense to prevail in the argument about wages.

Earlier today in Question Time the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) used the most insidious of all answers to the arguments against a centralised wages system. He said that if we free up the wages system, we will have a wages break-out similar to that which followed the abandonment of wage indexation in 1981. Yet quite recently the ACTU took responsibility for that particular blow to the Australian economy. Now surely when we talk about responsibility and rationale it must come not only from employers but also the trade unions and the Government, not the least of which is the Minister for Finance. Are we to be stuck forever with this appalling wages system that is killing incentive and productivity simply because if it changes the unions will run riot?

I suggest that, if those in the trade union movement wish to be treated like adults and paid like adults, perhaps they should behave like adults and not like standover men. I hope that the words of Charlie Fitzgibbon indicate the realistic approach the unions are beginning to take. They are not apart from this community. One does not have to look too far at too many industries to see the problems that are occurring. One does not have to talk to too many young people to realise that all they ask is for a chance to gain experience and to work. The system we have at the moment does not allow incentive or flexibility. Within the present system there is little responsibility and little rationale. Without them, Australia's future is not particularly promising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition put forward by the Opposition entails a curious contradiction-curious because, with this Opposition, the contradictions generally appear further down the page. However, today we have the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for a more flexible system of wage fixing and a more co-operative approach to work practices.

This is a rather naive way of wanting one's cake and eating it as well. Opposition members want a more flexible system and a more co-operative approach to work practices. Put more concisely, they are dishing up to us the following: They want lower wages and they want the workers not only to be happy about that but also to co-operate in the whole process. Opposition members want happy workers experiencing significant wage cuts. Moreover, they even seem serious about this process.

We need to look at the implications of this policy. Flexible wage systems work both ways, but that has not yet dawned on the Opposition. In some industries in which workers can create havoc if they wish, their pay rates are unlikely to go down. In fact, in some areas wage rates may even skyrocket. The reason, of course, that the workers in these areas do not take this irresponsible road is simply that the present system of wage fixation is generally perceived as just and fair. I say `just and fair' because from time to time problems do arise and bloody-mindedness has on occasion reared its ugly head on both the employer and employee side.

On one point, though, the Senate can be certain. If the present arbitrated system of wage fixation is white-anted, then a correct perception will creep into the minds of the employee organisations. The perception is that the strong will get on top, the weak will fail, and the only way forward is to take constant and immediate action. I repeat, for honourable senators opposite `constant and immediate action'. I believe that both these points need to be underlined. The action will be immediate and few other options will exist for employee organisations to protect the legitimate wage conditions that already exist. The need to do this will be constant-constant because what will happen if arbitration is white-anted in this way will be the substitution of the law of the jungle for the rule of law. Of course, the law of the jungle has one rule and one rule only-the survival of the fittest, the survival of the strongest. The industrial jungle will see the fittest and strongest survive. We are told by the Opposition that it wants flexibility-flexibility to destroy the basic strength of the arbitration system. This is supposed to lead to an environment in which peace and tranquillity will prevail. So much for centralised guarantees. What the Opposition wants is to destroy the very means by which industrial peace has been achieved.

Three years ago when this Government came to power it did so in an economic environment very different from the one we have today. Unemployment had steadily become worse during the Howard-Fraser years until in 1982 it dropped over the cliff. Little can be said about the previous Government's policies other than that they were a disaster. However, in its twilight year the failed former Government tried to destroy centralised wage fixing. The message was clear and was taken up by the trade union movement. Massive increases in wages in areas of worker strength soon followed. To quote the words of one former prominent Liberal, they followed `as sure as night follows day'. The wage rises, of course, were not for all. Workers who were in areas that could be described as not strong fell behind. The erosion of living standards that followed hit large numbers of employees. A massive rise in unemployment also followed. Negative growth was a feature of the time Mr Howard was in control of the Treasury. It was a growth rate that had a negative sign before it.

Employers naturally reacted in the only way they could. The uncertainty of this law of the jungle led them to hedge their bets, to not review plant and equipment, to reduce or not to place new orders. The results were disastrous. When the public at large had an opportunity to pass its verdict upon these supposed initiatives, it did so. In March 1983 the Howard-Fraser team were shown the door by the voters. Moreover, in December 1984 the solid progress that had been made since March 1983 saw the voters re-endorse the Hawke Labor Government for another term. The Hawke Labor Government had managed to turn the economy around. That was done by the creation of an economic world in which certainty and guarantees could be kept. The accord between all major participants in the economy in August 1983 set the pace for the dramatic turnaround. It also set the pace for wage fixation that was perceived by the vast majority of employees and employers as sound and just. The principles of this wage fixation became the foundation upon which this recovery took shape.

On 28 April 1986 the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Neil Brown, had some interesting things to say in an article in the Canberra Times entitled `Voluntary unionism-major Liberal platform'. If we want the law of the jungle instead of the rule of law, I venture to state that union membership might rise dramatically. The only way in which ordinary workers can be protected under these rules is to join a union. However, in the same article, Mr Brown was quoted as stating that the new policy `would also encourage more flexible industrial awards to abolish ``archaic'' practices'. He said that `the present industrial system was bad for business'.

On 30 April we had a different angle put to us. In an article entitled `Liberals retreat on industrial policy' which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald we were told that the Liberals had watered down the policy that proved so successful last year in South Australia and Western Australia. In that article we find out that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will still have a role. The opting out clauses will now be referred to the Commission and the Commission will ratify the various award changes.
Out of all this confusion we are presented with a couple more chestnuts. In a Press release yesterday from Mr Brown's office we find the following:
It is clear therefore that reducing union power will make reform of our wage fixing process easier to achieve.
Australia needs restraint on extremist union power which is stifling freedom and preventing Australians from having a more sensible wage fixing process.

If the hidden agenda of all this is to reduce union power, the matter ought to be thought out again. The inescapable conclusion is that the Opposition wants to create a world of industrial relations in which large unions and employer organisations slug it out. It reminds me very much of an old time quack treating a patient suffering from blood loss with leeches! The point to be made here is that arbitration has been a well established tradition in Australia. Certainly from time to time problems exist. However, on the whole, the system has shown that it is adaptable and capable of measuring all types of submissions before it and coming down with a just consensus ruling. It has been this ability to create a just consensus that has ensured the existence of this body for so long.

The average Australian worker has the view that a fair day's work should be compensated by a fair day's remuneration. By no stretch of the imagination will people in Australia accept less pay for the same work as another worker. They believe, and I agree with them, that wage justice will be eroded at peril to our economy. During 1985, the Opposition gave us a few pointers on what it was intent on doing when in government. It was going-at that stage at least-to sell back to the public what it already owned. The `privatisation policy', as it was so called, was less than successful. In South Australia and Western Australia the public rejected it. In Tasmania, the Liberal Party did not even take the policy seriously. We now have presented to us another confusing and contradictory policy. This time we are told that we need to reduce the power of the unions and, at the same time, create the circumstances in which union power is the only safeguard of workers' rights.

My view is that such a move will have devastating results for employment. The tip of such devastation was in 1982. However, a full blown attempt at such measures will have terrible employment consequences. The employment consequences do not seem to be high on the agenda of the Opposition. In an article in the Australian on 11 April 1986 entitled `Libs take their time with policy on jobs' appears an interesting statement:
Nevertheless, it remained unclear last night how the new industrial relations policy-centred primarily on the rigid wages system-could be separated from employment policy.
Mr Brown, asked how long it would be before the Opposition had an employment policy, said:
Well, the industrial relations policy will be released in the course of the next month or so. After I've rebuilt my energies from that launch, we will then put pen to paper on the employment policy.
It remains my view that this policy certainly will also be the unemployment policy, or lack of employment policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the matter of urgency which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The need in Australia for a more flexible system of wage fixing and a more co-operative approach to work practices.

It is apparent that everyone in Australia, except the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government, is prepared to acknowledge that the root cause of our problems today is a totally inflexible wages system and entrenched, unproductive work practices. In a nutshell, the problems that we have include-I name but a few-an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent, which is absolutely frightening when compared with those of our major trading partners. By way of comparison, Japan has an inflation rate of 1.8 per cent; Germany, 0.7 per cent; and the United States of America 3.2 per cent. The average for countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is artificially bolstered to 3.8 per cent because of the performance of the other Labor Government, that of New Zealand, where the rate is running at about 16 per cent.

We had an increase in wholesale prices of 6.7 per cent in the period to the end of March 1986. In West Germany the figure was minus 1.5 per cent, in Japan it was minus 7.7 per cent and in the United States of America it was minus 1.3 per cent. I have picked those countries at random; others are slightly different. But the implications of that are horrific when one thinks of the flow-on that must sooner or later occur into retail prices.

We have the highest interest rates in 50 years. They have gone completely out of kilter with those of every other equivalent country in the world. As at the end of March the interest rate in Australia was around 19 per cent. In the United States of America it was 9 per cent; in Japan, 4.5 per cent; and in Germany, 7 per cent. We have a dollar which has collapsed on the market, which fact should be redressing our balance of payments situation. But that is not happening. I will come to that later.

We have a balance of payments deficit which for the first nine months of this fiscal year is running at $1.2 billion a month. It is already standing at $10.4 billion, which is more than for the whole of 1984-85. That is the official target for the whole of this year but we still have three months to go. We have an overseas debt of about $80 billion with overseas interest payments alone of the order of $7 billion. The debt when the Hawke Government came into power was $34 billion.

We have an unacceptably high rate of unemployment, particularly among young people. I suspect or hope that there are a few people in government who know that the real concern of the majority of Australians is the refusal of this Government, because it is paralysed under the control of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to recognise the inflexibility that exists within our wage structure. The pity of it all is that many of the practices which the Government and the ACTU will not recognise already occur in the work place. The fear of the ACTU and, of course, the Government-it is very hard to tell the difference; one is elected and one unelected but the unelected one controls the Government-is that the policies that already exist to some extent in the work place will carry on into other places. This, if allowed to continue, is a recipe for disaster.

What we are proposing is not an attack on unions. They provide a very useful function in society, provided that they stick to that function. In recent years, however, not all but some have come to expect that they are not required to act within the law as is every other citizen within our society. Over a period of years they have taken the view that overmanning and punitive wage related conditions will preserve employment. The effect has been the opposite. By their actions they have reduced our competitiveness in both export and import replacement goods and services and have reduced employment. They have done a disservice to their members. People have been pushed into higher tax brackets and their purchasing power has been diminished.

Let us look at some of the work practices that exist today in our great industries. The rural industry has been covered satisfactorily by Senator Brownhill so I will not go over that. Next is the mining industry. I was intrigued that Senator Cook was brought in to defend the Government on the flexibility or otherwise of its wages system. Senator Cook should not have been allowed into the chamber to talk on this issue. Prior to his entry into this place, Senator Cook was Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Western Australia. In that period he presided over, and presumably inspired, the worst industrial dislocations in the Pilbara. He was one of the architects of the perception by overseas people that Australia was an unreliable supplier which resulted in major buyers of Australian ore turning to Brazilian iron ore.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—Order!
—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. That was terrible language from people on the other side.
—You are not demanding that it be withdrawn, I understand.
—Yes, I would like him to withdraw it.
—Senator Cook, I ask you to withdraw the interjection.
—In deference to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I withdraw.

—Senator Cook is well aware of the damage done to the mining industry in the days when he was the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Western Australia. It is in the main a capital intensive industry competing with other countries. Yet what do we have in many areas of the mining industry?
—Do you know what its record is now?

—Senator Cook is no longer Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council so that may explain the reduction in industrial disputation. In much of the mining industry we have compulsory Christmas shutdowns so that all the capital equipment in this capital intensive industry lies idle. Certainly, no productive work is done in the coal mining industry in Queensland at weekends. It is a hangup from How Green Was My Valley, from the old Welsh days. There is an inability of management to talk with its employees. Within the open cut coal mining industry this is forbidden by the union leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to shipping. Australia is an island continent with a history of trade going back before Federation. We should have a merchant navy equal to virtually any in the world. Why is that not the case? It is because we are not competitive on international shipping markets. Why are we not competitive on international shipping markets? I will give a few reasons. We have wage rates and conditions in excess of those of other competitive countries and in excess of the International Transport Workers Federation regulations. We have work practices under which the men work for six months and then have six months off. They refuse to carry out repairs at sea. The unreliability of dry-dock repairs and maintenance makes the cost totally prohibitive. A shipowner cannot be sure he will get his ship back if he lets it go into dry dock. We have crewing rates double those of our major trading partners such as Japan and Korea.

Let me talk about tourism. Any attempt to have flexible working hours without penalty rates is totally resisted by the troglodytes in the trade union movement. On Sundays or public holidays penalty rates make it almost impossible to get a meal in a tourist area unless the establishment is run by a family. Of course, this means that employment which could be available is not available, particularly to young people.

Let me refer to manufacturing industry. Archaic adherence to comparative wage justice has wrecked our manufacturing industry. Achievements attained by people such as Senator Cook in the Pilbara in the capital intensive mining industry have flowed on to labour intensive manufacturing industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie too.

—Of course it has; Senator Cook knows that as well as I do. I have seen it happen in my own background. People have come along and said: `Don't worry. You are up here and get special consideration. It will not flow on'. The next thing that happens is that the tradesmen's group says that it will pass it on to everyone else. People then start to wonder why industry moves off-shore or shuts down and the equivalent goods are imported from South East Asia. It is often claimed that real unit labour costs have fallen as a result of the inflexible prices and incomes accord. Senator Walsh argues that.
—It's true.
—Senator Cook said before that the idea of the accord was in fact to maintain real wages, so I suggest that he and Senator Walsh ought to get together and get their story right.
—Maybe you ought to understand the accord, so you would understand what you are talking about.

—I can understand the accord, but I cannot understand the two points of view. If it were the case that real unit labour costs had fallen, the so-called J curve would be working and higher cost imports would be replaced by lower cost local manufacturing. Let me give an example which is indicative of many others in Australia today, one to which I referred the other day-the history of an on-line toaster designed in Australia by Sunbeam Corporation Ltd and launched on the Australian market earlier this year. Because of the international scope of its operations, Sunbeam was able to make accurate comparisons of costs in several possible sources of manufacture. The first comparison, made in January 1985 before the devaluation of the dollar, revealed that unit manufacturing costs for the toaster would have been $12.58 in the United States of America, $11.47 in New Zealand, $9.33 in Hong Kong, and $18.08 in Australia; almost double the Hong Kong price.
—Are you going to tell us the source of this allegation?

—Yes, I will. It happens to be the Sunbeam Corporation. Since the dramatic dip in our dollar the comparative manufacturing costs in Australia have improved a lot-Senator Cook will be pleased to hear that-but in the case of the toaster we are still not competitive. The latest costs are Australia, $18.08-unchanged; New Zealand, $15.42; the United States, $14.56; and Hong Kong, $10.80. Despite the devaluation benefits, Sunbeam elected to manufacture the new toaster in Hong Kong. The breakdown really spells out the disadvantages of manufacturing in Australia. It is in wage costs that Australia really slips.
—Would you like to see us with the same wages as Hong Kong workers get?
—No. A comparison of hourly wage rates for process workers puts Australia, at $7.40 an hour, at the top of the table, followed by the United States at $6.60 and New Zealand at $5.31.
—This is a capital intensive area you are talking about.

—It is a new toaster, which is capital and labour intensive, as Senator Cook knows. I am comparing this with the United States and New Zealand. It is pointed out also that only Australians have the privilege of a 38-hour week. Australia has the highest number of non-working days, at 52, compared with New Zealand with 30. This Government really has no choice. It must face up to the facts and recognise that we have a totally rigid wages system which is dragging down our country. Employers and their employees must be able to determine work practices which will be to the advantage of the employees, the industry and Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very interesting matter of urgency. Indeed, when the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, opened the debate on this we thought: `Here is a change in attitude, a change in approach which will move across the chamber and everybody will, as it were, join in almost a lovefest'. I remember Senator Cook listening with a great deal of interest when Senator Chaney was speaking and no doubt thinking: `At long last the new has arrived, there is a change in attitude'. Senator Chaney spoke about the need for co-operation, the need for us all to get together and work well together. Then we heard from two of the most powerful debaters on the other side, Senator Brownhill and Senator Parer, who came to this House about 15 months ago and have established themselves as great speakers. They were brought in by the Opposition to make what can only be called a most vicious and far-ranging attack on the trade union movement and on one of the great representatives of the trade union movement, Senator Cook, who has served that institution wonderfully in the past.
—A hero of the working class.

—A hero of the working class. How much credence can we give an urgency motion which was begun by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney-a man of considerable skill-who invited us all to get around and be co-operative and give an example to the rest of Australia, but, having said that, immediately lapsed into the old ways? Senator Siddons, who made his usual sensible contribution to this debate, felt a little embarrassed about the fact that he was following on from that opening, where all was going to be love and light, but then a most vicious attack was made on one part of the economy-that is, the workers. Let us be clear what is being said here. The Opposition has asked that people take a cut in living standards and that, insofar as the unions attempt to prevent that happening, the unions must be cut down. That is really what this debate is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be clear that no suggestion has been made by the Opposition speakers to approach the unions on this matter to see what they have to say about it. The whole tenor of the debate is that this union sector must be disciplined, punished and put into strait-jackets. How are we going to get all this love and light, all this co-operation that was called for, if one of the major elements of any scheme of reconciliation, namely, the union movement, is to be denigrated, abused and brought into disrepute? Clearly this urgency motion has to be looked at very carefully and perhaps looked at with some suspicion. The Opposition says: `There is a need for a more flexible system of wage fixing and a more co-operative approach to work practices'. How can we get a more co-operative approach to work practices if each time we abuse the workers in the work place and their unions? What sort of co-operation will we get if we take that approach? On the other hand, if we try some understanding-which is what has been happening through the prices and incomes accord-if we try to talk across the economic scene, not only to employees but also to employers, as this Government has done, we will get somewhere.

The urgency motion today indicates exactly what will happen if the Opposition returns to government. As has been indicated in the debate, it would talk to management and employers and direct them to discipline the unions and the workers and put them, as it were, into strait-jackets. The Opposition has said: `No, we will not do that, we will have a flexible wage system'. What does that mean? That means that people in powerful positions-people who own and manage the factories-can dictate to the people who want to be employed by them exactly how much they will get-away from the help they might get from unions.

The example put forward has been that of Mudginberri. When talking of Mudginberri no one on the other side has quoted what Mr Justice Neaves had to say on 14 August 1985 when talking about the Mudginberri situation. He said:
. . . it is unrealistic, in considering the scope and object of the provisions here in question-
he was talking about the law in regard to that situation-
to confine one's attention to the circumstances relevant to the particular establishment and treat as extraneous and irrelevant wider considerations concerning the industry generally.

Why has the Opposition come in here and tried to use that particular example as an example which applies right across the board, when we have people such as Mr Justice Neaves in the Federal Court of Australia last year-one might think that he is a man who stands well and truly above party politics-who says: `You cannot look at Mudginberri as an example of what can be done around the country, nor can you take Mudginberri as the end of the argument. What you have to do is to look at an industry generally'. Are not people who work in an industry entitled to have their conditions looked at? Not only is the economic welfare of that industry important but also the social conditions of the people who work in that industry are important.

Today, during the debate, there has been absolutely no indication from the Opposition that it is in any way sensitive to the social problems people face in the work place. The Opposition is happy as long as the cost to industry is reduced by reducing wages. Reducing them to what? Perhaps to nothing? It has been suggested that they be reduced to the Hong Kong levels, to levels well below what workers in Australia have fought for for years and obtained. The Opposition would throw all those things out the window simply to relieve the cost on industry, without any consideration being given to the social suffering that might occur as a result of that. Is it not better-and this is a question which has not been answered-to go along with what is happening with the accord, under which consideration is given not only to the economic impact in the work place but also to the social impact that these sorts of things have on those working in industry? What will we get if all these things are abandoned? What will we get if employers are free to tell employees what they can earn? Will we do any better than we are doing at the moment? The answer to that is clearly no.

Let us look at the evidence of how things are going. It is claimed that small business has been disadvantaged by the wage structures. I quote what the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said about a survey conducted by the Australian Statistician:

The latest survey was carried out for the December quarter and it shows a growth in the employment of wage and salary earners for the year to December 1985 of 4.8 per cent . . . The private sector accounted for 86 per cent of the growth, it having had a growth in the employment of wage and salary earners in 1985 of 6 per cent, which was a tremendously high rate of growth.

Not only was there strong growth in the private sector as a whole but also there was very strong growth among small business. One can get from the Statistician some unpublished data to complement what is in the published data. Taking the smallest of the three categories of private sector firms, which is firms with less than 20 employees, if one looks at the rate of growth of employment in that sector one finds that in the year to November 1985, the latest figures available, there was a growth in employment of 5.8 per cent, compared with growth for the private sector as a whole of 5.8 per cent. That is obviously a very high rate of growth for that small business sector. If one goes back two years, to November 1984, one finds growth for this small business sector over the period of 9.6 per cent, slightly higher than the whole private sector rate of 9.5 per cent.

What that indicates, amongst a lot of other indications, is that business, including small business, has worked and has progressed well under the accord. Employment has risen, wages have been maintained at an at least reasonable level and things are going along well, not only economically but socially. Yet now we have a motion which indicates that the Opposition's approach would be to change all that. It wants to throw out the accord and go to what it calls a more flexible system of wage fixing. Remember this: There is plenty of flexibility in the wage structure already, as Senator Cook has so eloquently testified. But no, the Opposition wants to go further. What will it mean to go further and have a flexible wage system? It will mean simply that it will be in the hands of employers to pay what they will to those who are weakest in the work force, whereas those who are strongest in the work force will get more. That will result in class distinction amongst wage earners, with those who have strength, whether through their technological abilities or otherwise, getting disproportionately more. Remember, under a flexible wage system it is possible not only for people to get less but also for people to get more. We will have those with industrial strength getting more and those with little industrial strength getting less and getting poorer.

Clearly it is not only wages that should count in a policy of co-operation. The Opposition's proposal ignores that. It fails to envisage how things would work in practice. We must remember that, in a policy of co-operation with workers, technological change is an industrial matter everybody should consider. Bringing in new machines and new techniques will cause redundancy problems. These are the sorts of things that should be looked at, in addition to wages. The matter of wages should not be taken in isolation, as it has been in this debate. We should also consider dividends, profits and what have you. Let me make it quite clear, people are more than entitled to dividends and profits, but just as that is so, so are people entitled to a decent standard of living.

Why has this debate, initiated by the Opposition, been put on a basis which in no way gives any consideration to the social and cultural needs of ordinary, every day workers, which most people out in the community are? What protection has been suggested today for those sorts of people? What effect will the reduction in wages hoped for by the Opposition-indeed, it is its policy to reduce wages so that there is less cost to industry-have on the person who already is on a low wage? Why is no consideration given in these sorts of debates to those sorts of questions? We have to remember the disastrous situation we had in the old days before the Australian Labor Party came to power. For example, we had 17 per cent growth in the average weekly wage in March 1982-much more than pertains under this Government. We remember the bitter-that is the only way it can be described-industrial disputation that took place in those years. We remember the thousands of people sacked in Wollongong. We remember all those things and contrast them to the way we are now heading.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The paper before the Senate is the fifth annual report of the Central Land Council. I have remained keenly interested in the progress and development of the three land councils in the Northern Territory since their inception. The Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council were established to present the views of the Aboriginal people on their land rights to the Aboriginal Land Rights Commissioner, Justice Woodward, in his inquiry into the land rights issue in the early to mid-1970s. The land councils were maintained under the Aboriginal land rights legislation which was introduced following that inquiry. Their main statutory functions include assistance with preparation and presentation of land claims, management of Aboriginal land, negotiation of agreements on land use proposals, sacred site protection, supervision of land trusts and royalty management.

It is a very apt time to be discussing the annual report of the CLC as Aboriginal land councils have been in the news in a big way quite recently. Press reports last month indicated that the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) planned to get rid of the land councils because they had become too cumbersome and unmanageable. Those reports were strongly denied by the Minister. However, I would not be surprised if there is not some element of truth to those reports. It is well recognised in the Northern Territory that the land councils have developed into very strong centralised organisations which are becoming less and less responsive to the needs of the people they purport to represent. The leaders of the councils seem to be more preoccupied with empire building than with ensuring that funds are well spent on Aboriginal people at grass roots level.

I make it quite clear that I do not make these comments to knock the concept of representative Aboriginal organisations. I am 100 per cent in favour of Aboriginal people having a forum in which to express their opinions and a means of conveying those opinions to the Government and other sectors of the community. My concern is that the land councils are no longer generally representative of Aboriginal people. They are run by a small clique who have minimal contact in some cases with the old men of the tribes-those who traditionally advised and led their people. These bureaux of land councils, I say, are not now representative. This development has led to some Aboriginal people wishing to form splinter land councils to protect what they perceive as their own interests which are being neglected by the land councils.

Land councils have become far too bureaucratic. They are top-heavy with administrators, consultants, advisers and an assortment of others who receive significant proportions of the funds for Aboriginal people to the detriment of the community Aboriginals who are in need of assistance. The situation of land councils in the Territory has really become a situation of the tail wagging the dog. This cannot have escaped the notice of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and however much he may deny it now, I would not be surprised, as I say, if there is not an element of truth to the claims that the land councils are to be dismantled, with presumably and hopefully some more representative organisations set up in their place.

One of the problems in providing services and resources to Aboriginal people seems to be that there is a duplication of delivery facilities and, hence, wastage of funds. During recent Estimates Committee hearings it was revealed that there are some 1,000 organisations dealing with Aboriginal services and there is no real attempt to ensure that duplication and wastage does not occur as a result of this. The whole matter of funding, delivery and representation needs to be reviewed and some less wasteful and more beneficial scheme must be devised. The money should not be spent on administrative costs for 1,000 organisations. It should get into the communities where it can provide housing, health care, education and essential services. This does not happen now.

One final matter of great concern to the land councils and to which this report refers is the excision of land from pastoral leases for the purpose of providing living areas. Procedural guidelines were set up in the Territory for the excision of living areas and they allow for secure tenure of land for Aboriginal people residing or who have resided in the recent past on pastoral properties. The scheme was only set up in April 1985 and figures are now available to show to what extent the scheme has been used until 31 January 1986. At the end of that period there were 91 still at the expression of interest stage, 58 had got as far as negotiations, 17 had failed to reach agreement, 11 had reached agreement in principle and 30 had signed a formal agreement. The idea behind the procedure was to avoid the necessity for special legislation, expensive tribunals and the like. It was intended that with some good will on both sides-Aboriginal and pastoralist-agreement could be reached by negotiations. The figures which I have just quoted show that substantial progress has been achieved as a result of the contribution and co-operation of many people, not least the pastoralists and the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association. This gives added impetus to call for the amendment of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. We have yet to see the Federal Government's legislation although I understand there are suggestions that it will be introduced into the Parliament shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly to the fifth annual report-1984-85-of the Central Land Council. To those people who are interested in the current situation with regard to land rights in Australia, I recommend that they read this report. It is a report put together by the Aboriginal people themselves. They run that Council and they run the organisation in a very efficient and effective manner. The Council engages in various activities, particularly with regard to education, the administration of the parts of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act which are under its control, the research it provides for the land claims and mining and cultural protection, on which it gives advice, and the legal division which assists Aboriginal people and various groups with regard to land claims. All of these activities are carried out in an exemplary manner.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia we find too often a willingness to criticise Aboriginal people and Aboriginal-run organisations. I suggest that those people in Australia who feel that that is the normal course of events should look at the Central Land Council, which is a body which controls quite significant funds and which has very important matters under its control, and see the very effective and efficient way in which those functions are carried out. I think it does credit to the Central Land Council. Its report is a report that would be accepted as being a very good report by almost any government organisation. This is not a government organisation; this is one of the few almost, as it were, independent organisations which presents a report to this Parliament. I found the report fascinating and interesting reading and I hope that more people in Australia will read this type of good news instead of the type of bad news which is so constantly put around about Aboriginal people and their organisations.
