SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the opportunity to say a few words on the annual report for 1984-85 of the Human Rights Commission. I note with some interest and concern that it is reported on page 79 of the report that the budget for the Commission in 1984-85 was more than double that of the actual allocation in 1983-84, and that of that more than doubling increase, the administrative expenses increased almost threefold from $1.12m in 1983-84 to $2.99m in 1984-85. One of the reasons given in the report for the increase of this magnitude is the first full year's operation of the Commission's education program in the schools, `Teaching for Human Rights'.

The Senate will recall that this was an educative program that attracted a lot of attention here and in the wider community some time ago. Over the last two or three months it has also been considered in the debates we have had on the Australian Bill of Rights proposals and one wonders how justified, when one looks at this teaching program, many of the other expenditure increases of the Commission are. Time has prevented me looking at that, but I just repeat for the benefit of the Senate one of the criticisms that was echoed very strongly in this place about some of the teaching for human rights material which has been distributed to schools-155 schools throughout Australia, I remind the Senate-and of the fact that teachers receive a payment of $500 or $1,000, depending on whether it was a one-year or two-year project, to promote this material in the schools. There is a very questionable content in that documentation, including a very anti-Western society or anti-capitalist bias in those writings. I will just repeat the most well-recorded text from the booklet `Teaching for Human Rights':

The construction of a capitalist world economy, predicated upon dishonesty and greed, has slaughtered uncounted millions the world over through the exploitation and the mis-development of global resources. The United States and the other erstwhile `free market' democracies have much to answer for in this regard.

That was not atypical of the type of material and the flavour of the material in much of that `Teaching for Human Rights' documentation which has gone out from the Human Rights Commission to the schools. I understand that the publication is under review with a view to taking out some passages like that. Nevertheless, that will not affect the whole flavour of the documentation. It is one of the reasons why many members of the community have expressed very grave concern, as I am sure would all honourable senators on both sides, about the nature of the Human Rights Commission and the role that it will play if and when the Government's Bill of Rights legislation comes into being, because the Human Rights Commission will be given a greatly expanded role under that legislation. It will have powers that very few, if any, bureaucratic arms of government have ever had. I repeat the concerns that I have expressed on this Bill on more than one occasion. The Human Rights Commission will be pivotal to where we go in the area of human rights. For that reason, the Human Rights Commission annual report 1984-85 bears very serious consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in speaking, albeit briefly, to the Human Rights Commission annual report 1984-85. To recognise publicly that not all the good things that happen in our society have been undertaken by the Hawke Labor Government I remind honourable senators that the Commission was set up by the previous Government under the leadership of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. The functions of the Commission are many and varied. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: 9 (1) The functions of the Commission are-

(a) to examine enactments, and (when requested to do so by the Minister) proposed enactments, for the purpose of ascertaining whether the enactments or proposed enactments are, or would be, inconsistent with or contrary to any human rights, and to report to the Minister the results of any such examination.

Annexed to the Human Rights Commission Act which set up the Commission in 1981 are the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights proclaims the right of all people to privacy, marriage and family, use by minorities of their own language, culture and religion, participation in public affairs, freedom of expression, movement, association and assembly, and a number of other matters. I mention these things only because in the concluding chapter of the report the Commission refers, in what I believe to be a tongue in cheek comment, to the fact that it has been in receipt of a degree of criticism to such a point that in some cases the suggestion has been made that the Commission be abolished. Many of the criticisms of the Human Rights Commission have been associated with the proposed Australian Bill of Rights which is before this chamber. Another criticism that has been levelled at the Commission is that it is a star chamber. Webster's Dictionary defines it as:
A court existing in England from the 15th century until 1641 that exercised wide civil and criminal jurisdiction under rules of procedure well suited to the purposes of absolutist sovereigns.

Speaking with an Irish accent, I can say that the history of my people would verify that. In no way could we claim that the Australian Human Rights Commission in any shape or form could be deemed to be a star chamber. Another criticism levelled at the Commission is based on cost. Its budget for 1985-86 is $4.76m. This is only one per cent of the projected expenditure on law, order and public safety of $454m. Thus, it is only 0.007 per cent of the total Budget outlay of the Commonwealth for 1985-86. It is worthy of note that during July 1984 to June 1985, the period which the report covers, seven major reports were produced by the Commission. Its eighth report dealt with deportation, the ninth with the Queensland Community Services (Aborigines) Act, the tenth with the Human rights of Australian-born children, the eleventh with human rights and the terminally ill, the twelfth with the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act, the thirteenth with human rights and the Migration Act and the fourteenth with Queensland electricity supply and related industrial legislation. Of seven major reports by the Commission in the year July 1984 to June 1985, three dealt with legislation within Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Human Rights Commission allows a number of matters to be raised which in part relate to the Bill of Rights and associated legislation before the Senate. However, I direct my remarks to a couple of matters which are specifically raised in this annual report. Perhaps the annual report ought to be seen as indicating that in some respects the Human Rights Commission reports could be a two-edged sword. A number of reports were made to the Government during the year on the rights of Australian-born children of people who had overstayed their permission to reside in Australia. These matters having been drawn to the attention of the Human Rights Commission, it made public its belief that the civil rights of those children were being infringed when parents were properly deported. The matter having been drawn to the Government's attention, the Government decided that it was best to legislate to take away the rights of the children in total so that that situation could never occur again. It is unfortunate that in this case a matter has been drawn to the Government's attention involving abuses of human rights of particular categories of persons, namely certain children born in Australia, and those rights are now to be wiped out permanently.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point arising from the report is the distressing news in one of the very famous cases with which the Commission dealt, that of Mr Metwally, who had an action against the University of Wollongong. Mr Metwally was a victim of the legal system. It was found that his case could not be acted upon because there was a jurisdictional problem in that the legislation in New South Wales was in conflict with the Federal legislation and, therefore, the Federal legislation prevailed. Mr Justice Deane of the High Court of Australia is quoted on page 22 of the report as drawing attention to this matter:

The outcome of this case will inevitably appear to Mr Metwally to involve an unjust denial of his reasonable expectation that, as a visitor to this country, he might resort to, and rely upon, what Governments and Parliaments have asserted to be the law.

Mr Justice Deane went on to say that unfortunately Mr Metwally cannot do so. Although compensation was recommended by the Bench of the High Court of Australia, he has to date received no compensation.

I make two final points. I believe that a number of tribunals of this sort are bringing on themselves some ill-informed criticism from the community. In a decision made in New South Wales quite recently, on 24 April, in the case of Shane Edmund Burke v. Peter Tralaggan and John Spence Real Estate Pty Ltd in which a person acted on his conscientious religious belief about the sort of people to whom he should lease his property, the Equal Opportunity Tribunal ruled that the landlord did not have that right and he was not to be allowed to practise his religious freedom in a way that was in conflict, so it appeared, with a law in New South Wales. Nevertheless, the Human Rights Commission report provides us with some very valuable information not least of value being a statement at the end of the report by a Minister who is reported to have said:

I believe, and the Government believes, that in an era of social change in which governments exercise wide powers and corporations and large institutions greatly influence the lives of individuals, it is important to have an agency that is active in the protection and promotion of the rights of individuals.

Those words were spoken by Senator Durack, my Party's Deputy Leader, in 1981 when introducing the legislation to establish the Human Rights Commission. I believe that Senator Durack would not want to resile in any way from the words he spoke on that occasion. I believe they are an accurate reflection of what is required in the years to come.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vigor) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the sale of, and dealings with, hazardous goods, and for purposes connected therewith.
Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is part of a concerted package of legislation to solve some of the problems facing Australian consumers.
This particular Bill deals with consumer safety.
Australians are dying,
Australians are being hurt,
Fellow Australians are suffering,
Australians are paying for corporate greed.
Anyone of us could be the next victim. Our fragmented approach to identifying and dealing with hazardous products has caused and is right now causing needless harm to innocent Australians.

I propose a co-operative solution where the Commonwealth complements and enhances the work of State authorities by ensuring, as far as is possible under our Constitution, that hazardous products cannot continue to be offered for sale to Australians or to anyone. I hope that the States will reciprocate the trust that we have placed in their expert officers by accepting the results of work carried out elsewhere in Australia. In this way we can stamp out most of the current dealing in goods not fit to be offered for sale.

It is a tragic twist of history that governments and legislatures have generally failed to deal with the menace posed by dangerous goods until after a major disaster has occurred. I ask the government to act now and support this Bill. We must not wait for either a trickle of deaths and injuries, or for a major catastrophe before taking action. In the United States, where the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency monitor standards that are among the most safety-conscious in the world, improvements in the legislation have quickly followed tragedies. Our record in Australia is much worse.

In 1937, a chemist at the S. E. Massengill Company found that a formerly insoluble `sulpha' drug would dissolve in a chemical relative of radiator antifreeze. The product was eagerly marketed as `Elixir of Sulfanilamide' without any safety testing. Within weeks, reports of deaths of those who had consumed the Elixir started reaching the Food and Drug Administration. In all, 107 people died as a result of taking the product and the chemist committed suicide. The following year, Congress passed the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act which required a new drug to be tested for safety by the manufacturer and their results to be reported to the Food and Drug Administration. It also abolished the requirement that only false and fraudulent labelling of drugs be punishable. Nevertheless, there was no requirement that manufacturers sustain with scientific evidence claims which they made for their products.
In 1962, President Kennedy pointed out that one in five of the new drugs that had been introduced in the last six years failed to live up to one or more of their manufacturers' claims.

Congress enacted in that year the Kefauver-Harris amendments which required drug manufacturers to provide evidence from well-controlled expertly-conducted clinical tests to back up all claims made concerning the effectiveness or safety of their products.

This legislation followed quickly after the world-wide thalidomide scandal. Thalidomide had been introduced as a tranquiliser by Chemie Grunenthal of West Germany in 1957. The drug was advertised as being completely safe, and by 1961 thalidomide was providing half the company's sales revenue. Although no tests had been done on the effects of the drug on foetuses, advertising literature claimed that thalidomide could
`Be given with complete safety to pregnant women'.

Doctors who reported problems with the nervous system in some patients who had taken the drug, and others who raised possible connections with phocomelia, were ignored and publicly blackguarded if they persisted in their opposition to the drug. Great pressure was placed on medical authorities to allow thalidomide to be sold over-the-counter and without prescription. This pressure succeeded in several countries but not in the United States, largely because the responsible officers in the Food and Drug Administration, Dr Lelsey in particular, withstood all blandishments and threats. At this stage, the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act still applied only to pharmaceuticals.

Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon sent eight consecutive annual messages to Congress, urging them to legislate to require pre-marketing clearance of medical devices for safety, efficacy and reliability. None of these entreaties resulted in any legislative action being taken.

When in 1971 G. D. Searle and Company was seeking to market the Copper-Seven (Cu-7) intra-uterine device and to contend that its copper content increased its contraceptive efficiency, the Food and Drug Administration ruled that because the device contained a non-inert substance, it was a new drug and consequently has to face the pre-market testing and other safety and effectiveness requirements.

The A. H. Robins Company sought to avoid these strictures by claiming that the copper and copper sulphate in the Dalkon shield served only to improve physical or mechanical characteristics of the device, and had no active function in its contraceptive effectiveness. This was despite the warning by A. H. Robins' Director of Product Planning that the addition of copper and copper sulphate to the plastic from which the Dalkon shield was moulded
`May have a deleterious effect on account of the irritant and astringent nature of copper salts.'

He was also worried that not disclosing the presence of copper and copper sulphate to doctors amounted to an implied warranty that the device alone was producing the contraceptive effect. Yet because copper had appeared to improve effectiveness, the soluble copper sulphate has been added to further enhance it.

Even though A. H. Robins withheld their evidence that the Dalkon shield's multifilament string could act as a conduit for bacteria into the womb, the Food and Drug Administration in October of 1974 stated that the Shield's safety remained in question and that
`The moratorium on commercial distribution . . . [would] remain in effect pending accumulation of definitive data.'
The shield was never again sold in the United States, but vast quantities were promptly exported to many countries around the world, including Australia.

As more and more women suffered severely from the use of the Dalkon shield, and more and more evidence emerged about the misleading advertising and corporate corruption, U.S. Congress adopted the Medical Device Amendments of 1976.

Australian women, however, continued to be fitted with Dalkon shields well into the nineteen seventies even though A. H. Robbins Company ``ceased'' distribution of the devices in Australia in 1975. They had dumped so many of the devices already in Australia, and these continued to be fitted by the Family Planning Association for instance. As only patchy records of implantations were kept, we cannot even now be certain that all have been removed. Yet the last day for claims and damages caused by this product worldwide was last Thursday, 30 April 1986. I sincerely hope the Government will be approaching the United States Government to extend this deadline for Australian women.

The present Government has improved the Australian situation relating to safety of drugs, chemical agents and therapeutic goods over the past two years. In the Budget for 1984-85, $1.3 million was set aside to establish a register of medical devices sold in Australia. The National Therapeutic Goods Committee proposed this in 1970, but it was unfortunately set aside. The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare took it up again in 1981 and eventually the Government took action. The Government has also made a commitment to introduce a Chemicals Notification and Assessment Scheme. This follows a proposed budget initiative on which work is already proceeding which will provide a computerised databank register of medical devices and any problems experienced with them. We will also, I hope, have an excellent record of pharmaceuticals and a complete summary of reports of suspected adverse reactions.
In December 1985, the Acting Minister for Health wrote to me that

``The question of adapting the National Register of Therapeutic Goods to provide a reporting system for defects in, or injuries due to medical devices and to provide a hazard alert for devices is under consideration.''
I sincerely hope that the resources will be found to implement this important undertaking. I also commend the recently-passed product recall legislation.

The Social Development Committee of the Victorian Parliament made the following recommendations in its excellent report of November 1985 titled ``Inquiry into Therapeutic Goods and Cosmetics Bill 1984''.
``(54) That the Commonwealth Government maintains its evaluation processes for imported therapeutic products.
``(55) That the issue of a National Registration Scheme, its resources, staffing and operation be referred to the next Health Ministers' Conference.''
The Committee made these remarks in its report:
``The Commonwealth exercises its powers through an adequate evaluation of the importation of new therapeutic products and drugs into Australia.

``However, the registration of Australian-produced products is vital and is not currently adequately controlled by the Commonwealth. For this reason, the Committee concludes that the present Australian system is unsatisfactory.''
The Social Development Committee devoted two chapters of its Report to the interlocking Federal and State powers, and the consequent legislation relating to:
The registration of products,
The licensing of manufacturers and wholesalers,
The control of advertising,
The setting of standards, and
Various import controls.

There are no uniform definitions of therapeutic goods and cosmetics, nor an inkling of a uniform approach to legislation. For instance, in regard to controls placed on therapeutic goods and their distribution and promotion, the Committee concluded that
``. . . problems include a lack of uniformity, a lack of resources to implement controls, and a lack of clarity and incomplete coverage of regulations''.
It also said that

``. . . apart from New South Wales, all other States and Territories have rather broad sweeping provisions in their legislation which are non-specific and in all cases appear deficient in resources and staffing''.
I believe that this situation applies generally to consumer safety matters, not just to therapeutic goods and cosmetics dealt with so thoroughly by the Social Development Committee.

Under the Trade Practices Act, a Commonwealth Minister may proclaim product safety and product information standards, and can declare goods to be unsafe where it appears that injury may be caused to either persons using the goods or to any other persons.

The Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations also include extensive lists of goods which are unsafe or dangerous and consequently are not allowed into Australia. Some of the items are fairly general, and a customs officer may not be able to detect a problem without recourse to facilities for analysing the ingredients or composition of a product. Some items will always slip through no matter how carefully enquiries are conducted.

State governments have powers to deal with hazardous products under a variety of legislation, including Health Acts, Consumer Protection Acts and Environmental Protection Acts. Ministers for Consumer Affairs quite regularly gazette notices banning the supply of particular goods or varieties of goods in their States. Similar orders are made in the Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory.

While the staff dealing with such matters are generally most enthusiastic and dedicated, the overall resources are quite limited and staff can rarely initiate action as a result of their personal inspections and testing of products. Basically, the Departments or Offices of Consumer Affairs have to wait for complaints from the public or notifications of danger after the event, before they spring into action. Only as long as there is generally an atmosphere of willing and cordial exchange of information between jurisdictions, is there a mechanism for co-ordinating prohibition action. Without an effective mechanism for information exchange, unscrupulous operators can move their wares interstate and open up trade, perhaps after waiting for the fuss in the State where the prohibition is in force to die down. My approach in this Bill is to complement the independent activities of the Offices and Departments with a central registry or clearing house for such notification to ensure that no such dangerous products can go unnoticed.

Where State Departments or Offices have determined that goods are hazardous, I believe that their judgment can be trusted, and that all Australians should, if possible, be able to benefit from that work. Accordingly, I have drawn on the corporations, trade and commerce, territories, broadcasting and postal powers of the Commonwealth to restrict, as much as can be done within the Australian Constitution, the scope for moving hazardous goods away from any place where their sale is prohibited. Naturally, I have left open the possibility that the goods may be dealt with inside Australia as scrap, or be returned to the manufacturer for repair or reprocessing. However, in the light of previous experience, which I shall come to directly, and of the need for the most exacting ethical standards in foreign trade which is needed if we are to establish a reputation for trading integrity for Australia, I believe that once goods have been declared hazardous, they should not leave this country for any purpose whatsoever.

This is quite compatible with the Government's approach in amending the Trade Practices Act: it would just place goods declared to be unsafe in a category much more strictly monitored than goods not meeting published Australian standards which are able to be sent overseas under certain very stringent notification conditions.
The need for some tough and uncompromising co-ordinating action is absolutely clear from past examples.

In my maiden speech, I referred to the need for an adequate child accident surveillance and reporting system. I mentioned the deaths and hideous injuries caused by a `potty' shaped skimmer box used extensively in fibreglass swimming pools around Australia. Children who mistakenly sat on the box were maimed or disembowelled through the heavy suction. Three died and seven were severely injured.

It took some nine months to co-ordinate a nationwide ban on this hazardous product in 1983. If a reader had not sent a clipping from a Northern Territory newspaper to Choice magazine, the process may well have been drawn out for months longer, and more children might have been killed, injured or needlessly put at risk.

The problem of banned products reappearing on the market under a new name is illustrated by the case of a compound used for blowing balloons. The product went under a variety of names, including ``Super Elastic Bubble Plastic'', ``Magic Moon Balloons'', ``Blo-it'' and ``Loony Balloony''. It was first banned in New South Wales in 1974 after it was found that something in the compound caused throat irritation. A federal import ban was imposed in 1979 when it was discovered that substances in the compound were carcinogenic. To this day, the schedule of prohibited imports under the Customs Regulations contains the entry ``Balloon-blowing kits capable of being used to make balloon shapes, which contain polyvinyl acetate, ethyl acetate, acetone or benezene''.

Whether unscrupulous importers or those deceived by overseas manufacturers would volunteer enough information for a customs officer to treat such items with suspicion is not clear. However, in 1981, New Concept Import Services Pty Ltd was fined a mere $2,000 for selling such a product. I believe that the internal restrictions on movement, and the seizure, and possibility of court order of destruction, of such hazardous products, which are provided for in this Bill, would lessen the chances of such episodes recurring.

There are copious examples where products banned in one or more States have remained on sale elsewhere in Australia. One of the more grotesque cases began in 1981. Some brands of doll's feeding bottles were found to contain coloured water contaminated by human faeces. Bans were imposed in New South Wales, Western Australia and Queensland, and like items subjected to the most stringent health standards in future. Yet the bottles were reported as still on sale in Victoria last year. A similar thing happened in the case of the Sweet Suzie toy vacuum cleaner banned New South Wales in June 1984. A subscriber of Choice magazine drew that publication's attention to the potentially-fatal inhalation by children of polystyrene beads that were used as play dirt. Several children had died after inhaling similar beads used in bean bags, and choking to death. It took some nine months before officers of the Victorian Consumer Affairs Ministry were convinced that the item was still on sale in their State, and got around to initiating remedial action.

There was the case last year where necklaces made from strychnine seeds had been banned in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, both Territories and under the Commonwealth Customs Act. In a letter to its Product Monitors in March, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations asked that people check for the product's availability where is was banned, and that they lobby for its proscription in Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania. The following month, the volunteers were asked to check for an imported lamp filled with wine. It was claimed in the instructions that the bottle could be filled with petrol and the lamp lit once the wine had been drunk. Unfortunately the strong possibility of a Molotov Cocktail exploding had not occurred to whoever came up with that idea. Initially however, only South Australia and Victoria banned the item from sale.

This Bill seeks to minimise the risk of injury to Australians by making it as hard as possible for commerce in dangerous products to take place once the danger has been detected by at least one competent Australian Government body. The states can obviously assist by adopting uniform legislation based on the concept of a national register of hazardous products which combines all their efforts and protects all Australians as a result of any detection of dangers. In a situation where individual States' resources are stretched thin anyway, it is quite tragic that they be wasted in re-doing work already carried out elsewhere.

I shall be appealing to all State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to consider the well-being of all Australians, and to show faith in the expertise of all officers working on consumer hazards in this country. After the legislation is proclaimed we will no longer see the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department listing items banned in only one or two states or territories in its informative publication ``Minder''.

In the United States, there has been a robust Consumer Product Safety Commission in existence since 1972. The Commission's own work revolves around the imposition of standards, the banning of dangerous products and the maintenance of statistical databases. By its own estimates the Commission has saved US Taxpayers over $15,000 million. Its work has diminished lost working time and cut down both hospital and medical costs; and much more significantly it has eliminated much suffering and needless injuries. The Commission established a sample procedure to monitor hospital emergency rooms in 1976. Recently the US Federation of Consumer Organisations concluded that in return for the $31 million spent on the collection of data research and national enforcement each year, there were savings of over $700 million in medical, disability and rehabilitation costs.
I believe that a similar approach is needed in Australia.

Instead of tolerating fragmented State, Federal and Departmental responsibilities, we should bring together the people and resources currently in this area of consumer safety. We can in this way better protect Australians from injury and suffering, and save millions of taxpayers dollars. The Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Spyker, has been noteworthy for his strong, public support for the notion. It is, and has been for some time, Federal A.L.P. policy. The question transcends party politics and this sensible step of legislation must be taken as soon as possible. It can only win the praise of all Australians. One way of achieving this goal is to expand the resources available to the proposed registrar of Hazardous Products and the investigative and administrative brief of the registry.

Just as we need to shed parochial jealousies in relation to the battle against disease, poverty and crime, we must sustain a unified campaign against hazardous goods. We must also take proper heed of detailed work carried out overseas. That is why I have given the Registrar of Hazardous Products a capacity to seek out information and take other steps to be satisfied or otherwise about the safety of any goods.

It is important for Australia to apply its standards and make its decisions on the best information available and preferably information related to local conditions. This is particularly so when we are faced with greater theoretical hazards on one count or another. An excellent case in point was that of the anti-arthritis drug, Opren, which was never approved for use in Australia because it increased users' sensitivity to ultraviolet light. However, its use in the United Kingdom, under the name Oraflex, resulted in the deaths of at least 25 people. Others died from kidney and liver failure in Scandinavia. The Food and Drug Administration was purposely not told of any known overseas problems before it approved the use of the drug in the United States in April 1982.

A lot of the information still had not been provided when the drug was withdrawn from the market in August of that year, following at least 26 deaths and another 200 serious cases of kidney and liver failure in Scandinavia.

The Eli Lilly company and its chairman were prosecuted last year by the US Justice Department and given small fines after some plea bargaining which was said to have arisen from the difficulty of proving intent to deceive or defraud. Dr Sidney Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, in fact strongly attacked the Justice Department for its timidity in the light of its report, and claimed that Lilly executives should have been put in jail.

Cases such as this one and the deceit of the A. H. Robins Company over the Dalkon shield drive home the point that we cannot just rely on the word of manufacturers. When there are vast sums of money at stake, there will always be temptations for corporations to sweep unpleasant facts under the carpet in the hope of the problem going away. That certainly happened in the case of Robins where conscientious employees were ordered to keep quiet, and later hounded out of the company for insisting that the multifilament string could be easily prevented from acting as a wick for bacteria to get into the uterus. I do not believe that this sort of misbehaviour should be tolerated in the name of protecting corporate profits, and following the Nuremberg principle, I have provided for individual officers to be fined if they have knowingly participated in the distribution of registered hazardous goods.

The other lesson that we must draw from such occurrences is that it is somewhat safer to take product prohibitions at face value where there are open processes for deciding overseas, and to reserve the capacity to call for more information or do more testing where disputed approval has been given. Fabrication of test results has been going on for some time now, whether it be the statistically fraudulent techniques of Hugh Davis who for a long time refused to disclose his financial interest in the Dalkon Shield while he promoted it and stressed problems with other forms of contraception, or the outright fraud of chemical-testing-laboratory scientists declaring dangerous chemicals safe.

At the same time, we must pay heed to the detection of hazards by the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency in the United States for instance. There is also the United Nations publication, `Consolidated List of Products whose consumption and/or sale have banned, withdrawn, severely restricted or not approved by governments' which is regularly updated by the United Nations Secretariat. This initiative, opposed only by the United States, followed the adoption on 17 December 1982 of General Assembly resolution 37/137 which sought to bring together as much information as possible on hazardous chemicals and unsafe pharmaceuticals. It is a useful starting point when concern is expressed or allegations are made in Australia, and resources are not available to properly investigate the matter locally. Registration as a hazardous product for up to nine months will act as a lever to encourage manufacturers to provide timely information. The Registrar can initiate such a procedure under the Bill.

We would not have situations such as that revealed recently in the Sydney Morning Herald, where Ciba-Geigy undertook in 1979 to remove a carcinogen from a cattle dip and spray, but has not yet got around to it.

We might not find Ciba-Geigy reporting chlordimeform farm contamination levels on the basis of analysis of urine taken 24-48 hours after exposure, rather than within the first twelve hours after exposure before the chemical has had a chance to be degraded and excreted. Interestingly, the chemical has been voluntarily withdrawn from the market in New Zealand. It is banned in Cyprus, Pakistan, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Thailand. The company sprayed it on teenagers in an open field in Egypt as part of its testing procedures!

Other short residue pesticides are apparently available to do just as good a job without the attendant risks of using chlordimeform. This sort of information can at least be put to the manufacturers or distributors for detailed comment.

We might have avoided the dumping in Australia of heart valves by Bjork Shiley after the US Food and Drug Administration forbade their sale because evidence was needed that changes in manufacture had not introduced new risks. Apparently our Health Department was under the incorrect impression that the heart valves had investigative status in the United States. That was of little comfort to the relatives of the five Australians who died in 1983 following cardiac surgery, when the defective valves cracked away and crumbled in patients' chests. We do not yet have a class action mechanism to bring this outrage properly to book.

We may also have avoided the dumping four or five years ago of baby pacifiers which the US Consumer Product Safety Commission was rejecting. Design faults in the pacifiers posed a risk of babies swallowing them and suffocating.

We may have been better prepared when the United State introduced a safety standard for bicycles. Shonky merchants in Taiwan chose Australia as a convenient, nearby dumping ground for what they would no longer be able to clear in America. We had a sudden spate of injuries which resulted from poorly-made equipment collapsing or giving way. The 1984 Federal Court cases against two major retailers who failed to check that their merchandise met safety standards is a salutary reminder that there will always be manufacturers interested only in the quick buck. We must use all the intelligence at the disposal of Austrade and the Department of Foreign Affairs to remain one step ahead of such crooks.

In my formulation of prohibitions against the export of registered hazardous products from Australia, I was particularly moved by examples of dumping of products in another country. Some instances where we were the victims I have already alluded to. However, I also want to make sure that there is no repetition of the scandal in 1977 when Nestle continued production in Victoria of breast milk substitutes after routine tests had shown that the plant facilities were contaminated with salmonella. In Australia alone, 134 cases of gastroenteritis were positively identified as caused by the Nestle product, and eighty of those babies needed hospital treatment. We will never know the extent of the damage, to babies, and also to our trading reputation, in South East Asia as a result of this unforgiveable cover-up and corporate irresponsibility.

There are grounds for believing that Australia is regularly used as an intermediate point for the disposal of pharmaceuticals which are totally substandard. Dr. John Braithwaite of the Australian National University has pointed to estimates that 15 per cent of the drugs sold illegally in Indonesia are smuggled from Singapore, some via Australia.

Just recently Ciba-Geigy agreed to withdraw one of its anti-arthritic pain killers, Tandearil, a brand of oxyphenbutazone, worldwide and to put severe restrictions on the marketing of another, Butazolidin, a popular brand of phenylbutazone. This came three years after a leaked internal memorandum admitted knowledge of over 700 deaths due to use of Butazolidin and over 330 due to Tandearil use even though, respectively, only 72 and 76 deaths had been officially reported in medical literature. Health Action International threatened an international boycott of Ciba-Geigy products if the company continued marketing the two drugs without modification. Consumer groups are still distressed that a product that should only be a drug of last resort may again be inappropriately promoted in the third world.

This is what happened with the drug clioquinol which Ciba-Geigy had marketed aggressively in many third world countries and Japan, as a general anti-diarrhoeal agent, despite periodically warning Western veterinarians that clioquinol could lead to epilepsy and death in animals. Clioquinol created tens of thousands of victims of sub-acute myelo-optic neuropathy in Japan: Nearly 1,000 people died and many others were left in severe pain, blind, paraplegic and with irreversible damage to the nervous system. In 1978, a Tokyo District Court concluded that Ciba-Geigy had failed to adequately inform Japanese customers about the nervous system dangers. The company apologised to the victims and their families, and paid over US$150m in compensation, yet it continued to market clioquinol throughout much of the third world for several more years.

We must not allow ourselves to become an unwitting party to any unconscionable behaviour of this sort. I am heartened that the Government has moved to close the `for export only' loophole inserted into the Trade Practices Act by the Fraser Government. If goods are hazardous in Australia, they are hazardous elsewhere. We have a moral obligation to stop their further movement. We must also take steps to discourage the US Congress from any inclination to support legislation that would enable the United States pharmaceutical industry to manufacture drugs for export before the Food and Drug Administration had cleared them for domestic consumption.

The International Chemical Workers' Union has pointed out how jobs will actually be lost if an unapproved product turns out to be hazardous and the company's reputation takes a battering. There would also be no guarantee that this type of material would not find its way back into the country of origin after a complicated chain of world-wide movements. I am glad that Australia has shown the courage to resist this through the recent amendment to the Trade Practices Legislation.

My Bill provides greater protection for ordinary Australians, ensures that our trading reputation will remain high, and provides a means of pooling the meagre resources of the States and the Commonwealth to achieve worthwhile results for consumer safety. I commend both the principles and the Bill to honourable senators and urge them to address the problems of consumer safety with as much vigor as they can muster.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
