SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes-
(a) the implications to life and the planet of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster in the Soviet Union;
(b) the possible contribution to this disaster by Australia in exporting uranium;
(c) the possiblity that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;
(d) the possible eventual danger to Australia in the event of any disasters; and
(e) the need to close all uranium mines in Australia.

I thank the Government and the Opposition for their co-operation in allowing me to bring on this motion. As Leader of the Australian Democrats I am proud to move this motion. I am disgusted and outraged that, because of collusion between the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party, this Senate will not vote on it. They have got together and, by way of a series of amendments which the Labour Party will move and the Liberal Party will support, they will vote on something entirely different. The Democrats' statement that we should close down all uranium mines will not even be voted on by the Senate because, by sheer weight of numbers-a combination of Labor, Liberal and, of course, National Party, senators-I will be denied the opportunity of having my motion voted on by the Senate. The Senate will not vote on the Democrats' motion that exporting uranium and the Chernobyl disaster represent a danger to the world and to Australia. That is party politics. We must never, ever embarrass ourselves before the electorate! Therefore, we will vote on nothing.

Labor, Liberal and National senators may as well amend my motion to state `We love motherhood and we hate sin' or vice versa, so meaningless will they make my motion. That is dirty, nitpicking, petty party politics that the Liberal Party and the Labor Party are playing about something that could threaten the whole fate of this world, that could threaten every innocent woman and child on this planet, including this country. They cannot help playing party politics with it. Because it is a genuine matter the Australian Democrats raise this question of the danger to the world of the disaster at Chernobyl. Why do Liberal and Labor Party senators not have the guts to stand up and say that they believe that uranium should be mined? Why do they not vote on it? Why do they not expose themselves to the people of Australia for what they are? Instead, they will change the motion in a sneaky, underhand way so that they will not even have to vote on that matter.

In speaking to this motion I must, with great respect, refer to how little interest has been shown in this chamber and by the Parliament generally in the Chernobyl disaster since it happened. I am distressed that even in the responsible Press little or no mention has been made of the Chernobyl disaster. Today it has gone off the front page, yet not even a week has gone by since it happened. It is off page 2 and page 3. There is an obsession by newspapers, radio and television with the confessions of one Rodney Groux. For goodness sake, Rodney Groux demanded all of the pages in the responsible Press last week, to the exclusion of a disaster that could threaten the whole of humankind. The tax on car perks and flexible wage rates are considered by this Parliament and the media to be more important than the future of the world. There are not only the immediate consequences of the melt down of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor, but also the implications for the rest of this planet, and in particular for Australia. I remind the chamber that Australia is one of the largest uranium producers and exporters in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the only one.

—What a pathetic interjection. Who said it was the only one? It is one of the biggest, and does the honourable senator deny that? Why does the honourable senator not move an amendment to the Labor amendment so that he can have the guts to stand up and say: `I, Senator Parer, support the mining and export of uranium'? Why does he not at least have the guts to vote on it instead of hiding the whole matter as he is doing?

SPEECH.PARA: There were groans on both sides of the chamber last Thursday at the beginning of both my question and the question of Senator Haines on the nuclear accident. Liberal senators thought that this was not an important matter to raise; it was much more important to go after Mr Justice Murphy, Mr Rodney Groux or some other tremendous trivia. Both sides of the chamber have had a vested interest-the reason is now being exposed-in defending the indefensible, the use of nuclear energy, and the indefensible fuel cycle which leads to the production of nuclear weapons. Both sides have supported the export of Australian uranium and the proliferation of nuclear energy.

Chernobyl represents the enormity of the problem of nuclear energy. It is hard to believe, after nearly 40 years of intense anti-nuclear lobbying by anti-nuclear people, when the Democrats have stated for years that a nuclear accident would be a totally new phenomenon, unlike conventional accidents, that only last week we found out that there were fires in at least one, possibly two, reactors and that nothing could be done about them. Humankind could not put the fires out; they had to burn out. It was only this disaster that brought home to people the fact that a man-made disaster of the nuclear kind has to run its course. We cannot turn off the radiation; we cannot stop the cancers; we cannot even dispose of the nuclear waste. Chernobyl is not a question of nasty technologically inferior communist reactors, as some people have tried to make them out to be; it is not a question of communist reactors versus the good, safe, clean Western reactors. This is not fuel for the new Cold War. To treat the reactor meltdown in this way is to miss the real lesson of the accident.

This accident is not the first; it just happens to be the biggest so far. Let me give honourable senators a few examples. In 1950 at Chalk River, Canada, a hydrogen explosion caused one death and five people were contaminated. The reactor was destroyed and no follow-up study was made of the long-term health effects. In 1957 at Chelyabinsk in the Soviet Urals a nuclear waste dump explosion caused unknown deaths and long term consequences. We do know that 60,000 people were relocated, 30 towns were eliminated and 16,000 square kilometres and 14 lakes were contaminated. In 1957 at Windscale, England, a massive release of radiation from a fuel fire occurred. The fallout area included Ireland, Belgium and West Germany. The nearby town of Seascale suffered a tenfold increase in the national average of leukaemia cases and significant increases in Down's syndrome children. In 1961 at Idaho Falls in the United States of America three were killed, one gruesomely. In 1966 at Fermi, Detroit, in the US a fast breeder reactor had a partial meltdown to the point where an explosion was imminent, and 66,000 lives could have been lost immediately and the city of Detroit laid to waste. In 1979 at Three Mile Island in the US a reactor had a 20 per cent meltdown. A total disaster worse than Chernobyl could have occurred had the temperature increased by only a further 8 1/2 per cent. This could have happened anywhere, with any reactor in the world.

Even if it were agreed to increase international inspection of nuclear power reactors the accidents would still happen. It could, where a crack was discovered, lead to the closing of a reactor but it could not stop the accidents caused by human error. Unless this nuclear insanity is halted there will be many more Chernobyls. One 1982 study carried out for the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission calculated that on the history of operating experience between 1969 and 1979 a major accident could occur every 200 to 600 reactor years. Given the 350 reactors operating in the world, we could now face a major nuclear accident every 20 months. The other vital 1982 study for the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission concluded that it was possible that a US reactor accident similar to the one at Chernobyl could cause 100,000 deaths in a year and property damage in excess of $A300 billion. To say that it could not happen in the West is to fly in the face of all the facts.

So far the commentators have said there were two weak points in this nasty, communist reactor which do not exist in the good reactors of the Western world. The commentators say that the two weak points were that firstly the communist reactor used graphite and, secondly, it had no containment shell. Let us have a look at those two points. Firstly, in relation to the use of graphite, James Landis, Senior Vice-President of Stone and Webster, a Boston-based engineering firm that builds nuclear plants, said that the Chernobyl accident `is the worst kind . . . and any reactor that has graphite is susceptible'. Wait for it: Australia's own Lucas Heights has a two-feet thick wall of graphite, acting as a neutron reactor, surrounding the fuel assembly. This, together with the fact that Lucas Heights is 27 years old, makes the reactor a real safety risk. As the US study I referred to earlier indicates, graphite or no graphite a similar accident to that at Chernobyl could occur in the US or somewhere else. Secondly, let us look at the lack of a containment shell-the second point attributed to the riskiness of the Soviet communist reactor. Nuclear reactors on warships have only minimal containment shells, if any at all. So in the event of a meltdown any containment shell on a ship's nuclear reactor would not make any difference. All the nuclear-powered ships visiting our ports-the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia welcome them with open arms-are similarly vulnerable and pose safety threats to this nation's population centres. This accident could quite easily have occurred in the US, in Britain, in France or at Lucas Heights or indeed in any Australian port.

Can we begin to contemplate what a disaster Chernobyl is for Russia? The area affected by the meltdown produces 5 per cent of the Soviet Union's wheat and oats, 24 per cent of its rye, 11 per cent of its meat and potatoes, 13 per cent of its milk and 6 per cent of its eggs. The rich black soil of the Ukraine is still black, but it is now the blackness of death. A 30 kilometres radius-at least-around Chernobyl will be unusable for generations. The death of large numbers of people from radiation will peak in another two weeks and go on for two weeks after that. The cancers will begin and the genetic effects will haunt us for generations. For what motive? For greed. Yet every member of the Labor Party in this place as well as every member of the Liberal Party and the National Party in this place saying: `Let's have more reactors; let's export our uranium'. At least that is what they say when the Australian Democrats put up a motion in this chamber to ban the export of uranium. That is what they say when the Democrats move in this place to ban the import of nuclear hardware.

What of Australia's responsibilities? Australian uranium is sold in Europe-to Finland, Sweden, West Germany, Belgium and France. Let us take Finland, for example. All Australian uranium sold to Finland is shipped directly to France, where it is converted into uranium hexafluoride. This is then sent where? To the Soviet Union, for enrichment. What hypocrisy, what humbug, for people to say that Russia is our enemy, and yet we allow our uranium to be shipped via Finland and France to it. After that, the fuel rod fabrication is carried out in West Germany or Sweden. Based on what the Government has been at pains to tell us is an all-in, all-out basis-whatever the hell that means-what goes into the Soviet Union at the enrichment stage is uranium hexafluoride but what comes out is U235, for nuclear energy, and the tails-U238. The Democrats say that the tails-that is, the by-product of the production of U235-is then sent to France to be used as a blanket for the French Super Phoenix fast breeder reactor used in the production of plutonium for use in nuclear weapons. France produces each year 330 kilograms of plutonium, which is sufficient for up to 60 nuclear bombs each year. Yet we have the hypocrisy to blame France for exploding nuclear devices in the Pacific when we are, directly or indirectly, exporting to France the stuff that allows those nuclear bombs to be made. This is not hypothesis, it is official information from the governments involved. So much for the double speak and cant of the Australian Government and the Australian Opposition, who say that no Australian uranium ever finishes up in nuclear weapons. Of course it does. It finishes up as French nuclear bombs.

As for our flashy safeguards, an officer from the Australian Safeguards Office-this is cute-a person entrusted with guarding us on the safeguards issue, made a statement in 1985 saying that the contract between Finland and the Soviet Union for enrichment had expired and that no more Australian uranium sold to Finland would be enriched in the Soviet Union. One wonders how safe we are if we have safety officers making such idiotic statements of misinformation. Not only Finland but other of Australia's customers send fuel to the Soviet Union for enrichment under contracts going back to the mid-1960s. France, Germany, Britain and Sweden all send their uranium to Russia for enrichment. There is one common denominator of those countries-all of them happen to be Australia's customers. Yet we still have the hypocrisy to say we do not send our uranium to Russia.

Not only are Australian safeguards officers apparently misinformed but also the agreements themselves are ridiculous. All Australian safeguards agreements include a clause which says that in the event of non-compliance the offending receiver country has to return all nuclear materials. Presumably they have to give us back our yellowcake. The Australian Government should now immediately on that basis ask France to return our yellowcake. Can anybody here really see that happening? It is a ridiculous situation. In answer to Senator Haines's question last week, Senator Evans said:
I believe we do have an obligation to supply uranium to those countries dependent on nuclear power for a substantial proportion of their energy needs.

A number of quite serious questions arise out of this rather quaint statement. According to Senator Evans, we have a legal obligation through the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons to supply uranium. Under Article VI of that Treaty we also have a legal obligation, as do the super-powers, to:
pursue negotiations in good faith . . . for the cessation of the nuclear arms race and nuclear disarmament.

This is a legal obligation and, given the facts I have just presented-that through the enrichment process Australian uranium is at least used in the production of French nuclear bombs-we are in reality breaking the NPT through the selling of our uranium.

Secondly, Senator Evans said that we have an obligation to sell uranium to countries that are dependent on nuclear power for a substantial proportion of their needs. How dependent-100 per cent, 50 per cent or 20 per cent? He has not said. On what basis are we selective? Do we draw the line at some, or does a so-called moral and legal obligation extend also to Egypt, Yugoslavia, Taiwan and Iraq, who are NPT signatories with nuclear energy needs? This Government draws the moral and legal line where it suits it, and the only line that suits it is the making of a quick buck. The Opposition has exactly the same policy.

Thirdly, when is a country dependent for a substantial proportion on nuclear energy? If this Government says that we have to provide nuclear energy to those nations which are dependent on it for a substantial proportion, what is the proportion it operates on? For too long this Government has been able to hide behind a lot of generalisations and mumbo-jumbo. If it is to export uranium, surely it has an obligation to the people of Australia to say to whom and on what basis, and that it is not just for money. Again, the Government decides where it will draw the line, and it is a line based on convenience and greed.

I began this speech by referring to the massive lack of interest in this matter which threatens life on this planet. It is a matter which could block out all forms of life for centuries. We have an opportunity to begin to deal with this matter at the Australian Labor Party Federal Conference. It can do so without shame in the light of Chernobyl. It can draw the right conclusions from this disaster. The reality of Hiroshima, Chernobyl and Windscale is that those who have a flat learning curve will finish up on the nuclear scrapheap of history. The tragedy is that they will take the rest of the world and many innocent people with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The quality and the level of responsibility of Senator Chipp's rhetoric in the contribution we have just heard can be gauged by giving just one example of a comprehensive and indeed dangerously misleading misstatement. I am referring in particular to Senator Chipp's reference to the HIFAR reactor, the research reactor in Australia and Australia's only nuclear reactor, as having graphite as an essential component in it and therefore being indistinguishable in some relevant respect in Senator Chipp's statement from the Chernobyl reactor, which is the subject of this motion. It is of course the case-I spelt it out in detail in answer to a question from his own colleague Senator Mason on 30 April-that there is simply no comparison whatever between the Australian reactor and the Russian one that has been the subject of this calamitous accident. The construction is entirely different with heavy water, which of course is not combustible at all, rather than graphite being used as the moderator in the Australian reactor. The only graphite contained in HIFAR is a neutron reflecting layer which is outside the reactor vessel.
—Graphite is a neutron absorbent.

—We have had enough illustrations today of Senator Sanders's understanding of technical things and his responsibility in addressing matters of fact. Let me answer this matter. This graphite layer is not exposed to sufficient fast neutron flux levels to make it even conceivable that those conditions of heat and radioactivity would combine to create the kind of situation here that has developed elsewhere. It is not conceivable scientifically that that could occur. It is also the case that HIFAR operates at a power level of only about one three-hundredth of that of the Soviet reactor, as I also told Senator Mason. It is not a pressurised system. As one physicist was widely reported as saying, even if something did go drastically wrong with the HIFAR reactor-which does not seem possible, given the safety systems; but even if it did-the chances of that causing serious harm would be about the same as being electrocuted by a torch battery. For Senator Chipp to create the impression in the community for those who happen to have been listening to him that there is some prospect in Australia of Australia's one nuclear research reactor creating the same kind of disaster as has obviously occurred in the Soviet Union is sheer irresponsibility on his behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: It should also be acknowledged on the same point that the only other graphite moderated water cooled reactor in the world is a research one at Hanford in the United States of America operated by the United States Department of Energy. It is that combination of a graphite moderator system and a water cooling that is unique and uniquely dangerous about the Soviet system, particularly in the absence of backup safety systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Windscale?

—Why do I bother? Windscale is a completely different system. It has graphite in it but not the same cooling mechanism; it is a gas reactor, as Senator Sanders ought to know but clearly does not. But that does not stop his prejudice, emotion and the stream of nonsense that emerges from him. Let me return to the terms of the motion, having demonstrated by that one example-and there are many more I could pick from the speech-just how irresponsible, inaccurate, extravagant, misleading and misguided the Democrat motion is.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one part of it with which the Government does of course agree, namely:
The Senate notes the implications to life and the planet of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident in the Soviet Union.

Those implications are very grave, profound and certainly deserve to be noted, and noted with great seriousness, by this Senate, in exactly the same terms in which the motion at least to this extent has been moved by the Australian Democrats. Although the situation appears to have stabilised at the Chernobyl reactor, it is manifestly serious. It is difficult for us, on the information available to us still at this stage, to assess just how serious it was. Though it is important not to extravagantly overexagerate what may have been the case until we know the reality, there is no doubt in anyone's mind that the most serious nuclear accident in the history of this technology has in fact occurred, with grave consequences not only for the health and safety of those in the vicinity but clearly for a great many people in both eastern and western Europe. We deplore that that has occurred. We deplore that obvious weakness in the safety systems and the administration and everything else. We deplore the secrecy that has been associated with this by the Soviets from the first day, and there are many lessons to be drawn in weighing and evaluating that accident.

So far as Australia is concerned, there is no evidence to suggest that the plume of radioactivity from the accident has reached the upper atmosphere. Further, the spread of radioactivity appears confined to surface wind systems and it will probably be 12 to 18 months before there is any movement of contamination at all from the accident across the equatorial belt. In the meantime, the radioactive contamination will be reduced by natural decay and wash-out by rain and it is not expected that readily detectable levels will reach Australia.

In response to the suggestion that will be picked up later in an Opposition amendment about the need to establish a full inquiry within Australia as to the Chernobyl disaster and its implications for Australia as well as for the world so far as nuclear technology is concerned, I would mention that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission has established an internal task group to examine all available information on the accident and its consequences. I believe that that may well go most of the way, if not all the way, towards satisfying the Opposition request, which it wants to add to the terms of this motion, to establish a task force of suitably qualified experts to advise the Government in carrying out the terms of the resolution.

At this stage the AAEC task group is receiving and analysing overseas reports through Australia's diplomatic contacts. I understand that it is due to produce at least a preliminary report within a week. It is certainly my intention to make public, as soon as may be, the Atomic Energy Commission's assessment. We would certainly be happy, with the expertise we have, to make it available to anyone elsewhere who wants it, but it has to be acknowledged that our capacity to assist is quite limited as we have had no experience anywhere in this country of operating reactors of the type used at Chernobyl or in the operation of any commercial nuclear-powered reactors of any type.

The second part of Senator Chipp's motion refers to the possible contribution to this disaster by Australia in exporting uranium. The terms of the Government's amending motion, which I have circulated in this place and which I will formally move at the end of my speech, make it clear that the way the second part of the Democrats' motion has been couched is simply not acceptable. What we would prefer to say, and in this respect we accept the Opposition's amendment to our original proposal, is:
. . . that the policies of successive governments mean Australia makes no contribution to the USSR's supply of nuclear material;

We acknowledge, as I have said in Question Time in answer to questions from the Democrats, that some of our uranium customer countries may wish to use the uranium enrichment facilities in the USSR. It is the case that Finland and Sweden, both customers for Australian uranium, have used those enrichment facilities. Australia permits enrichment of consignments of Australian origin nuclear material in the USSR on behalf of our safeguards treaty partners on an all-in all-out basis. Senator Chipp expressed some bemusement at what that concept meant. It simply means that under this arrangement both the enriched uranium and the depleted uranium tails which are left over as a result of the enrichment process must be removed from the USSR and returned to a country which has a nuclear safeguards agreement with Australia where the material can then be accounted for by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you happy about how that is checked?
—I would be delighted for Senator Chipp and his colleagues to get a full appreciation of how the nuclear accounting system works by visiting the Australian Safeguards Office in Sydney.
—You don't know.

—I am sick of this lunatic assertion that I do not know, that the Government does not know, that the Australian Safeguards Office does not know, that the International Atomic Energy Agency does not know where Australian origin nuclear material is. The nuclear accounting system is such that we can account for every portion of the material that goes into that country and comes out again, on the principle of equivalence. We can account for it. We have accounted for it. I have the information available. I will be happy to put it on the record tomorrow in answer to the honourable senator, describing with some precision all the different weights, measures and volumes of Australian origin nuclear material and where it has ended up. Of course that information is available. Our system is a sophisticated one. It works very well. We are quite conscientious in our application of the international safeguards system. No reasoned argument in the world can combat the kind of emotionalism that is wafting across me at the moment from the other side of the chamber. I do not intend to respond, except to say that I reject utterly the constant assertion, which Senator Sanders has been parroting away all day, that we do not know where this material is. We know perfectly well that it is not in the USSR.
—Do you know that it is not in France?

—I will be happy to answer any further questions at the end of the day. I want to get on with the business of answering this debate. The principle of all-in all-out which applies very effectively precludes the possibility of any nuclear material of Australian origin remaining in the USSR and provisions of that kind are incorporated in our nuclear safeguards agreement with Finland, Sweden, Euratom and Switzerland. I think that sufficiently answers that point.

SPEECH.PARA: The third part of the Democrats' motion concerns the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe. What we propose, bearing in mind what I said earlier about the unique character of Soviet technology, is that a more constructive way of expressing that point is to say that the Australian Government will pursue all opportunities for further strengthening of international co-operation in this area, including the possibility of mandatory international safety standards to minimise the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe. We do not acknowledge that a disaster of this type could be repeated elsewhere because the technology is so conspicuously different and the safety standards are so obviously conspicuously different elsewhere where there is a nuclear energy industry. The accident at Chernobyl has, of course, made the safety of nuclear facilities a very prominent issue. It is quite appropriate that that should be so. But I think we can do better in strengthening international co-operation in this respect. Australia is perfectly happy to do its utmost to generate that extra degree of international co-operation. There is much more I could say in detail about this matter but for the moment I think that is probably sufficient. We have certainly supported a whole variety of initiatives through the International Atomic Energy Agency on a bilateral basis, and on a multilateral basis through the Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and we will go on doing so.

The fourth part of the Chipp motion refers to `the possible eventual danger to Australia in the event of any disasters'. Again, that is something of a misreading of the present situation in the light of, as I said, the evidence available to us about the supreme unlikelihood that readily detectable radiation levels will reach Australia as a result of the Chernobyl nuclear accident.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you let the Senate vote on that? Why did you remove it from the motion?

—We will still be able to vote for it. I am moving it by way of an amendment to Senator Chipp's motion. If he does not like it, he can vote on his own. We prefer to put it in the following terms `while there is no cause for concern' because we do not want to generate concern, alarm or anxiety in the community at large. We are a little more responsible than Senator Chipp and his colleagues who are prepared to say and do anything to generate a quick, populist response and not a clear understanding of what the issues are. Against that background, we would prefer to word this part of the motion differently, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . while there is no cause for concern that fall-out from the Chernobyl accident will present any hazard in Australia, it is essential that this country continue to maintain adequate systems to monitor levels from all sources of radioactivity which may present a public health hazard . . .

In that respect let me say for the record that in Australia a radiation monitoring system has been operating since the mid-1950s. Samples of fall-out are collected routinely from sampling stations across Australia and analysed at the Australian Radiation Laboratory in Melbourne. Periodically milk samples are also analysed. These monitoring systems are considered to be adequate to meet the current, or any other possible future, circumstances and the Government will ensure that they are maintained.

The final part of the Chipp motion is about the need to close all uranium mines in Australia. This is at odds with the present Government's uranium policy. I will explain in a moment why that policy exists and why we believe it must be maintained. Clearly, Senator Chipp's motion is unacceptable to the extent that it amounts to a head-on confrontation with that policy. More constructively we would prefer to say in this respect that the Senate notes:

. . . the Government's resolve to pursue in international forums the establishment of a mandatory system requiring nations in which similar accidents occur to notify other countries which may be affected, at the first opportunity and in the fullest possible detail.

There is an obvious need, in the aftermath of this accident and, in particular, the utterly indefensible secrecy which surrounded it, to have an international regime operating in which we would hope that every country in the world co-operated and which made at least provision for a recording system and a capacity as a result for an emergency response associated with it. We believe, as I said earlier, that there is a need for international arrangements in the nuclear safety field to be further pursued, particularly in the areas I have just mentioned of early warning and emergency assistance. We are now examining the most effective way of promoting multilateral measures of this kind. We recognise the difficulties involved because many countries, including, in particular, the non-Western regimes, are not prepared, or have not been prepared so far, to accept mandatory arrangements. But we believe that there are opportunities for pursuing further international co-operation in this area.

Some steps are already under way in international forums in response to the accident. I advise the Senate, for example, that the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency Committee on the Safety of Nuclear Installations is convening a special meeting this Friday, 9 May, to discuss the possible impact of the accident on OECD countries. Australia will be represented at that meeting. I heard on the news earlier today that the Director-General of the IAEA, Dr Blix, has been invited, I think, to the USSR to be briefed on the accident. As a result he will then be in a position to report upon it to the IAEA. That meeting of the Board of Governors of the IAEA in June will provide an opportunity for effective debate on this issue. It is a major topic of discussion at the present Tokyo economic summit meeting. There is an expectation that there will be a communique today expressing the need for, among other things, mandatory reporting of nuclear accidents. I know that bilaterally Australia and Japan have already had discussions. In my discussions a few days ago with the Japanese Minister for Science and Technology we discussed the need for international co-operation in securing mandatory reporting arrangements of this kind.

Finally, let me say something about the Government's uranium mining policy and how it contrasts rationally with Senator Chipp's demand, in the final paragraph of his motion, to close all uranium mines in Australia. No government has looked more closely at this issue or had to justify its position under closer political scrutiny than has the Hawke Labor Government. That is well known.

A number of points could be made but I really have time to make only one. It is not a matter of selling uranium in order, as Senator Chipp would rather churlishly and inappropriately say, to make a fast buck at any cost, whatever the consequences. We are selling uranium because the contribution we make to the peaceful uses of nuclear energy is something that might be regarded as desirable from the point of view of an energy starved world, and one that will not get any less energy starved in the years ahead with the depletion of oil and other more readily accessible fuels; but it is not only for that kind of reason. It is not even because of the greater responsibility we bring to the selling of our uranium than is the case with any other supplier in the world or because of the much more meticulous attention we devote to safeguard regimes to ensure that that material is used for peaceful and not for military purposes, although we do have an extraordinarily meticulous regime.

Overwhelmingly, the reason is that we see it as a corollary of our acute and intense commitment to the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. I have said it before and the Government has said it before but it bears repetition over and again: The Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty to which we are all committed in every part of this chamber is a commitment that involves reciprocal obligations. It involves an obligation on the part of the nuclear weapons states not to supply nuclear weapons technology or material to any other country to proliferate in that way and an obligation on its non-weapons signatories not to develop nuclear weapons technology and not to accept the supply of nuclear weapons material in that way. The third part, where Australia comes in as well as at the second leg, is the obligation it imposes on all states, both weapons states and otherwise, to co-operate peacefully in the supply and exchange of raw materials and peaceful nuclear technology. That is an Australian commitment. It is one that we are obliged to honour and one that we are proud to go on honouring. I therefore move the following amendment to Senator Chipp's motion:
Leave out all words after paragraph (a), insert
`(b) that the Government's policies mean Australia makes no contribution to the USSR's supply of nuclear material;

(c) that the Australian Government will pursue all opportunities for further strengthening of international co-operation in the area of mandatory international safety standards to minimise the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;

(d) that while there is no cause for concern that fall-out from the Chernobyl accident will present any hazard in Australia, it is essential that this country continue to maintain adequate systems to monitor levels from all sources of radioactivity which may present a public health hazard; and

(e) the Government's resolve to pursue in international forums the establishment of a mandatory system requiring nations in which similar accidents occur to notify other countries which may be affected, at the first opportunity and in the fullest possible detail'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was dealing with the problem facing Australia and the world from the implications of the Chernobyl disaster in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics a week or more ago. SPEECH.PARA: Nuclear power now accounts for about 13% of the electricity produced in the world, with France and Belgium generating over 50% of their electricity by nuclear power in 1984. At the end of 1984 there were 318 power reactors . . . in commercial operation in 26 countries . . .

It goes on to say that it has been estimated that coal has the potential to provide between one-half and two-thirds of the additional energy that will be needed by the world in the next few decades and also discusses the various restraints and limitations that there are upon coal as alone being able to meet the needs of the world for electric power. —It is all very well for Senator Sanders, who apparently has decided that he will escape from the United States of America, from where he comes, to Tasmania in the hope that he will get as far away from the rest of the world as he can. The Australian Democrats' motion simply does not do that. The policy of the Opposition for some time has been stated to be:

SPEECH.PARA: We will work, in conjunction with the International Atomic Energy Agency, to promote improvement in the efficiency and effectiveness of its safeguards operations and encourage other member countries to do the same.

We will maintain an active role in the maintenance of high international standards of safety and surveillance in the industry and in the improvement of those standards where necessary. Australia imposes standards higher than the minimum currently laid down internationally, and we will press for the extension of Australian standards to all user and supplier countries.

It was one of the major initiatives and decisions of the Fraser Government to institute rigid safeguards standards as a condition for the supply of Australian uranium. That is why it is simply not true, as the Democrats assert in their motion, that Australia may have contributed to this disaster by exporting uranium. Because of the policies pursued by the Fraser Government and continued by the present Hawke Government, it is simply not possible under our safeguards policies that any Australian uranium would be able to be used in the Soviet Union. Under the umbrella of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons we have established safeguards which are higher than those standards which have been in place.

It may well be that there ought to be a further development in the world community, through and under the control of the International Atomic Energy Agency, for higher standards of control and monitoring of safety standards. Safeguards are one thing. They deal with preventing the diversion of uranium for non-peaceful means. The other standard which is required-recognised by the Government in its amendment, with which the Opposition will agree-is that there ought to be a build-up of the powers and resources of the International Atomic Energy Agency to monitor and enforce international standards relating to safety. That is a weakness in the present situation, despite a great deal of work that has been done by both the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Nuclear Energy Agency on the establishment of safety standards. We should work towards encouraging the international community to give a greater role to the International Atomic Energy Agency in safety areas. Therefore, we support the Government's proposal. We also believe that it is disgraceful that the Soviet Union did not alert the world, particularly its neighbours, to what had happened at Chernobyl. It did not even admit it for two or three days after it had happened. Clearly, there is need for a system of mandatory requirement to advise neighbouring countries and international agencies of any incidents that may occur, not simply of disasters but of any incidents which may occur of significance. If there is anything like an accident on the scale of Chernobyl, or anything far less than that of Chernobyl, these should be advised, by the country concerned and its nuclear industry, to an international safety body so that immediate action can be taken by other people in the world. These incidents are not simply the business of the country concerned; they are the business not only of its neighbours but of the whole world.

We believe that the Government should establish a body which can operate in international fora, where these matters should be discussed, to implement the policies which this Government has asked us to note that it will adopt, and with which we agree. We have pursued similar policies. As our policies continue to improve on the international control of safety standards, we believe that the Government should establish a task force of suitably qualified independent experts to advise the Government in carrying out the terms of this amendment and to report their advice to the Parliament.

As I said earlier in this debate, the Government should have taken the initiative in making a statement to this Parliament and in initiating this debate. I believe that the Government has set out, in its amendment, the right approach. The Government has been deficient in not having even told us that it had established a task force in the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. We learned that tonight from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). But I think a wider task force is required than one simply from within the Commission. It should have qualified, independent experts, drawn from universities or from other bodies in Australia, advising the Government on how to design, carry out, and further the international standards which are required and which, undoubtedly, will be the subject of a great deal more debate in the international community. Finally, the advice from that body of experts should be made known and reported to this Parliament so that we can keep this matter under constant review. On behalf of the Opposition, I move the following amemdments to the Government's proposed amendment:

`, and in the opinion of the Senate the Government should establish a task force of suitably qualified independent experts to advise the Government in carrying out the terms of this resolution and to report their advice to the Parliament'.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I would like to commend the motion and to thank the Australian Democrats for bringing this issue to the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: I deplore the secrecy which has surrounded this accident so far. The Soviet Union deserves to be severely criticised for its secrecy in the way it has dealt with this problem. TALK.START.PARA: —What about coal mining?

—I have talked about coal mining already. If the honorable senator did not listen to that, he should have been listening. I would like to mention just a couple of instances of accidents involving the transport of uranium and nuclear materials in general. In December 1968 an entire ship carrying a consignment of uranium oxide disappeared in the Mediterranean Sea and later turned up in a Turkish port, minus its crew and its 200-tonne cargo. It is widely believed that Israel used the uranium to fuel its weapons complex at Dimona.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1977 a train carrying uranium hexafluoride was derailed in North Carolina. It took rescue teams over seven hours to determine how much radiation was leaking from canisters and, when high readings were measured by military personnel, they fled the scene. In September of the same year 40,000 pounds of yellowcake was allowed to remain on the ground while State officials, the company and the trucking firm bickered over whose job it was to clean up the mess. So much for the safety of transporting uranium.

Uranium is transported around the world in increasing quantities because there are 374 nuclear powered generators in operation and there are also in operation 352 reactors on board ships belonging to the world's navies. In total, there are 726 opportunities for disaster of the type that we have just seen in the Ukraine in the last week-726 potential time bombs either moving around the world in the world's navies or housed in the various countries that are part of the nuclear industry. There are 26 countries involved in the nuclear industry and fourteen of those countries have identified severe problems.

I am sure that other speakers who follow me will talk more about the accidents that have happened in other places, but I want to draw into the debate the problem that is faced by many people in Australia who live in ports which are visited by nuclear powered warships. Nuclear powered warships visit Australian ports in increasing numbers. Up until 1979 only 7 per cent of warships from the United States of America coming to Australia were nuclear powered but since then the figure has increased to 40 per cent. In 1980 Western Australia had 11 nuclear powered warship visits. In 1981 it had 14 and since then it has dropped off to eight in 1982, 13 in 1983, six in 1984 and seven last year. This is probably not such a major issue to senators who come from other States but in Western Australia it is a real issue. My presence here is testimony to that.

Nuclear warships, both American and Soviet, have a bad history of accidents. There has been one reactor meltdown on board a ship and that was on board the icebreaker Lenin, which happened in 1966. A possible meltdown also occurred on one of the two United States submarines that sank in the Atlantic in the 1960s. There has been a long record of leaks in Apra Harbour in Guam and in other ports, even if none have so far been recorded in Australia, which is rather more a matter of luck, I believe, than of careful management. Numerous other accidents involving collisions, weapons accidents and breakdowns have been recorded by nuclear navies everywhere. One of the problems with nuclear powered vessels is that they are controlled by military authorities, which are secretive about their operations and, in particular, about their safety standards. There are no independent overseers and there is no international control.

A United States Navy report obtained in the United States in January 1986 under the freedom of information legislation admits that 628 mishaps occurred between 1965 and 1985. Most of those were minor but 32 rated `Broken Arrow' status, so they are quite serious, and they included the rupture of weapons leading to radiation leakages. It is most important that people understand that every time these nuclear powered warships come into our ports we are putting the population at risk.

By way of example, I will refer to a few accidents that have occurred. In 1963 the USS Thresher, a nuclear powered submarine, experienced reactor problems and sank off the New England coast with 129 men on board. It lies in 8,400 feet of water but it has never been precisely located. In 1968 the nuclear powered submarine USS Scorpion, with all crew on board, was lost in the mid-Atlantic. It has never been recovered. In 1968 Japanese scientists monitoring radiation adjacent to the submarine USS Swordfish discovered levels up to 20 times higher than normal background radiation. The Japanese believed the radiation may have been linked to the discharge of coolant into Sasebo Harbour. In 1978 in Puget Sound naval shipyard, the reactor on board the submarine USS Puffer released 500 gallons of radioactive water from the coolant system into the shipyard.

As far as the emergency procedures are concerned in the event of an accident on board nuclear powered warships, there are no adequate safeguards. Evidently there are documents detailing emergency procedures but they are not available to the public. There is a document called the `Nuclear Warships Visit Plan' but it has been extremely difficult to obtain information from the State emergency services which are meant to be able to deal with any emergencies. Recently Michael Lynch, a former member of the Royal Australian Navy, who was command control operations officer at Cockburn Sound and who was in charge of the visits of all warships to Western Australian ports, said that after 20 years in the Navy he found himself compelled to resign because his commission was to defend Australia. He said he realised that in his position of dealing with the visits of warships to Cockburn Sound and to other Western Australian ports he was not defending Australia but was inviting risk and inviting attack on Australia by the frequent visits of these nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships.

I believe that the Australian Government is not being honest with the Australian people, because it does not give out any information on emergency procedures, unlike the situation in New Zealand. The Government says it has emergency procedures but they are kept secret, I believe, because they are totally inadequate. In New Zealand a leaflet prepared by the Auckland Civil Defence Council in 1979 warned people about some of the possible dangers and some of the precautions they would need to take. It stated, for instance, that warnings would be given to the public, that there would be assembly points, that there would be decontamination centres, that welfare centres would be set up and that there would be evacuation procedures. It is this kind of information which the people in Australian ports visited by nuclear warships need to have at hand. There would be total chaos in any ports visited by nuclear powered warships if there was an accident, because nobody is aware of the emergency procedures. I believe that not even the people who are meant to be engaged in carrying out those emergency procedures are aware of them. For example, the firemen in Fremantle have never had a practice or a drill so that they know what they are meant to do in the event of an accident.

The Australian Government needs to come clean. It needs to prepare for accidents by having simulated nuclear reactor accidents so that people can actually practise what they are meant to do in the event of an accident or it should not continue to allow these dangerous warships to come into our ports. They are potentially extremely dangerous. As well as the interest that is being shown in this matter in Western Australia, of course, there is a new angle on this subject more recently in respect of Jervis Bay, part of the Australian Capital Territory, which is now on line to receive more visits of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships.
