TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a rather emotional motion moved by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes-
(a) the implications to life and the planet of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster in the Soviet Union;
(b) the possible contribution to this disaster by Australia in exporting uranium;
(c) the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;
(d) the possible eventual danger to Australia in the event of any disasters; and
(e) the need to close all uranium mines in Australia.

That motion has been emotionally supported by the senator from Western Australia, Senator Vallentine, who has just sat down, and undoubtedly will be emotionally supported by yourself, Madam Acting Deputy President, and some of the other Australian Democrat senators. Let us get this debate back on the rails and let us talk a little bit about reality. First of all, we have a world that relies pretty generally on electricity power generation. The major power stations run on steam driven turbines. That steam is generated by some sort of heat source, either the burning of coal or the burning of oil and in some instances by a chain reaction in a nuclear reactor. Let us get down to what it is-it is a heat source that generates steam to drive turbines that will then drive generators. It is technology that has been with us now for some considerable number of years.

Senator Chipp said that this debate has become a case of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics versus Western-type technology. I put it that it is really old technology versus new technology. We are talking about the reactor meltdown that it appears happened in Chernobyl last week. The reactors at Chernobyl are unique in nuclear-power generation. They have a large graphite core which is used for moderation. In this instance, the core is 1,200 tonnes of graphite. The pit in which it is placed measures 21.6 metres by 21.6 metres and it is about 25 metres deep. That is a large graphite core in anybody's language. Through that core there are 1,600 channels through which pass the fuel rods and the piping which takes the water.

The Chernobyl reactor, to my knowledge, has a capacity of about 3,140 megawatts thermal or 1,000 megawatts electrical. That is pretty large in anybody's language, and that size creates one of the basic problems for Russian power generation in that the reactor is not inside a containment vessel. It is charged with 204 tonnes of uranium 235 enriched to only 1.8 per cent, compared with about 3 per cent in most of the Western-type reactors except for the Candu reactor. That is up from naturally occurring uranium 235 of 0.7202 per cent. The reactor basically works on what is known as a dirty circuit. In other words, water is heated by coming up through the core, through the chain reaction. As it heats up steam is generated which then goes to the steam turbines. If the reactor were to be properly contained, the whole thing would have to be inside a vessel because it is a very dirty circuit. Having gone from the turbine, the steam comes back through the condenser.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you are describing is a simple pressurised water reactor. It is not unique at all.

—It is more a boiling water reactor, not a pressurised water reactor. The honourable senator should know his terms. As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted by the ignorance of the honourable senator from Tasmania--
—Don't call him a Tasmanian or you and I will fall out.

—I am sorry, but that is where the honourable senator comes from. I know the Tasmanians do not own him. The reactor is a little similar to the Magnox reactor which has been generating power in Great Britain for some 20 years. There is one at Tokai Mura in Japan and I think there might also be one in Italy.
—Similar? That is gas cooled.

—Senator Sanders has got one thing right tonight. It is a gas-cooled reactor but it has a graphite moderating core. It is gas cooled and the gas goes through the dirty circuit to a heat exchanger which in turn generates steam, which then provides the power for the turbines. So there is a clean secondary circuit. As well as being gas cooled, not water cooled, as is the Chernobyl reactor, it has a clean secondary circuit, whereas the Chernobyl reactor operates mainly on the dirty primary circuit in which steam goes straight through the turbine. So there is that difference. The last Magnox was commissioned in 1969. Advanced gas reactors have been made since then but the last was commissioned some time after 1974. Using the graphite as a moderator is basically pretty old technology. Most reactors in the Western World are boiling water reactors or pressure water reactors. This is where Senator Sanders was a little confused. A boiling water reactor is very similar to that at Chernobyl in that there is a dirty circuit, whereas in the pressure water reactor the water is the moderator and cooler. It goes through the primary circuit to the heat exchanger, then there is the clean secondary circuit which goes to the turbine, thus generating power.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened at Chernobyl? We do not know. One of two things probably happened. Either something went wrong with the control arms or something went wrong with the cooling water coming into the reactor. Quite possibly there was human failure, and Three Mile Island has already been mentioned in the debate. For those who have studied Three Mile Island, it is quite significant that had the reactor been left to its own devices nothing would have happened. It would have shut down and everything would have been all right. Unfortunately, operators who were not as skilled as they should have been interrupted the normal proceedings and thus the Three Mile Island accident happened. Significantly, nobody was killed in that accident.

At Chernobyl, whatever happened, ultimately there was lack of cooling. Control rods are used to control the heat out of any reactor. In a major call on a normal steam-driven generator more coal or fuel is blown in. In a nuclear reactor the control rods come out and allow the chain reaction to speed up, thus more heat is generated. When the control rods all drop in, the chain reaction stops. However, once the chain reaction has started there is a lot of residual heat from the ongoing radioactive decay in the fuel rods. Thus it is imperative that the cooling water gets into the reactors straight away. In this instance, we do not know what happened. It seems that there was a lack of cooling water. A tremendous amount of heat would have been generated. For the graphite core to catch fire the temperature would have had to have been about 4,000 degrees centigrade. There could have been a massive and immediate buildup of heat or superheated steam, or both, which blew the top off the reactor.

The Soviet system has a lack of safety devices compared with the Western system. There being no containment vessel at Chernobyl, the explosion blew the top off the reactor and the building. Thus radioactive fall-out was released which went all over Eastern Europe. For those who do not understand, it was not a nuclear explosion. It was an explosion such as might occur if a boiler blows up, with a massive amount of heat, steam, or whatever being released straight away. Anybody in the vicinity obviously would have been killed. Death always comes into the argument, whatever accident occurs in whatever industry. In power generation in thermal-powered stations, when anything happens, perhaps a steam pipe bursts, if anybody is around there will always be death. There are deaths on the road, but apparently it does not matter if people are killed on the roads. We accept that, yet we do not accept years of safety in nuclear power generation. When something goes wrong the heat in the argument goes up astronomically.

I remember clearly the day of the Three Mile Island accident. It made the headlines in most newspapers in Australia. On page 3 or 4 there was a four- or five-line paragraph indicating that about 25 coal miners had been killed in an underground mine accident. Twenty-five coal miners rated hardly a mention in the newspapers. Nobody was killed in the accident at Three Mile Island yet it made the headlines. Let us keep things in perspective. As long as there are thermal power stations that have to be fired by coal there will be accidents in coal mines, safe as we try to make them. There seems to be emotion about the nuclear cycle but not about the other.

What are the options? Too many thermal-fired power stations are causing such problems as acid rain in Europe, which is of concern to all of us, particularly those in the Northern Hemisphere. There are arguments that we cannot build dams here and there, yet that is a renewable source which is quite clean. We have to make up our minds. Do we need power and the standard of living we have come to accept? The other argument that was being used, of course, was weapons. Weapons that are designed around plutonium need pure grade plutonium 239, which generally does not come out of nuclear power reactors. I am not denying that that plutonium comes out of reactors. Most of those nations that are into the nuclear weapons business have their own research reactors to provide it. Certainly most of the power reactors are not providing plutonium 239. The plutonium that comes out of them, plutonium 240 and 241 and all the rest of it, is too impure for nuclear weapons. Our own HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights has already been mentioned. Australia literally leads the world in some of the medical uses to which products from the nuclear reactor are put. It manufactures technetium, cobalt is used in cancer treatment and all the rest of it.

Of course, solar power always comes into the argument. I would be the first to agree that more work should be done on the use of solar power, but there is one basic physical fact: In optimum conditions we get one kilowatt of power from the sun per one square metre on the ground. That is pure and simple. By the time we convert that power to electrical energy we are down to about 10 per cent usage. Whereas we certainly should use more solar power-I agree with that-we have to be realistic about it. When we need massive amounts of power generated we certainly cannot get that power purely from the solar system. My colleague Senator Sheil mentioned by way of interjection when Senator Vallentine was talking that far more people die of sun cancer in Australia every year than are ever likely to die from any nuclear power generation plant mishap.

No matter what we think, in Gabon between 1.7 million and 1.9 million years ago there were naturally occurring reactors in the ground. At that stage, in that place, there was sufficient uranium 235 at 3 per cent to start off a chain reaction. There was sufficient water in the ground then to act as a moderator. It is estimated that those natural reactors operated for about 150,000 years, 1.7 million to 1.9 million years ago. We might think we are pretty good in this age but, as usual, mother nature has beaten us to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a lot of talk but very little of it has been highly informational or instructional. The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, came into the debate with his usual eloquence but very little else. He said that the danger from Lucas Heights was about the same as being electrocuted by a torch battery. He has a rather Yes, Minister, response to these issues and I do not know whether that is just because he is a lawyer and perhaps does not understand the issue, or whether he is actually being misled by his Department. Either is possible. Certainly he does not understand the route that Australian uranium is taking. The end products, of course, are ending up in France.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has launched a motion which is as fatuous as the Government's amendment. The thrust of Senator Durack's argument was apparently: Yes, we may have trouble with nuclear power, but not much. At any rate we have to accept this. This is the way it is and we cannot fight City Hall. Basically that is what he said. I say: Rubbish. If we cannot change anything in this world there is no point in our being here. We might as well pack up and go home. We have to work for a better world. We have to try to better our conditions, in spite of those troglodytes amongst us who have their heads buried in the sand. I do not know how many people here are making money out of the nuclear power industry but the way that honourable senators on the Liberal side were talking there must be plenty. They do have rather closed minds on the issue.

The Laborials-members of the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia-have displayed their usual ignorance of the issue. Instead of debating the issue they descend to personal vilification. We can always tell when either they do not understand or they feel that they have lost the argument, because then they start abusing the Australian Democrats. Senator Collard, who spoke for the Opposition, is not in his seat, so he will have to be silent. He tried to blind us with science. I do not know whether he was reading something-it sounded as though he was-out of a text book. He obviously did not understand it, nor did he interpret it for us, except to say: `Science is wonderful. Gee whiz, isn't technology grand? After all, we can only get one kilowatt of power from a square metre of a solar collector, therefore we cannot ever count on the sun and we must continue along the same path that we are going on'. That is a simplification of what he said but his was a very simple argument.

At this moment President Reagan and his friends are in Japan conferring about two things-nukes and terrorism. Actually, they are one and the same thing. At the moment, through nuclear power, international terrorism is being being escalated far beyond anything that Gaddafi had ever thought of. Nuclear reactors around the earth are spreading radiation-at this very moment one is spreading radiation which has already extended from Spain to Japan and ultimately will reach Australia. If that is not terrorism, what is?

Nuclear power leads not only to terrorism but also to the necessity to protect nuclear power plants from terrorism, to totalitarian governments and to totalitarian methods. All people who operate nuclear reactors behave in a totalitarian manner. They control the flow of information to the people. They allow no dissent against their operations. I would like to talk about that. There is no essential difference from country to country, east to west, in the reaction of government officials to their own nuclear reactors. The United States of America Nuclear Regulatory Commission said:
The probability of a major nuclear catastrophe was equivalent to the probability of a meteorite striking a major city.
A newspaper article reporting on the Russian plant states:
The Chernobyl nuclear power plant was hailed by an official Soviet magazine in February as being a model of safety.
The article continues:
The odds of a meltdown are one in 10,000 years. The plants have safe and reliable controls that are protected from any breakdown with three safety lines . . .

Basically, members of the Liberal Party have been saying that these plants are absolutely safe. We see that they are not. Let us go back in history and see what actually has happened to the nuclear power industry. On 7 October 1957 at Windscale, a graphite moderated reactor like Chernobyl, fuel rods melted during a Wigner release. This may be what happened at Chernobyl. The reactor has to be run at a fairly high temperature to cause the graphite core to lose some of its energy. Interestingly enough, Lucas Heights also has in it the same carbon as Chernobyl, or Windscale for that matter. The point I would like to make here though is that no warning was given to the public by Windscale. A public information spokesman for Windscale made a brief and cryptic statement. He said:

There was not a large amount of radioactivity released. The amount was not hazardous and, in fact, it was carried out to sea by the wind. There has been no injury to any person. There is no danger of the reactor's exploding.
In fact, the radioactivity was not being carried out to sea by the wind, nor had it ceased to be a concern, as the announcement implied. It was coming down the coast, over land.

It ultimately spread all over England and parts of Europe. Yet the British Government-I am sure our Liberal friends here would not like to say it is a totalitarian government-still made this rather totalitarian statement.

What about the statement that no one has ever been hurt in a nuclear reactor accident? What about the SL-1? In Idaho Falls in America on 3 January 1961 the SL-1 exploded and killed three people. One person was standing on top of the reactor at the time. A control rod went through his groin and out through his shoulder and pinned him to the roof of the containment vessel. The other two people died of radiation poisoning immediately. They were so radioactive--

TALK.START.PARA: —What was his name?

—I can give the honourable senator his name later if he wishes it. They were so radioactive that their heads and hands had to be buried as radioactive waste. Yet the nuclear industry, sponsored by our Liberal friends, states that there has never been a fatal accident. What about the Fermi reactor? We have heard a little about the Fermi reactor. It was the bright hope of American nuclear technology; a fast breeder reactor and the best that there was. On 5 October 1966 it had a melt-down on start-up. This was impossible; it was incredible. People said that it could not happen; it would be one chance in a billion. The automatic devices failed. People said it was impossible, but they failed. They had to scram the reactor manually, by hand. They said that that would never happen. There was a danger from a secondary explosion from a sodium coolant, or a uranium explosion-it was a fast breeder reactor. This reactor was within 30 miles of the city of Detroit, which had a population of some two million. Did those in authority notify anybody?

SPEECH.PARA: There is an excellent book-I recommend it to all honourable senators-which reads like a novel and I think honourable senators could understand it. It is called We Almost Lost Detroit. That quotation is from an engineer at the plant who said: `Oops, we almost lost Detroit'. One phone call was made. It was made to a sheriff in the local area informing him that something was wrong with the Enrico Fermi atomic power plant, that the situation would be clarified, and that he would be called back. He never was called back. No news of the accident had been broadcast that afternoon or evening but the power plant made it a point to call the local paper to give out a brief, but very ambiguous, statement to appear in the paper the next morning. It mentioned nothing about any fuel melting. It merely stated that the radioactivity level of the argon gas was observed to rise substantially. Yet that reactor was out of control. It was so out of control that when it was finally got under control 52 hours later nothing could be done with it. The plant was decommissioned and it has never operated since.

There was a more recent accident at Three Mile Island. Once again we had no notification from the officials, yet 20 per cent of the core of Three Mile Island melted. The authorities refused to evacuate the residents. When the people of Philadelphia in Pennsylvania were asked whether they believed the statement about Three Mile Island, 66 per cent would not agree with our troglodyte friends from the Laborials; they did not believe the Atomic Energy Commission at all.

These accidents go on and on. Can we expect technology to come to our rescue? Many honourable senators seem to worship technology. I direct honourable senators' attention to the most highly developed technology in the United States today-the space effort. On 28 January we had a very unfortunate disaster. Seven astronauts were killed when the Challenger shuttle blew up. On 18 April this year a Titan 34D blew up at Vandenberg. Yesterday a Delta with a geo-7 weather satellite, which would have given us weather data in Australia, blew up at Cape Canaveral. If the Americans cannot get this technology to work after as much effort as they have put into it and after spending more billions of dollars than have gone into even the nuclear power industry, how can honourable senators believe that they can ever get an industry which has to be 100 per cent foolproof? The nuclear industry has to be 100 per cent foolproof, not 99.999 per cent. It can tolerate no human error. How can this possibly happen? It cannot happen.

One of the big problems we have in Australia is that we have a nuclear reactor. It is no use saying that we do not have one; we do, and it is in Sydney. The Lucas Heights reactor has a two-foot thick wall of graphite surrounding the fuel assembly. It is a neutron reflector which causes neutrons to be bounced back into the fission process, thus assisting in sustaining the reaction. As Senator Chipp has said, the Vice-President of Stone and Webster, which builds nuclear power plants, said that any reactor that has graphite is susceptible to a graphite fire. We should immediately demand a study of the likelihood of an uncontained meltdown at Lucas Heights in the light of the Chernobyl disaster. We should also decommission that reactor. The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, has said in the Senate:

The studies demonstrate that in the unlikely event of such an accident the existing HIFAR safety systems, in conjunction with the 1.6 kilometre buffer zone around the HIFAR reactor, would provide a very high level of protection to members of the public.

A 1.6 kilometre distance between the reactor and population centres! The radiation from Chernobyl has extended from Spain to Japan. How is that 1.6 kilometres away? If I lived within 1.6 kilometres of Lucas Heights, in spite of my friends in the Senate, I would migrate to Tasmania immediately.
What about Australian uranium? We have heard that it is not used in Russia. Of course it is. Senator Gareth Evans has stated:

What is already well known and on record is that all-in all-out does not necessarily mean that every single atom and molecule that goes in with an Australian flag sticking on it like a toothpick in an olive is the same atom or molecule that actually comes out again.

Of course it is not. We send uranium in, it goes into the pool of uranium hexafluoride which is being enriched by the Russians, and we get some out. Mostly what we get out is Russian uranium. The Australian uranium stays in the system; it is used in nuclear weapons; it is used in power plants-and no one in this chamber can deny that.

The final bottom line is that nuclear power is so unsafe that no insurance company will protect a policy-holder in case of a nuclear disaster. In the remaining minute left to me, I refer to my motor vehicle insurance policy. I ask all people in Australia including all honourable senators to look at the back of their policies. They will find a nuclear exclusion which says that a person is not covered in case of any type of any nuclear reactor accident or any kind of ionising radiation. This is the fog cutter. If the friends of honourable senators opposite in private enterprise will not support the nuclear power industry, why should we? I support the original motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to a lot of rhetoric about this subject today, not the least being from Senator Sanders. I also listened to Senator Chipp, who spoke earlier. I get used to Senator Chipp's emotional outbursts on this subject.
—Particularly on a broadcast day.

—Yes, that is usually the time the honourable senator picks to rant and rave about the inadequacy of the Government and the Opposition on these matters. I must say that I was quite impressed with the way that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, responded to him. He pointed out that the Australian Democrats are prone to this sort of emotive, uneducated--
—It is just as well that we are, isn't it?

—The honourable senator ought to think about his future and wonder about alternative energy sources. It is not surprising that the Australian Democrats have once more generated an hysterical and dishonest motion relating to the peaceful--
—Do you mean hysterical or historical?
—And historical. I will talk about the history of the matter in a moment.
—If you are going to speak at 9 o'clock, you must dine carefully.
—Let me express my sorrow with respect to the two people who--
—Do you get my drift? Particularly when you are talking about the future of the world; you have a serious dinner.

—I see. Let me reply to the honourable senator. First of all, in expressing sorrow about the death of two or three people as a result of the Chernobyl accident, I find it difficult to contain my anger at the childish outburst from the anti-nuclear industries in Australia and abroad. In historical terms they resemble those British citizens who, in the nineteenth century, hysterically demanded that railways be banned because of the first railway accident and the effect of the noise of railways on the farmyards. There is much concern in the world over the accident at Chernobyl. It is possible that a serious nuclear power station accident in one country could adversely affect not only its own citizens but also those in adjacent countries, and not only its own environment but that of adjacent countries as well. For this reason Australia should be doing its utmost to persuade the Soviet Union and other communist nations to adhere to the nuclear safety codes and guides program which is known, as I understand it, as the NUSS program.
—You are not reading that, are you?

—I am like the honourable senator: I try to put a few facts before the Senate. The International Atomic Energy Agency is concerned with the development and peaceful utilisation of atomic energy. The IAEA has concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are no factors related to safety that would limit the use and development of nuclear power, safety could be improved by giving more attention to the relationship between the operator and the plant and by devoting more effort to developing equipment and training personnel to ensure that small accidents did not turn into more serious ones.

As yet we do not know either what happened at Chernobyl or how serious the accident has been. This is due to the extraordinary secrecy of the Soviet Government, in regard to both its own citizens and the international community. We have been told that the accident was due to human error. That may be true. Nonetheless, we know that Soviet technology in this field is both outdated and below the standards demanded in the West. Despite the NUSS program, which should be concerned with the establishment of internationally acceptable safety standards, codes and guides in connection with the regulation, siting, design, construction and operation of research reactors, nuclear power stations and other nuclear facilities, the Soviet Union has chosen to ignore these standards and has persisted with technology rejected by the West in the early post-war years.

The Soviet Union, probably working on plans supplied to it by spies from Western nations, adapted the plutonium production reactors used at Hanford in the far west of the United States of America during the war. In 1945 Britain rejected that style of reactor for its Calder Hall facility. I think Senator Chipp referred earlier to Windscale. Of course Calder Hall was the initial power station developed in the United Kingdom but of course, as I said, the Hanford type of plant was rejected as being too risky for the United Kingdom. However, the Soviet Union used the Hanford model and its first military reactors were in operation in the Urals in 1947. By June 1954 it had built a five-megawatt Obninsk reactor and coupled it into the Moscow grid a year before Britain connected up the Calder Hall facility-which of course was much bigger but also much different and safer as far as technological development was concerned. Over the next three decades the Soviet Union pushed ahead very quickly, but without the constant urge to improve technology which the profit and safety motives of the West ensured. Because of this the Kremlin has forbidden its engineers and scientists to discuss nuclear power generation with their Western counterparts.

It is interesting that despite the findings of nationally and internationally respected authorities the Socialist Left, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and I believe the Australian Democrats have opposed the nuclear industry in Australia. In so doing-I exclude the Democrats from this-they have really extolled the virtues of the nuclear industry in the Soviet Union. I do not think the Democrats have done that, but they have reserved all their hysterical venom and doomsday rhetoric for the nuclear industry in the west.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the world. I made that point.

—I excused the honourable senator from supporting the Soviet Union. I would like him to recognise that. But the Socialist Left, that wonderful euphemism for Australian communists, has eulogised Soviet nuclear power generation and to demonstrate that point I quote from a well known Left extremist, the one time President of the Pro-Soviet Socialist Party of Australia, Pat Clancy. At the 1979 South Pacific and Asian Trade Unity Conference he stated that nuclear energy can be used for peaceful purposes but he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It depends on who uses it. In Australia we are opposed to it. It must be publicly owned. Whenever it is in private hands and for profit, it poses great danger. We support its use in socialist countries but not in Australia. In socialist countries it is necessary and safe for the generation of electricity. There has never been a nuclear accident in the USSR and there never will be. Waste is dumped where there is no damage to other countries.

The truth has never moved Pat Clancy or his colleagues before-not the Iron Curtain, not East Germany, not Czechoslovakia, not Hungary, not Poland and not Afghanistan. The reality of this tyranny has never affected their slavish support for the Soviet Union; nor will Shermanville.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shermanville? Where is that?
—It is in Russia, isn't it? Hasn't the honourable senator heard of Chernobyl?
—Shermanville; no.

—That displays the honourable senator's ignorance of the subject. The Democrats persist in the myths surrounding the Three Mile Island accident. For the benefit of that old rustler who spoke before me and who is now riding the range in Tasmania, I will provide a little education. Let me quote Professor Leslie Kemeny, senior lecturer in nuclear engineering at the University of New South Wales. The professor put it in words that even Senator Sanders should be able to understand. The professor stated that, had the good senator stood stark naked at the boundary fence of Three Mile Island throughout the period of emergency, the senator should have received less radiation than if he had had a tooth X-rayed. I hate to think of the effect on the beasts grazing in the nearby fields of the sight of Senator Sanders standing there naked, but in any case the honourable senator would not have had a hair of his body damaged.

SPEECH.PARA: People who call for the abolition of the nuclear powered generation of electricity fail to recognise that it is an infinitely safer method than coal fired generation. We have over 3,000 years operating experience of coal fired generation-and it produces 15 per cent of the world's electricity. In some countries over 50 per cent is produced by nuclear fission. I suggest that what we ought to be doing with respect to the catastrophe that occurred in Russia is calling for some sort of international nuclear disaster task force. I think that would be something to which even the Democrats would subscribe. I made a comment about that recently, and said that there ought to be an international scientific, engineering and medical task force with appropriate lines of communication between countries. That should be established within the International Atomic Energy Agency to cater for the possibility of future accidents, particularly in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, where there is a significant number of nuclear power stations which have inferior standards compared with Western installations. People who call for the abolition of nuclear power generation fail to realise that it could be an infinitely safer method than coal fired power stations.

TALK.START.PARA: —A safer way to die.

—Senator Chipp does not realise the problems associated with coal-fired power stations, the emissions from which are killing the forests of Germany and fish in the lakes of Canada and the United States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing Senator Chipp's motion-a rather emotional one, as it has turned out. However, I do not think the House has discussed the pros and cons of the nuclear industry. Indeed, I do not think that topic has ever been discussed in this country and it is sad that that has not happened. We must look at the history of mankind. When man first made a fire and controlled that fire, he was on the way to progress. Man improved his way of providing for himself and his family in food, clothing and shelter. So it has gone on through thousands of years to this day. The world's population today is approximately six billion. In my lifetime man has come from the use of animal and manpower to the present situation, where everything is automated. The amount of fuel burned in the world today is astronomical. If the fires were to go out in the world today, millions of people would die of starvation because we simply could not produce the food and the things that are necessary for life to exist. Those things are impossible to produce unless we have the fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: I and every other member of the Senate realise that nuclear power is dangerous, certainly if used by irresponsible people. A few short years ago in the 1980s the price of oil jumped to $43 a barrel when at one time it had been $5 a barrel. That price rise was disastrous for many countries. A country such as Australia does not need atomic fuel, we have plenty of oil and coal, but many countries such as Taiwan, Korea and Japan have people rather than resources. Those countries have to import raw materials in order to manufacture articles and then to export them. Are we to say that those people should not live? If they had not built atomic power stations, they could not have afforded to pay the price of oil. Consequently many people in those countries would have died of starvation; there would have been nothing left for them. They must import raw materials, manufacture them and export to live. That is true of many countries in this world.

It is easy to say that we should not use this material, that we should not mine it or export it. If that were the case, we would bar ourselves from every international forum. Such an attitude is not good enough. We have a say, and I believe that the attitude of the Liberal Party and the Labor Party is aimed at improving conditions in the world and making it safer. It is good that we take that view. Nothing is perfect. Would the motor car ever have been invented if it had been realised that millions of people would have been killed as a result of the invention of that vehicle? There is a risk in everything we do, but today the world must provide for its billions of people and risks will have to be taken if those people are to survive. Who are we to say who will live and who will die? That is not the way society should be run.

I agree with Senator Chipp and some of the Australian Democrats that we should endeavour to make the world safer. If an oil well blows out, the Red Adairs of this world will go to the scene and put out the fire. In the nuclear industry scientists and skilled people should be available at a moment's notice to go anywhere in the world to overcome problems in that industry. To say that such forms of energy should be completely done away with is not facing the reality of the world as it is today.

I consider that nuclear fuel has a future and is yet only in its infancy. I believe that the world will need nuclear fuel and we have to learn to understand it. Most certainly it can be improved. Man has been negligent in the past with the amount of waste generated by many products. Not all societies, including our own, have always been responsible in cleaning up wastes correctly and safely. But man is learning. We realise, as does every other country, that we must be more responsible, but it is a learning process. It is ridiculous to say that everything can be done all at once. Nobody wants to see anyone die or live in misery. We are all trying to improve life on this earth and to be responsible.

It is no use taking the view that because there has been an accident we should stop mining uranium. It is no good saying that we must take that course because the problem has not been solved. One does not solve problems overnight. I believe that the world will evolve a system involving a safe form of energy. Perhaps that will happen in 50 years time. It may not involve nuclear power; it may involve the fission system. I do not know and I do not think anybody else in this place would dare to say what it will be. It is only as a result of experimentation and trying to improve things that we can advance mankind as a species. The world will run out of coal and oil. As I have said, if the fires ever go out mankind is in desperate trouble.

It is wrong to alarm people by saying, for example, that the atomic experimental establishment at Lucas Heights is a danger. I have visited that establishment, I have gone through it, and what Senator Gareth Evans said about it is quite correct. It is of no danger. It is not like the nuclear power station in Russia that has blown up. It is a disgrace that the Russians have not allowed scientists into that country to analyse and look at their power stations or take advice as to the advanced designs that have been developed in the West. I suppose that is the Soviet's business, but obviously something is wrong when a station of that type blows up and spreads danger throughout surrounding countries. Restraints should be placed on countries with nuclear power stations. Standards should be set down throughout the world. We do not live in an isolated community. We all share the world's wastes and all nations should be more respon- sible. It is a matter for international forums to decide and we are gradually pulling the threads together. Senator Gareth Evans moved an amendment to Senator Chipp's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose we could close down the coal mines in Gippsland if we had nuclear power. What would you think about that?

—The coal mines probably would be closed down. We on this side of the Senate will be supporting Senator Gareth Evans's amendment and also the amendment moved by Senator Durack. They are sensible amendments. I said previously that the world's population was about six billion people. I have just been advised that it is 4.7 billion people.
—That was pretty close, anyway.

—It will not be very long before it is six billion people. In the last 10 years the world's population has almost doubled. There will be problems as the world's population increases. Most certainly there will be a need to use more and more nuclear power. It has been said that nuclear ships are dangerous. If the price of oil in the early 1980s had been sustained there would now be nuclear-powered cargo ships all around the world. I asked the Deputy Premier of Tasmania what his Government would have done if a nuclear-powered cargo ship had pulled in to Hobart to take away goods Tasmania wanted to sell on the world market. Most certainly Tasmania would have loaded those goods into that nuclear-powered ship.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no use people standing alone, saying: `We will not tolerate nuclear-powered ships'. It is unfortunate that the world has so many atomic weapons. Everyone would agree with that. That question will have to be resolved. I hope that the world powers reduce their nuclear armaments. Every honourable senator in this place would hope so. But it cannot and will not be done overnight. There will be a lot of international discussion on the matter. Australia has decided that we will not go into the field of providing nuclear weapons. We have tried to impress upon all our neighbours the need not to do so. We have instigated nuclear-free zones in the Pacific. I hope that my Party also looks at the possibility of creating nuclear-free zones in the Indian Ocean. I think that is the way for this country to go.

It is our duty to try to persuade countries not to develop nuclear weapons. That is the responsible way. We safeguard all the uranium we export. We make sure that it is not used in the production of nuclear weapons. We are represented on international bodies. We are not afraid to come out and say that there should be better uses of nuclear material and stricter controls, so that the type of tragedy that has happened in Russia does not happen again. It is a learning curve. It will take many years, I suppose, for things to become perfect, if that is possible.

All of us must try for perfection in this field. Everyone wants to see a better world, a world free of pollution. That is everyone's responsibility. It is no use doing what the Democrats are doing. They are simply going inside and closing the door. We live in the world of reality. It is no use running away from that. Some people support the Democrats' opinions, but I do not think the majority of those people realise that what the Democrats propose is an impossibility. If oil became so expensive again, would the Democrats advocate that millions of people should lose their jobs simply because the generation of electricity was too costly? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today a long motion moved by Senator Chipp deploring in essence the consequences of the accident at Chernobyl and putting forward a number of resolutions with regard to Australia's behaviour in the future. A couple of amendments to the motion have been moved by the Government and the Opposition, in connivance with each other I suggest, aimed at downplaying not only the effects of the accident but also any involvement Australia may have in the world nuclear energy industry. We have heard allegations by a number of honourable senators tonight that some people are being too emotional about this matter and that we ought to get our feet back on the ground, presumably. Several suggestions have been made that we get back in touch with reality. Since when has emotion necessarily been divorced from reality? I would have thought that in this case quite the reverse was needed.
—Just link it with a bit of reason and it will be all right. Emotion is fine, but link it with some reason. Don't go on a solo flight.

—Listening to Senator Evans's speech, I was struck by the lack of conviction, shall we say, in his voice. I suggest that the anger and desperation that were evident were due more to the fact that he knew he was wrong than that he believed we were wrong. Why should I and other people in this chamber and elsewhere not become emotional when discussing the reality of a nuclear disaster such as occurred at Chernobyl, when debating the dangers of massive radiation and when criticising the Russians for failing to warn neighbouring countries and for not evacuating their own people? Why should we remain unemotional when we consider the very real, long term damage done to the world and its inhabitants by a nuclear catastrophe of the sort that occurred at Chernobyl?

SPEECH.PARA: I find it outrageous that the Government would like to stop debate on this matter on the grounds that, as Senator Evans said in his rather extraordinary speech, it might alarm people. One presumes that that was exactly the reason the Russians did not bother to tell anyone in the vicinity of the disaster that the area was threatened by radiation. They did not want to alarm people. So we hide the information from people and keep them in the dark, glowing though it may be, in the hope, presumably, that they will not get worried and may not notice the ill effects of the disaster that occurred. I wonder whether Senator Evans and others thought that the article in the Weekend Australian was either unnecessarily alarmist or excessively emotional. The Weekend Australian ran a full page article entitled `Chernobyl-An accident waiting to happen'. The lead in to the article stated:
. . . the frantic race forward of Soviet nuclear expansion has time and again been at the expense of safety.
The article states:
Chernobyl, or somewhere like it-was always an `accident' . . .
Quotation marks are used around the word `accident' as it was clearly something which could have been prevented had people behaved responsibly:

Chernobyl-or somewhere like it-was always an `accident' waiting to happen inside the Soviet Union, where unfettered by a democratic parliament and unbridled by the straps of public opinion, successive Kremlin leaders have thrown aside all semblance of scientific restraint to hurl their country into industrial line with the capitalist world.

The fact that the reactor was, as other speakers have mentioned, an outmoded piece of equipment does not lessen the fact that the disaster occurred. It means only that where there is similar equipment the disaster could happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can happen to any of them.

—As Senator Sanders just said, it can happen to any of them, outmoded or not. As he said a little while ago, the high technology of which the United States is so proud certainly has not stopped its having its fair share of space technology disasters. In fact the 12.30 p.m. Australian Broadcasting Corporation news yesterday reported a statement from a committee of United States scientists which has catalogued in the vicinity of 3,000 nuclear mishaps of all kinds last year alone. This is a 20 per cent increase on the previous year and is surely something about which we ought to get emotional since, presumably, if it comes from a committee of United States scientists, it is based on reality.

SPEECH.PARA: In a report commissioned by the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission in 1982, it was estimated that the risk factor had increased fortyfold since 1975-another thing that I would expect people in our situation to get emotional about. Yet this Government says that nuclear energy is safe. When there is an accident, it says that it is safe and that there are no health risks. Indeed, it persists in justifying its part in the whole nuclear cycle by, on the one hand, arguing that it is being responsible about the sale of Australian uranium and then admitting that it sends it to countries such as Finland, which uses Russian equipment for enrichment and reprocessing programs, and, furthermore, sells it through the European Atomic Energy Community.

Throughout the last week we have heard constant claims that the increased radiation levels outside the immediate accident zone at Chernobyl are safe and carry no health risks. Despite those stock reassurances from the Soviet Union, seemingly backed up by the Australian Government or some elements of it, a few governments in the more immediate vicinity are not quite so sanguine about what is happening. A number of countries have been issuing iodine tablets to children, instructing those same children to stay indoors, suggesting protective measures for pregnant women, impounding farm products and quarantining farm animals. Presumably, they have done this with good reason.

Again, the Weekend Australian has indicated quite graphically the radioactive elements that are around as a result of the Chernobyl accident, and the effects that they can have on the food chain. It talks about entry of fallout into the food chain and the fact that solid radioactive contaminants fall into bodies of water and onto the soil. Anybody who has ever taken any interest in agriculture will know that they are then taken up by plants and animals, becoming more concentrated as they move up the ladder of organisms in the food chain. As far as human beings are concerned, they move to target organs, delivering large close range doses of radiation. The specific chemicals involved in something like the Chernobyl disaster-iodine, caesium, krypton, strontium and so on-are the sorts of things that, when they come into contact with the human body, affect everything from muscles through to thyroids, lungs, bones, kidneys and ovaries. But it is suggested in this place that that is something about which we should not get particularly emotional.

The fact is that the scientific community knows that there is no safe level of radiation. Health authorities set what they determine to be safe levels to produce an acceptable level of damage to our species, knowing in fact that damage is inevitable and that they are unwilling to do anything about it. Arguments rage about how many people have so far died as a result of the Chernobyl tragedy. Of course, what is being ignored is the much greater toll that will be exacted in the long term. There have been credible estimates of anything up to 10,000 cancer deaths in the vicinity of Chernobyl over the next 10 years and up to 4,000 cancer deaths in Sweden over the next 30 years.

Of course, as far as the Soviet Union is concerned, secrecy is paramount. Information on this accident is hard to get, as has been the case with past accidents. But one thing we do know is that the Chernobyl disaster will inevitably lead to shorter life spans for those in the immediate and associated vicinities, genetic damage to children exposed to radiation-both children who are alive now and those who have yet to be born-and the insidious effects of countless mild mutations in successive generations. The Chernobyl accident has in effect added to a growing stock of radioactive pollution from nuclear weapons use and testing, nuclear power plant accidents and radioactive waste discharges, all of which have been detailed in contributions made earlier today by Senator Chipp, Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine.

What makes all of this worse is the official reluctance, both in the Soviet Union and in other countries, to investigate and publicise the health effects of even the worse nuclear accidents. It is almost as though we have regarded this as something akin to a car accident; that is, that for the sake of expediency a certain level of loss is regarded as acceptable, disregarding the fact that, while a car accident may have immediate and tragic effects, disasters such as happened at Chernobyl, at Windscale, at Three Mile Island and elsewhere have ongoing effects.

The survival of our species-indeed the survival of a number of species on this planet-cannot simply be guaranteed as radiation levels rise. It is timely, therefore, for us to consider the most serious long term source of radioactive pollution; that is, nuclear waste disposal. We need to ask ourselves what guarantees we can give to successive generations that the Chernobyl, Three Mile Island or Windscale disasters will not come to them unawares through ground water and the food chain; that is, by the sort of insidious poisoning and pollution that the Weekend Australian so graphically described.

Of course, the problems of waste disposal are enormous. Firstly, there is the long term stability of the site; the waste can be predicted only by using not necessarily accurate mathematical models. Like Star Wars programs and various other pieces of new world high technology, the only proof of this particular pudding will be in the eating, by which time it will be too late to do anything about the recipe. Chernobyl and the Challenger disaster show us the fallibility of complex technology. They ought, if anything, to stop us from becoming either apathetic or smug about what we do in science and technology these days.

The implications for Australia are quite severe. First of all, we contribute to the world nuclear cycle by selling our uranium to practically anybody who is prepared to buy it. Secondly, the continued export of uranium is fuelling an unsolved and probably insoluble waste problem for the countries to which we sell it. I suggest that we should take a leaf from the book of those States of the United States of America which have banned further nuclear development until the whole waste problem issue is sorted out. In human terms alone the nuclear industry has left us with a cost the brunt of which will be borne not by us but by future generations. If we do not learn the lessons of Chernobyl, if we do not realise that this cost is inevitable and too high, we will be looking at the death of our species. It is not good enough to assume that because we, the current generation, may not be affected, we do not need to do anything. We prattle on in this chamber about the importance of families and the way that children are our most valuable natural resource. This debate has indicated quite clearly that most people in this chamber view that as mere rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate and all Australians deplore the Chernobyl accident. Our sympathy goes to the families of those Russians who lost their lives and to those who have suffered physical injury. Regrettably, some of that physical injury will not be apparent for some years to come. That having been said however, the points have to be made, firstly, that this accident should never have happened; secondly, it was clearly preventable; and the third damning indictment of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is its secrecy. The accident became known only when it could not be kept quiet. It is not a matter of the Soviets keeping their own policies to themselves, but what we had demonstrated once more was the Soviet's lack of concern for humanity, because the lives and safety of quite a few citizens of Europe were put at risk by the secrecy of the Soviets. The governments of the European countries were denied the opportunity of taking any preventative public health measures that could have been taken had they been warned at the time, as they should have been, by the Soviets.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has before it a notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Chipp on behalf of the Australian Democrats. That motion is unbalanced, inaccurate and highly emotional. The kindest thing that can be said about it is that is based on ignorance or is the consequence of panic. We have a very serious problem and it needs some sober analysis, not hysteria. The motion reads:
That the Senate notes-
(a) the implications to life and the planet of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster in the Soviet Union;
We support that. The second point is:
(b) the possible contribution to this disaster by Australia in exporting uranium;
That is a transparently dishonest statement. As Senator Gareth Evans said, we have never done that and we have no intention of doing it. The third point of the motion reads:
(c) the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;

That is a possibility. We admit that it might happen, but it is not very likely. We recognise the possibility that it could happen and that we need some constructive moves, not the moves of fear or panic or running away from the problem, which is the solution the Democrats have given us. The fourth part of the motion reads:
(d) the possible eventual danger to Australia in the event of any disasters;

Again there is no fear that Australia will be affected by this accident at Chernobyl, as anyone with any scientific knowledge or any intelligence at all would know from reading the reports. The last part of the motion states:
(e) the need to close all uranium mines in Australia.

That is absolutely pointless. People who wish to get uranium can get it from sea-water, as the British and the Japanese demonstrated over 30 years ago. Soviet Russia possesses the greatest deposits of uranium in the world, and Australia will gain nothing at all from closing down the resources we have and not making them available to the world.

Senator Chipp's speech was highly emotional and devoid of any scientific fact or analysis. He said in his speech that he was trying to influence the far left of the Australian Labor Party at the convention to be held in July. What a noble motion to bring before the Senate! A member of one party trying to influence the internal politics of another. It was really a matter of theatre. When Senator Chipp had finished his histrionic display just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, he turned around to Senators Siddons, Sanders and Vigor, flung down his glasses on the desk and said words to the effect: `Next time I speak show a bit of enthusiasm', really making a mockery of this chamber.

Senator Gareth Evans gave us one of his best speeches; the most responsible speech I have heard him give in this chamber. He fully exercised the judgment that the Labor Party has shown in him by elevating him to the high office of a Minister of the Crown. He handled a matter of great importance to this country with both responsibility and distinction, as did Senator Durack and Senator Collard when they spoke. Senator Vallentine, of course, contributed her usual brand of hysteria, and Senator Sanders made his usual uninformed and irrelevant contribution.

All of this is about the supply of energy, and the most common source of energy is electrical energy. The human race happens to need quite a lot of it and will need a lot more in the future. Some of this energy comes from sources that do not have a thermal origin, such as hydroelectricity, and a very small amount from wind power. The developments along these lines are necessarily very limited. We derive most of our power from heat, through combustion in some source or other, either by burning solids such as coal or wood or burning hydrocarbon liquid fuels such as oils. Coal provides the major part of the electrical energy used by the human race, and people tend to think that it is quite harmless. But tens of thousands of miners have been killed in winning that coal from the ground, and the number of people killed will go on increasing in the future because mining is inherently a high risk operation.

If we burn coal and oil we contribute very much to pollution. It is one of the great inconsistencies of this place that the friends of the greenies and the other illogical people in the community, the Democrats, talk about pollution and preserving the environment, on the one hand, yet they will not use the environmentally clean fuel which is nuclear energy. When anything is burned it is an inevitable consequence of combustion that we end up with carbon dioxide and water. Carbon dioxide builds up in the atmosphere, and the carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere has gone up considerably in the past 50 years. This contributes to the well known greenhouse effect; as it goes into the upper layer of the atmosphere it reduces the ability of the ozone layer to inhibit the sun's rays, which increases the temperature of the atmosphere. The other side is that most fuels, whether liquid hydrocarbons such as oils, or coals, contain sulphur and the combustion releases sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere which reacts with water to form sulphurous acid. This is the origin of the acid rain which is having such a devastating effect on the forests of Europe. In other words, there is no clean and safe source of power through thermal processes.

I want to link this with the present energy consumption of the world. Seventy-seven per cent of the world's energy is used by 28 per cent of the world's population. I do not believe that we can hold those ratios. Furthermore, I argue very strongly that we have a moral obligation to spread 100 per cent of the world's energy around 100 per cent of the world's population. If we are to do that we will have to have a threefold increase in the amount of electrical energy developed. If we do that by burning coal and oil, the world will become quite uninhabitable. This leads to the inevitability of nuclear power. Already some countries generate as much as 50 per cent of their electrical energy from nuclear power. It is not a matter, as some of the interjectors have said, of conservation and the rest of it. There is a limit to how much can be conserved. We have to develop, and the use of energy is expanding as industrialisation takes place. A lot of countries simply do not have the option of having their own coal fields or oil fields to provide this energy, so inevitably we come to the fact that nuclear power is a fact of life. It might be a minor part of power generation, but it is something we have and the responsibility is on all of us collectively to manage it responsibly.

I link this to the penultimate part of the Australian Democrats' motion, because in many ways this is the most irresponsible part of all. Section (e) deals with the need to close all uranium mines in Australia. The Australian Science and Technology Council, which is the ultimate scientific authority in this country, reported to the Government about a year ago that Australia should be involved in all phases of the nuclear fuel cycle. We in the Liberal and National parties support that position completely. The ASTEC report showed that between 1984 and 1996 a market exists for 130,000 to 170,000 tonnes of uranium for which contracts have not already been signed. The inference from that is that Australia with its cheaply produced uranium oxide should move in and capture the major part of those markets.

It is not only the export earnings which are so important to us here but also the legal consequences of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, as Senator Gareth Evans said tonight, is something that puts an obligation on us not to buy nuclear weapons-we do not hold them-but also puts an obligation on those suppliers of nuclear fuel to meet the market and supply under very strict safeguards the demands of those countries that need uranium for their nuclear power. Australia, under the Fraser Government, signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. It has been one of the greatest stabilising influences on the whole of the nuclear industry that we have had. The obligation is very clearly on us legally to supply uranium to those countries which conform to our safeguards.

It is very clear from what has been said by Senator Chipp, Senator Vallentine and Senator Sanders that either they cannot differentiate between nuclear weapons and nuclear power or they are deliberately trying to confuse the two and make them synonymous in the mind of the Australian public. There is a very big difference between nuclear power and nuclear weapons. While all of us want to see a rundown in nuclear weapons in the world and hopefully the elimination of them, not too many of us want to see the elimination of nuclear power because we see nuclear power as the only way to meet cleanly the electrical energy our civilisation needs in the foreseeable future.
In conclusion, I will deal with the amendments to the motion. Under Senator Durack's first amendment, paragraph (b) would read:
that the policies of successive governments mean Australia makes no contribution to the USSR's supply of nuclear material;
That is perfectly true. That is the amendment which those of us in the Liberal Party and the National Party will be supporting. Paragraph (c) of the Government's amendment reads:

that the Australian Government will pursue all opportunities for further strengthening of international co-operation in the area of mandatory international safety standards to minimise the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;
That is a common-sense and responsible amendment moved by the Government which we will be supporting. Paragraph (d) reads:

that while there is no cause for concern that fall-out from the Chernobyl accident will present any hazard in Australia, it is essential that this country continue to maintain adequate systems to monitor levels from all sources of radioactivity which may present a public health hazard;
Again, that is a responsible notion by the Government which we will be supporting. Paragraph (e) reads:

the Government's resolve to pursue in international forums the establishment of a mandatory system requiring nations in which similar accidents occur to notify other countries which may be affected, at the first opportunity and in the fullest possible detail.

That is very necessary in the light of the secrecy of the Soviets. It is absolutely inhuman where there is a disaster which affects other people not to publicly advise those people as rapidly as possible, particularly when lives are at stake. The final amendment moved by Senator Durack which we will be supporting is to add the following words after proposed new paragraph (e):

, and in the opinion of the Senate the Government should establish a task force of suitably qualified independent experts to advise the Government in carrying out the terms of this resolution and to report their advice to the Parliament.
This gives effect to what is very clearly in this debate the intention of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1964 a United States SNAP 19, that is the system for nuclear auxiliary power supply burnt up. The result of that operation was measured world-wide in 1970 and 1971. The world wide sampling determined that in the intervening years 14,000 curies of plutonium 238 from that system had been deposited. That was approximately double the amount of plutonium 238 already in the world environment. That is, from one accident alone there was a doubling of the environmental problem. It is interesting in the debate to hear the numbers being talked about of people who may or may not have suffered. The estimate that has been made of the result of that 1964 accident is 40,000 fatal lung cancers. That is a conservative estimate by the World Health Organisation. Where did that appear in the newspapers? Where did that appear in the literature? Yet we have bandied around in the Senate time and again that no one has died as a result of nuclear power accidents. The World Health Organisation has put down that accident alone as having 40,000 fatalities. That particular power plant was, in fact, a 100-watt system; an incredibly small system.
—A 100-watt? That is a light bulb.

—That is what I said, if the honourable senator does not mind listening-a 100-watt experimental system. That was in 1964. If the honourable senator would go back that far to work out what they could put up then, he would know it could only be that. That is what was caused as a result of that accident. Under the strategic defence initiative program in America contracts have been let for 100-kilowatt plants. This is supposed to be another exercise in `no problem for their human race'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the next Challenger shuttle that was to be launched after the one that was such a disaster would have had 46.7 kilos of plutonium on board. We were all lucky in many ways that the payload of the next shuttle mission was not on the one that blew up.

There has been a lot of talk about poor Russian technology. I will just run through a number of examples of situations currently occurring. For example, there is a petition filed with the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission requesting immediate proceedings to revoke the Detroit Eddison Company's operating licence for the Fermi 2 nuclear power plant located 30 miles south-east of Detroit. The required stress analyses had not been performed when design modifications were made during the final stage of construction. The Fermi 1 reactor, to which Senator Sanders referred, is shut down for repairs, and the Fermi 2 reactor has been shut down for repairs since October following a low power testing described by the NRC officials as the worst ever test which they have conducted. The NRC has identified multiple violations of requirements including five unplanned radiological emissions from the plant and the off-site transportation of radioactive resins to an unlicensed disposal source.

Another example: There was an earthquake in the vicinity of the Perry nuclear power reactor on 31 January this year that reached 0.5 on the Richter scale with an epicentre estimated to be less than 10 miles from the Perry site itself. The ground motion from that earthquake reached 0.25Gs causing the evacuation of half of the plant's work force and a declaration of a site emergency. Perry, by the way, is designed to withstand a force of only 0.15Gs.

Another example: The NRC is investigating the Cook nuclear power plant in Michigan. It has uncovered a pattern of poor management control, leading to numerous instances of personnel error, missed surveillances, lack of control over work activity and unauthorised procedures. In all, the plant is now being cited for 84 violations. It is extraordinary when one goes through the list of these investigations. Unfortunately, I do not have a chance to go through all the current NRC investigations in the 15 minutes available to me. It makes absolutely horrifying reading. Yet here we have comments such as: `We cannot have another accident. It is perfectly all right. Do not worry about it. It is the poor technology of the Russians'.

Looking at accidents which have occurred outside the United States, in France, for example according to a report just to hand, it has been discovered that the Dampierre 1,900 megawatt class new kind of steam generation plant has steam generation tube cracking on steam generators, which is in addition to the longitudinal cracks discovered in 1984. At the moment the plant is still operating, but unfortunately nobody seems to know how to cope with that problem. The Ikata power plant in Japan was implicated in the red tide phenomenon at the end of last year in which toxic substances were released resulting in the death of fish in the vicinity. That power plant has now been directly implicated and investigations are under way by the Japanese regulatory commission.

In Canada, the spent fuel storage bay at the Douglas Point power station on Lake Huron is pouring into that lake about 500 gallons of waste per day and there seems to be no way to shut it off. There were two other power plant problems in the United States last year. These are of particular interest because they are both Babcock and Wilcox reactor designs. The first problem was at the Besse-Davis plant, which shut down in June, and the second problem was at the Rancho Seco plant, which shut down on 26 December, for almost identical reasons to the operations that occurred at the Three Mile Island plant. In other words, that was not a one-off operation because they were all Babcock and Wilcox designed plants.

Another problem Senator Sanders raised-even if we do not go to the heart of what I have just been rehearsing, that is, accidental problems-is that we are establishing in this country plants which could hold the entire world hostage. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber go stark raving mad when they talk about a union holding somebody hostage. We are actually building plants which could hold the entire world hostage. I will give two examples which are probably well known to honourable senators in this place. The first example is that of the West German parliamentarian who went into the Biblis reactor in Germany with a bazooka under his coat and presented it to the director. The second is the Canadian member of parliament who went into the reactor at the Pickering plant, again with a satchel which was unchecked.

What the Democrats are saying time and again is that there is an incredibly lethal operation being developed around the world that this Government and the alternative Government seem to think is a perfectly acceptable proposition. I will briefly relate some of the problems that have occurred. The Atucha 1 reactor in Argentina was taken over by 15 guerrillas for publicity. The Fessenheim reactor sustained peripheral damage by fire following a bombing by terrorists. The Brittany reactor had its cooling water inlet damaged by Breton separatist terrorists. Basque separatists bombed the steam generator at the Lemoniz reactor. Two reactors in the Argentine were bombed. The Trojan reactor in Oregon was bombed. Unexploded bombs were found in the Ringhals reactor in Sweden, at the Point Beach reactor in Wisconsin and at the Illinois Institute of Technology reactor. Deliberately lit fires damaged the Indian Point 2 reactor in New York and worker sabotage has been reported at the Trojan reactor at Angra Dos Reis in Brazil. Quad Cities in Illinois, Preach Bottom in Pennsylvania, Fort St Vrain in Colorado, Browns Ferry in Alabama and Beaver Valley in Pennsylvania have all suffered from worker sabotage. All those plants showed enormous problems in terms of the security mechanisms which were available in the plants.

What we are looking at, of course, is a vast potential for sabotage-and enormous potential for sabotage-and in fact Colonel Gaddafi has suggested quite deliberately that there should be retaliatory operations on power plants in the West for the attacks that have been made on his country. We have to recognise that, even if we are not looking at an accidental operation, we are possibly looking at an operation where a plant could be taken over by terrorists. The security mechanisms would then work in their favour and we would be in a situation of incredible peril and enormous difficulty. It is not like terrorism on a plant, a ship or a train. We would be faced with a most enormous and horrific problem and it is a problem that unfortunately this world is going to face at some stage.

In relation to terrorism, most of the power plants around the world are designed to withstand only a small aircraft crash. It is by lucky irony, indeed, that the double containment strength at the Three Mile Island plant enabling it to contain the hydrogen explosion which occurred in 1979 was designed in that way because it was in the direct commercial flight path of low level approaches at the Harrisburg Airport. Most plants are not equipped to withstand a crash by a well laden wide-bodied aircraft. In 1975 a B52 crashed 20 miles from the Savannah River reprocessing plant, which is an example of the type of accident that could happen or the type of terrorism that may result from the idiotic politics of various people around the world.

We have to acknowledge that potential dangers exist. It is not a matter of just being emotional; it is a matter of looking at the facts and being highly emotional. The results of the Three Mile Island plant accident have not yet been estimated, and we have had some discussions on that already. It is very interesting that there is currently a court action being taken in the Supreme Court of the United States by the citizens who live in the area around that plant. The enormous amount of evidence that has been presented makes it look as though there is every likelihood of success.

In the brief time that is left, I mention that the stance of the Opposition and the Government reminds me of an item I read about a British intelligence officer who, when retiring in 1950 after 47 years of service, reminisced: `Year after year the worriers and fretters would come to me with awful predictions of the outbreak of war. I denied it each time. I was only wrong twice'. Unfortunately in this area we may be wrong only once and that may be sufficient.
