That is the way it stands.
—So tonight you are going to vote against your principles.

—A cynic's laugh is a poor exchange for any principles. Having written to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) about this matter, I await clarification of some ambiguous points. It is in the interests of Australia to have a firm written agreement with the United States, and with any other foreign power whose nuclear-powered vessels might visit us, setting out the obligations and responsibilities of each party in the event of a nuclear accident. Such a written agreement would safeguard Australian sovereignty and also allow a clean-up procedure after any radiation accident to be instigated quickly without delay or conflict. I do not want those vessels here but I would like to see some proper agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: My second concern is that some States are under a misapprehension about the extent of Commonwealth responsibility for safety planning for ships' visits. The Commonwealth has stated clearly its belief that safety planning rests in the main with the States. Each is expected to establish a ships' visits committee which would oversee and co-ordinate safety plans by organisations such as the State emergency services, the port authorities, and the police, fire and health departments. The Commonwealth, for its part, offers assistance with overall guidelines, port safety assessment and radiation monitoring and would co-ordinate any wider emergency support required via the Natural Disasters Organisation. However, some States have not so readily accepted the Commonwealth's delegation of safety matters. I understand that some State governments that oppose ships' visits on principle would prefer the Commonwealth to undertake responsibility for safety arrangements. Some States have said that if a visit were scheduled to one of their ports the Commonwealth guidelines would not be comprehensive enough or could not be met by the ports. This ambiguity is clearly unacceptable. Every step should be taken to reach unanimous understanding with the States on safety planning.

In addition, we cannot say with certainty that the State safety arrangements which exist at present are complete or comprehensive. If the Australian Democrats were interested in State safety, they would listen instead of yacking. In my State, which has the majority of warship visits, there has recently been some reorganisation of emergency services. I have been advised that Western Australian safety plans are incomplete. I also question the rationale behind safety planning for only a limited radiation incident. Radiation monitors are stationed only in the immediate vicinity of the port. The public has every right to be assured that safety planning is undertaken for major contingencies. Many of the ports which were assessed as suitable for visits of nuclear powered warships are located quite close to centres of large population. An accident would not have to be severe to threaten the health and safety of thousands of people. For example, I know of no evacuation plans for the general population in the case of a nuclear accident in any of the host ports.

Finally, I am not satisfied that the issue of radioactive waste discharge is under our control. There may not have been any measured discharge of radioactive waste in an Australian port but such discharges have occurred in Japan, Britain and the United States, all from United States Navy ships. According to one report, these incidents total more than 30. My understanding is that there is no written requirement for the ship's commanding officer to notify the port authorities of such a discharge. However, this requirement is important. The Japanese experience in 1968 and again in 1969 was that United States authorities refused to accept the evidence of portside radiation monitors and claimed that no radiation discharge had taken place, even though monitors clearly showed higher radiation levels in the vicinity of the United States submarine Swordfish. This question can be resolved only if the visiting ship's commander is clearly under an obligation to the host country to inform it immediately if any unscheduled discharge takes place. I make these points because the existing situation for visits by nuclear powered or armed ships is loosely defined. We shall all benefit if steps are taken to close loopholes and set down in firmer language the clear expectations that we hold for ships' visits. I brought up these points and took advantage of Senator Chipp's motion because I have been in contact with each of the States. I assure the Senate that there is a lot of misunderstanding between the States and the Commonwealth regarding who has to accept what responsibility. There is no provision for evacuation in any of the States. This matter is important. I take this opportunity to vent it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the matter raised by Senator McIntosh, I make it clear that I support the proposal he made that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence should look at whether our arrangements for safety in the event of a nuclear powered ship having an accident are adequate. A point that one has to understand in comparison with the accident at Chernobyl is that ships can be moved. One of the matters at which we must look is whether, in the event of an accident to a nuclear reactor in a ship, the ship can be moved away from where it endangers the population in the time scale in which the accident might occur.
—Can they be moved if there is a core meltdown on board?

—They can be towed or they can move under their own power. Towing would obviously be best. The Committee must be satisfied with these precautions. I would support, as I said to Senator McIntosh before, a reference to look into this. I think the precautions are adequate, but we must satisfy ourselves that they are. A static land based power plant is quite a different problem compared to a mobile ship. What comes out of the Chernobyl accident is emotion. There is no doubt that this is an unparalleled nuclear accident. It is not an unparalleled power generation accident. We do not yet know the scale on which the danger rests. The Soviet Union, as usual, has been extremely secretive about the scale of the accident. Its report of only two deaths is barely credible. Whether there are hundreds or perhaps even thousands dead, nobody knows. A lot of people are talking about the number, but nobody knows. There is no doubt that, in terms of nuclear power generation, this is an unparalleled accident. I give a word of caution. If one read the headlines about the Three Mile Island accident one would have thought in the early stages that it was a comparable accident. It was well said by someone after the Three Mile Island accident that a person could have stood naked on the boundary fence of the Three Mile Island plant for six days and the radiation--
—That was an apologist for the uranium industry.

—I do not appreciate the honourable senator's intervention. I have met many people who are totally ignorant of technology and irresponsible in what they say. The honourable senator is the first person I have met who is totally top of the class in both categories.
—Thank you. I take that as a great compliment.
—Yes, I know; I imagine you would. What I am getting at is that one wants to look at the way in which these events are projected. In the case of the Three Mile Island disaster-
—Put down your notes from the apologists and you will be right.

—I am sorry, I do not understand. The Australian Democrats are incomprehensible, as usual. What we want to get over is the fact that one wants to look at accidents in proportion. As far as I can see at the moment, this is an unparalleled nuclear accident. But all systems of power generation have accidents. What one wants to look at is how the accident level in nuclear power generation compares with other methods of power generation. Many countries in Europe and around the world are using nuclear power as a prime system of electric power generation. I cite three countries, Finland, Sweden and France, that are all moving towards half their power being generated by nuclear energy. They will not opt out of that form of power generation. What we ought to look at is whether, from the point of view of the rest of the world, this is a satisfactory, safe and acceptable means of power generation. There is no doubt at all that as the Soviet Union has been generating nuclear power, it has not been acceptable. The precautions taken by the--
—Go and tell that to the pregnant women around Chernobyl and see how they like that.
—Of course, he wouldn't know. He doesn't care about anybody but himself.
—Order!

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. The point about the risk is that we have to take it in comparison. We cannot take, as we tend to take, nuclear power accidents out of context and pretend that they are the only risks in power generation. A very interesting table was prepared, admittedly before the Chernobyl accident, on statistical evidence that I think is still valid. It pointed out that all forms of power generation cause deaths. The only way to compare the generation of power is by looking at how many deaths can be expected to be caused by the generation of a specific amount of power. Let us look at 10 gigawatt years of energy. What would be the expected deaths? From coal there would be 800 deaths, from oil 700, from wind 450, from hydro-electric power generation 100, from solar, or space heating, 95, and from nuclear power 8 1/2.
—You made it up, did you?
—No. That was produced by Lord Rothschild, a Labour adviser to the British Government.
—Look at the disasters that they have had.

—Britain has had disasters. It has had coal and oil disasters. What happens is that people look at the disasters in the area of nuclear power and from that they deduce the most bizarre conclusions. We could have an accident where a hydro-electric dam collapses and kills 1,000 people, but we do not deduce from that that hydro-electric power generation should cease. People deduce from that, if they are sensible, that they should improve the design standards of their dams so that the dams do not collapse. If nuclear power generation causes deaths we look at the way in which we can prevent that. We will not stop this system of power generation, particularly as coal and oil, by the way, cause quite serious environmental problems. The acid rain that is causing immense damage to Europe is caused by the oil and coal power generation in those countries, yet we hear nothing about that. People seem to have a fixation on the dangers-which are real but, relative to other forms of power generation, not excessive-of nuclear power generation. I heard nothing from Senator Chipp about the danger of hydro-electric power when 1,000 people were killed in the collapse of a hydro-electric power dam in Italy. We heard nothing from Senator Chipp then to the effect that hydro-electric power generation should be stopped. We do not know how many casualties there are now in this accident, but we hear what Senator Chipp deduces from this accident, caused in a country which is notoriously not using proper safety precautions. It is using graphite as a moderator when everyone else is using heavy water. It does not have an enclosing container which other countries have-
—Senator Collard can tell you that your last statement is not true.
—I would not trust anything that Senator Sanders said.
—That is what Senator Collard told us.

—I would not even accept that what Senator Sanders said Senator Collard said was correct, because Senator Sanders is notoriously a very unreliable senator. As a result of this accident Senator Chipp produced this motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes-
(a) the implications to life--
here comes a pure bit of Chippism--
and the planet of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster in the Soviet Union;
Of course there has been a risk to life! Of course there has been a loss of life!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp is always in space. That is why he is always talking about the planet.
—He may be, but this is not a very sensible motion for the Senate to accept. Nevertheless, that is what he said. His motion states further:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the possible contribution to this disaster by Australia in exporting uranium;

There is no way in which we will control the use of uranium by trying to produce an artificial shortage of it. There is far too much of it around the world. By being a reliable exporter of uranium, however, we can ensure that it is used only in nuclear power generation and that it is not used in reprocessing nor in fast breeder reactors, because the very effect of trying to produce an artificial shortage will be to encourage people to go in for reprocessing and fast breeder reactors. Of course, those two produce dangerous effects; they produce plutonium and that is what we must avoid. Our great contribution to the world would be as a reliable, safe provider of uranium, with proper safeguards, and that should be our role. The third point in Senator Chipp's motion is:
the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;

Of course it could! But so could any power generation produce casualties. We want to see this in perspective. The Democrats are getting highly emotional and they do not know the facts. I heard nothing from them when comparable accidents occurred in coal power producing plants, in hydro-electric power plants and in gas producing plants. But when there is an accident at a nuclear reactor, bang! The Democrats get very excited. The motion continues:
(d) the possible eventual danger to Australia in the event of any disasters;

That is very hard to see. I think it is most unlikely, with the distribution of nuclear power plants around the world, that Australia will be affected by them. Finally, we have the ridiculous conclusion in the motion, which is contrary to all the effect of the previous points:
the need to close all uranium mines in Australia.
As I have said, our duty to the world is to provide it with a reliable, sensible, controlled use of uranium.

I support the amendments that have been moved by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. I do not often support him but what he has said on these amendments is absolutely true. The first amendment deletes all the nonsense produced by the Democrats and states:
That the Government's policies-
Senator Durack will amend that to say `the Government and preceding governments'-
mean Australia makes no contribution to the USSR's supply of nuclear material;

That is patently true. The Soviet Union is a major producer of uranium-in fact, it is a net exporter. To say that our exports of uranium will make any difference to the availability of nuclear fuel in the Soviet Union is absolute nonsense. The Government's second amendment is:

that the Australian Government will pursue all opportunities for further strengthening of international co-operation in the area of mandatory international safety standards to minimise the possibility that such a disaster could be repeated in other places around the globe;

We can do that but we can only do it if we are ourselves a uranium exporter. If we are not we will have no standing in this matter and we will achieve absolutely nothing. As a major uranium exporter we can achieve something. The next amendment moved by Senator Evans is:

that while there is no cause for concern that fall-out from the Chernobyl accident will present any hazard in Australia, it is essential that this country continue to maintain adequate systems to monitor levels from all sources of radioactivity which may present a public health hazard;
I think that would be accepted by all honourable senators. The final amendment is:

the Government's resolve to pursue in international forums the establishment of a mandatory system requiring nations in which similar accidents occur to notify other countries which may be affected, at the first opportunity and in the fullest possible detail.

One of the greatest outrages of this accident has been the total secrecy of the Soviet Union. It has not revealed the scale of the disaster to its own people or to neighbours who might be affected. It is a very serious disaster and we must not, in any way, ignore that. What we must do is keep in perspective the fact that all systems of power generation cost lives. That is sad but true. We want to keep in perspective the lives lost in nuclear power generation and not go off on a totally emotional binge as have the Australian Democrats.
